story:
freight.

Written By: Amber eL
Directed By: Camille Kashaka
Produced By: eL & Fearless Artistry
Cast: Karen Lawrence (as 26), Jasmine Jackson (as 44), and Shemika Berry (as Office Worker)

WHAT IS freight.? - A synopsis

freight. is an exploration into the lives of three Black women who, for different reasons, have found themselves sitting in the benefits office on the last Monday in November of 2008 at the onset of a global recession. During this visit, they share many of their unique experiences and have their understandings of life challenged. freight. takes a glimpse at the humanity of those in need, and how that humanity effects the lives of 3 Black women as they become entangled in a system governed by many who are not interested in ever learning their names. This piece attempts to dismiss the false narrative constructed about Black women in the United States and their relationships to government social safety nets. 

From the playwright:

There is a common saying of "being one illness or accident away from the poor house." For much of the world, the poor house is the structure in which they live presently. The risks then of living, are not associated with stock options, but with choosing between nutrient rich foods or having enough food to last until the next payday. The risk is in choosing between having a day's pay or taking the day off to see a doctor (or spending 12 hours in the emergency room if you are uninsured). The risk becomes dealing with the crushing reality of uncertainty. The risk, is in finding the space to dream when you are intimately acquainted with a profound and persistent lack.

Like many things that are lingering from the Regan era in the United States, the myth of the welfare queen still shames and stigmatizes poor women of color; particularly Black women. It manages to place all of the burdens imposed by the various systems at play squarely on the shoulders of the victims of both active oppression and passive neglect. It then mocks these same women when they attempt to free themselves from the trap engineered for them. In this decades long, one dimensional portrayal of what it means to be poor, Black, Female, and a U.S. citizen, yet another aspect of Black womanhood becomes profane.

freight. was written to largely to dismiss (or at minimum counteract) a damaging narrative that has been thrust upon a community of human beings. This work is expressly intended to go beyond how popular culture and conservative politicians have defined poor Black women in the U.S. to the world. We visit them while they are entangled in the process of accessing help. We can know them as much as they choose to be known. We can hear their voices and their stories, and most importantly we can listen intently to their truth.

These three Black women are in different stages of their personal evolution. However, they are all grappling with what to do with the burdens that they carry. In this way, freight. is about how living, surviving, thriving, peace, happiness, and success are conceptualized under the ever present rule of poverty.


WHEN & WHERE?

The world premiere performances of freight. will be staged at the Anacostia Arts Center (1231 Good Hope Rd SE) in Washington, DC.

Dates: Saturday, June 14th @ 8:00pm, Sunday, June 15th @ 3:00pm, & Sunday, June 15th @ 8:00pm


WHO ARE WE?

Fearless Artistry Mission Statement:

Fearless Artistry is committed to confronting reality by challenging current narratives about marginalized, voiceless and minority populations. Fearless takes an aggressive approach to love, healing, and acceptance through art, drama therapy and new play development in a world that suppresses critical, intuitive and empathetic thought.

About Fearless:

Fearless Artistry is a new artistry collective headed by the multi-talented Camille Kashaka. The core values of Fearless Artistry are FEARLESSNESS, ACCESSIBILITY, CONVERSATION, and COOPERATION.

Fearlessness comes from creating and maintaining a safe space to confront all parts of our existence. No matter how ugly, it is all beautiful.

Accessibility comes from providing that safe space for the invisible, marginalized, traditionally underserved and ignored populations like people of color, women, prisoners, and people with disabilities.

Conversation comes from honestly confronting and embracing our stories, no matter how dark or light, and returning the favor by respecting the humanity of each other. So often we condemn and ostracize members of our human family. Fearless works to promote reconciliation through a celebration of difference.

Finally, Cooperation comes from working within the philosophy that all things feed each other. One broken part of a system means that the entire system is broken. In order to truly facilitate the other core values, we work diligently to run via consensus, responding directly to the needs of all parties involved. Community has a major stake in the choices in production and programming of Fearless. 

   

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP!!!

                       Our goal is to raise $3,000

You may have already noticed that we have incorporated all kinds of special perks that are attached to the generous donations to show our gratitude. We have perks ranging from a special thanks in our program, to being a part of the upcoming Fearless Writing Retreat!

Through your gracious contribution we will be able to…

  • Secure our performance venue
  • Rent set pieces and equipment
  • Rent costumes
  • Rent rehearsal space
  • Produce marketing materials (programs, posters, flyers, etc.)
  • AND MOST IMPORTANTLY: Provide a salary to our actors and technicians

We know that not everybody will be able to donate money but that doesn’t mean you can’t help! We would greatly appreciate if you could get the word out there! Share our Indiegogo and link and talk up our production on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, at work, at school or anywhere else you can!

Your contribution supports the professional growth and artistic exploration of each of the fantastic artists involved in the production.

We appreciate you all for taking the time to check out our site and for sending love and light our way! We recognize your positive energy and hope to see you all at the show!


THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR ALL OF YOUR SUPPORT!

WE APPRECIATE YOU BEYOND WORDS!

story:
Nataraj West is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Nataraj West must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only, and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The above video features my work with my teacher's dance company the Nataraj Dancers. Nataraj West (a non-profit organization and a sister organization of the Nataraj Dancers) is raising funds to support a concert of classical Indian dance (featuring me, Justine Lemos)  and a live sarod and tabla performance by Bruce Hamm and a featured guest tabla-ist. The concert will be presented on November 14th for the Hindu Festival of Lights, or Divali. Concerts like this are a rare treat on the Mendocino Coast and, unfortunately, not at all cheap to produce.
 Your donations will:
~ Insure the musicians are paid a fair wage for their performance
~ Support purchases of flowers to adorn the hall
~ Help with hall draping and hall rental
~ Dry clean costumes (required as sweat ruins the silk of the priceless costumes made in India)
~ Offset costs of crew for the program
~ Produce program playbills
~ Produce posters and fliers in advance of the program

All your donations are tax-deductible. Thank you for supporting the arts in our community.

story:
(English version bellow)

Voici l’opportunité de contribuer à mettre de l’avant la danse, non pas dans son aspect compétitif, mais inclusif et collaboratif.

L’artiste professionnelle en danse contemporaine Marie-Michelle Darveau s’investit, depuis sa graduation en 2014 de The School of Dance à Ottawa, dans le développement de sa carrière d’interprète et dans l’épanouissement de son parcours en enseignement. Œuvrant à la fois en Ontario et au Québec, les projets de son parcours professionnel sont interreliés par 3 caractéristiques: éduquer le jeune public, développer l’ancrage communautaire et optimiser l’accessibilité et la diffusion de la pratique de la danse.

Ses nombreuses expériences de mentorat au sein de plusieurs festivals et événements amateurs et professionnels lui ont permis d’acquérir le bagage nécessaire à la réalisation du présent projet. L’opportunité d’agir en tant que chorégraphe dans le projet, tout en étant guidé par une sommité, Meagan O’Shea, contribuera à l’élargissement de son champ de compétences. « Ma pratique en tant qu’enseignante et chorégraphe pour les jeunes influence positivement mon parcours d’interprète. »

Présentation du projet

La beauté des épines est un projet de création chorégraphique en danse contemporaine rassemblant un groupe de filles de 9 à 25 ans. L’idée est de distribuer un journal à chacune des participantes dans lequel elles partagent leurs peurs et leurs insécurités quotidiennes. Les journaux deviennent la source d’inspiration pour une recherche de mouvement en studio menant à la réalisation d’une chorégraphie commune où les interprètes seront amenés à travailler sur leur confiance en soi ainsi que sur leur emphatie. Le point culminant du projet est la réalisation d’une vidéo-danse dans laquelle la passion de chacune des interprètes est mise en valeur et leurs émotions sont mises en commun.

Leur force, leur vulnérabilité, leur soif d’apprendre, leur curiosité et surtout leur regard critique sur la danse contemporaine deviennent les moteurs de création.  La diversité du groupe en est la principale richesse : leur âge, leur corps, leur nationalité, leur éducation, leur formation et plus encore.

Cette opportunité d’investissement engendre d’importantes retombées : rendre la danse contemporaine plus accessible, contribuer au cheminement d’une artiste émergente et participer au développement de l’identité et de la personnalité des jeunes.

Votre contribution, essentielle et grandement appréciée, servira à financer la première phase du projet, incluant la recherche autour de la thématique, la conclusion de partenariats avec les collaborateurs et la préparation des prochaines phases de création et de réalisation.

P.S. C’est avec des cennes que l’on fait des piasses, en d’autres mots chaque petites contributions font une différence.

_________________________________________________________

Here is your chance to support a project that puts dance forward as an inclusive, collaborative, and non-competitive artform.

Professional dance artist Marie-Michelle Darveau has been, since her graduation from The School of Dance in 2014, devoting herself to developing her career as a dance artist and teacher. The projects she has so far initiated in dance communities in both Ontario and Quebec have three common points: educating young audiences, establishing a sense of community, and optimizing the accessibility and diffusion of dance.

Marie-Michelle’s many mentoring experiences at various amateur and professional festivals and events have allowed her to acquire the skills necessary for the production of this particular project. The opportunity to act as choreographer for the project, under the guidance of dance mentor Meagan O’Shea, will broaden her scope of abilities. “My practice teaching and choreographing for youth has had a positive influence on my career as a dance artist.”

Project Description

La beauté des épines is a contemporary dance project that brings together a group of girls aged between 9 and 25 years old. The idea is to entrust each participant with a journal in which she is asked to share her day-to-day fears and insecurities. The journals will then become the source of inspiration for movement research, which will subsequently lead to the development of a collaborative creation where the interpreters will have to work on their self-confidence and empathy. The point of culmination is the production of a dance video in which the passion of each dancer is showcased, and their common emotions brought together.

Their strength, vulnerability, curiosity, thirst to learn, and particularly their critical vision of contemporary dance will become the creative impetus. The group’s diversity is its most important asset: their age, bodies, nationality, education, training, and much more.

This opportunity allows the possibility of many important ramifications: making contemporary dance more accessible, contributing to the professional growth of an emerging artist, and participating in the development of youths identity and personality.

Your contribution, which is essential and greatly appreciated, will serve to finance the first phase of the project, including the thematic research, the solidification of partnerships with collaborators, and the preparation of the next phases of creation and production.

P.S. Every penny counts!

story:
Short Summary

This is a Protest of What Happened examines the "deconstruction of the administrative state" through the lens of Italian Futurism smashed against the giddy dread of Donald Trump's favorite musical, Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Phantom of the Opera. It is a manic post-logic performance collage, inspired by our manic post-logic world in which everything is a protest of something.

This piece will be performed at The Brick's THIS IS NOT NORMAL FESTIVAL on June 24th and 25th of 2017 featuring the work of Dara Malina (Lead Artist), Alexis Roblan (Lead Artist), Kenard Jackson (Performer/Co-Creator), Eunyoung Bona-Jung (Performer/Co-Creator), Gina Manziello (Performer/Co-Creator), Kea Trevett (Performer/Co-Creator), Jonathan Randell Silver (Co-Creator/Sound Designer), Amanda Clegg-Lyon (Lighting Designer), Kadaja Brown (Assistant Director), and Michael Padden (Producer). 

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT: On November 8, 2016, the world changed dramatically with the election of Donald J. Trump to the Presidency of the United States of America. Since, then we've all been trying to understand what this new administration will do to  the future of democracy and to the world at large.

This Is Not Normal is an arts festival at The Brick. Replete with weekly cabarets and collective action projects, the festival aims to remind us of the reality we live in and the reality we are moving toward.

This is a Protest of What Happened will take a look at the corrosive qualities of the new administration in an attempt to gauge what comes next for all of us. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $1,500.00 for this project. This money will be used for the following:

  • Stipends for our wonderful artists who are giving so much of themselves to create this piece from scratch. - $900 ($150 per person)
  • Rehearsal Space - $100
  • Insurance to cover our actors in case an accident occurs - $240
  • A few dollars for props and other related production items - $250
  • Money for Market and Publicity Materials so that people will know about our show-$100

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to purchase tickets in addition to contributing, you can do so by following this link: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/973528

story:
JUGGALICIOUS

by Britton Buttrill

Directed by Celine Rosenthal. 

What is a Juggalo? Not just a fan of the Insane Clown Posse. Being a Juggalo being part of a family. When Ice Pete, a young Juggalo from Alabama, discovers that his grandmother, Mammy, is in need of a new kidney, he and his friends Fluffy, Hatchett, and Twista take drastic but misguided means to insure her survival, journeying to the Gathering of the Juggalos and ultimately into the heart of the Dark Carnival itself. 

Britton Buttrill: Playwright

Britton Buttrill’s plays include The Saint Maarten Series; (MITF Short Play Lab, NYC), Iris; (Ego Actus, NYC/Midtown International Theatre Festival, NYC), Uffizi (Riant Theatre, NYC/Bottled Lightning, Atlanta Fringe, Atlanta), and Scratching (Pinch n' Ouch Theatre, Atlanta). His plays have received staged readings through the Work With Me Here Project (Here Arts Center, NYC), Naked Angels’ Tuesdays @9, Horizon Theatre, Pinch n' Ouch Theatre, Drive By Theatre Project, and The Essential Theatre Festival. Dramaturgy credits include The Odyssey at Georgia Shakespeare Festival and Red at Theatrical Outfit. He was the recipient of The New South Young Playwright’s Award and an E.B. Osborne Artist Residency Fellowship at The Purnell School. He is an Associate Artist with Pinch n’ Ouch Theatre, an Associate Artist with Bottled Lightning Theatre, a script reader for MCC Theatre and a member of the Dramatists Guild of America.

Britton is currently a Playwriting MFA candidate at The New School for Drama.

www.brittonbuttrill.com

Celine Rosenthal: Director

Celine Rosenthal is an NYU Tisch Alum, Tony Nominated Producer (Leap of Faith, Seminar) and Directing MFA candidate at The New School for Drama. She is a founding member of Neela Theatre Project in Mumbai, and a Collaborating Choreographer with General Mischeif. Selected directing credits: Rose Petals (NYMF), Four on The Floor (New York City Center Studios), Three If By Air (Manhattan Movement & Arts Center), Roberto Aguirre Sacasa's The Weird (Manhattan Theatre Source), Deployed: A New Musical (The June Havoc & The Gene Frankel),  and The Post Office (Bank St) .


What we need:

    -$750: Marketing
    -$150: Volunteer Accident Insurance (Required by FringeNYC)
    -$2000: Artist Fees, including stipends for actors and designers. 
    -$1000: Lights, Sound, Props

The Impact

Juggalicious is a dark comedy about of a group of fans devoted to the music and theology of the horror-core rap group, The Insane Clown Posse. These individuals, who define themselves as “Juggalos” have a communal devotion and adherence to religious and spiritual philosophies put forth through the albums of this rap group; a group who have been dubbed by Rolling Stone to be the “worst band in the world”. Yet, the Juggalos are representative of a social demographic; specifically the ostracized, the alienated, and the impoverished persons in American society. Juggalicious strives to explore themes of class-consciousness, the dichotomy between the privileged and the unprivileged, and in addition the fragmentation of the nuclear family. At its core, this play is about the human struggle against the immovable obstacles of poverty and abuse, and the drastic, though often destructive, measures one may take in order to overcome.

        Juggalicious bears a contemporary relevance specifically because of the recent legal entanglements surrounding The Insane Clown Posse. In 2013 the FBI elevated the Juggalos to gang status, based merely on a series of isolated crimes committed by individuals identifying as Juggalos. This, in turn, has lead to unnecessary harassment by law enforcement officials towards a group of individuals simply because they have a particular taste in music.  In response, The Insane Clown Posse has sued the FBI in order to get Juggalos removed from the FBI’s gang classification. The ACLU recently came to their aid, and they continue to fight against the criminal stigma associated with their fans. On a political level, this promises to be a landmark legal case in Free Speech and will set certain standards in the American Justice system regarding gang classifications.
story_txt:
JUGGALICIOUSby Britton ButtrillDirected by Celine Rosenthal. What is a Juggalo? Not just a fan of the Insane Clown Posse. Being a Juggalo being part of a family. When Ice Pete, a young Juggalo from Alabama, discovers that his grandmother, Mammy, is in need of a new kidney, he and his friends Fluffy, Hatchett, and Twista take drastic but misguided means to insure her survival, journeying to the Gathering of the Juggalos and ultimately into the heart of the Dark Carnival itself. Britton Buttrill: Playwright
Britton
Buttrill’s plays include The Saint
Maarten Series; (MITF Short Play Lab, NYC), Iris; (Ego Actus, NYC/Midtown International Theatre Festival, NYC),
Uffizi (Riant Theatre, NYC/Bottled
Lightning, Atlanta Fringe, Atlanta), and Scratching
(Pinch n' Ouch Theatre, Atlanta). His plays have received staged readings
through the Work With Me Here Project
(Here Arts Center, NYC), Naked Angels’ Tuesdays @9, Horizon Theatre, Pinch n'
Ouch Theatre, Drive By Theatre Project, and The Essential Theatre
Festival. Dramaturgy credits include The
Odyssey at Georgia Shakespeare Festival and Red at Theatrical Outfit. He was the recipient of The New South
Young Playwright’s Award and an E.B. Osborne Artist Residency Fellowship at The
Purnell School. He is an Associate Artist with Pinch n’ Ouch Theatre, an
Associate Artist with Bottled Lightning Theatre, a script reader for MCC
Theatre and a member of the Dramatists Guild of America. 
Britton is currently a Playwriting
MFA candidate at The New School for Drama.www.brittonbuttrill.com
Celine Rosenthal: Director
Celine Rosenthal is an NYU Tisch Alum,
Tony Nominated Producer (Leap of Faith, Seminar) and Directing MFA
candidate at The New School for Drama. She is a founding member of Neela
Theatre Project in Mumbai, and a Collaborating Choreographer with General
Mischeif. Selected directing credits: Rose Petals (NYMF), Four on
The Floor (New York City Center Studios), Three If By Air (Manhattan
Movement & Arts Center), Roberto Aguirre Sacasa's The Weird (Manhattan
Theatre Source), Deployed: A New Musical (The June Havoc & The Gene
Frankel),  and The Post Office (Bank St) .
What we need:-$750: Marketing-$150: Volunteer Accident Insurance (Required by FringeNYC)-$2000: Artist Fees, including stipends for actors and designers. -$1000: Lights, Sound, Props  The Impact

story:
This Fall Joint Productions presents MacIvor Mania! at the Barbara Barrett Theatre in the St. John’s Arts and Culture Centre. This is the company’s fifth (sixth, seventh, and eighth) show, following several well attended and critically acclaimed productions at this venue over the past two years. MacIvor Mania is four distinct plays from Canadian playwright, Daniel MacIvor.   Never Swim Alone, This is a Play, Wild Abandon, and See Bob Run. His play, Never Swim Alone won the award for Over All Excellence at the 1999 New York Fringe Festival and was remounted Off Broadway at the Soho Playhouse in 2000. 

Never Swim Alone  is a competition between a tall man and an imperceptibly shorter man. This is a Play is a play, about a play, about a play. Wild Abandon is the story of a man named Steve and an egg in a cage; "as yet I have been unsuccessful although I do continue, from time to time to try to disappear". See Bob Run is a one-woman play about Bob and her journey to the water, where she hopes she can wash away the brutal reality of her past and enter a fantasy of the "most perfect pretend". MacIvor Mania! will perform Dec. 3 - 7th, 2014 at The Barbara Barrett Theatre in St. John's, Newfoundland. Joint Productions has proven with ambitious projects in the past that we can transform and create magical things in the Barbara Barrett Theatre. Watch as we create four unique and captivating productions in a single weekend.

In order to make this festival happen, we need help from the community.  This is where you can help us make this ambitious festival a reality.  Without your help, MacIvor Mania! wouldn't be possible . We are presenting this festival with an affordable $35 pass option, see all four shows for only $8.75 per show buy purchasing a festival pass. These affordable rates are made possible by campaigns and fundraisers such as this one!  Please help our team put this incredible series of shows on stage for you, our wonderful audience.  From the cast and crew of Joint Productions, we are honoured to showcase the remarkable work of Daniel MacIvor.   Have a look at our perks, and make a donation today. Each small donation, be it $5 or $50, helps us towards our goal. Once again, thank you for helping us present this first ever festival of MacIvor Mania!   


Joint Productions

story:
Thank You for your contributions thus far....

PLEASE SEE OUR RE-LAUNCH (PHASE 2)  OF OUR INDIEGOGO  CAMPAIGN.. coming soon....


HERE I AM- A New Gay Themed Musical.....

http://vimeo.com/101441855

Synopsis:

Set in a successful cabaret bar in the West Village of Manhattan, Here I Am is a story about Love and Friendship.

It's a story about surviving some of lifes many challenges after "coming out". 

It's about Embracing Who You Are.

Miss Dee Vah and the Deevettes are in the throws of the   final dress rehearsal for a benefit to raise money to stop violence against gays. Christine is sideswiped by her ex-girlfriends Jessie sudden arrival after a 2 year absence.

To complicate the situation further , Stuart, who is battling his own demons and loss of a loved one has to contend with an out of control rehearsal as well as his anger toward Jessie whom he holds responsible for that loss.

BE A PART OF THIS INCREDIBLE PROJECT!

DONATE NOW!
Your Donation will be used for our Theater Rental: $10,000
OR....to Pay The Actors: $40,000

story:
The Eastside Actor's Lab was started by me, Kjerstine Anderson, and Trent Latta when we met on a commercial set and discovered a mutual love of craft and desire to improve as actors.  Being both residents of the eastside, we started meeting weekly to build our skills and talk about our future creative hopes and dreams.  As we worked, we thought that maybe others would benefit from our meetings, and decided to reach out to other actors and see if they might be interested. 

We have been overwhelmed by the inquiries for our group, and have developed two six-week series in Meisner technique; offering them for free to actors who live on (or would like to commute to) the eastside.  

We are passionate about bringing more theater art to the Eastside (the area east of Seattle).  There are many fewer opportunities for skill building and production outside of Seattle, and we have been overwhelmed by the excitement of artists in our community for our skill-building course.    Your donation would provide space for our artists to meet weekly and practice craft.  We are a fledgling operation, with hopes to produce work and bring more culture to our community. 

We need your help to provide this service to our community and to begin to grow a culture of theater art on the eastside!  Thank you for your consideration, even a small amount goes a long way.

story:
We at 7 Daughters of Eve Thtr. & Perf. Co. have been developing this piece since 2014, beginning with workshops at Dixon Place and at the formal launch of 7 Daughters at the Martin E. Segal Center on April 6th, 2015. We grew and solidified the piece through independent research initiatives, related performances (see our 12 SHOUTS TO THE TEN FORGOTTEN HEAVENS at the Whitney Museum of American Art) and several residencies at Mount Tremper Arts in Ulster County, NY, and Abrons Arts Center in NYC. 

The SASQUATCH RITUALS are a cycle of site-specific, live ritual performance installations performed by a rotation of six women. They begin with a study of the eyewitness accounts of Sasquatch encounters and are concerned in particular with the patterns of language that American people use on the internet to describe something they cannot explain. They document and contemplate, without metaphor (but not without humor), our spiral-shaped journey researching and investigating the Bigfoot phenomenon in the United States and Canada.  

The SASQUATCH RITUALS are physically performed anecdotal evidence of our relationship to Nature, science and technology, a mapping of the unknown within our selves, our consciousness and our collective & collected mythological memory.  

The ‘truth’ of the elusive, nocturnal forest beings’ existence (or lack thereof) aside, Sasquatch, walking the mysterious line between actual and imagined existence, represents the option each individual has as a birthright: to become part of a greater totality – an opportunity to politely decline the Cartesian separations between mind and matter, individual and environment.   

SASQUATCH RITUALS seek to restore the reciprocity between the hidden presences of the land and the recesses of our American imaginations, bypassing the pressurized and pressuring civilization in its current dark age of disconnection, consumption, and over-accumulation.   

In order to fulfill the shamanic aspect of the RITUALS, the theatrical performances for humans have been balanced by performances for the Sasquatches themselves – on their turf – out in the woods, in locations that evidence a concentration of sightings, at night. That which has been sourced for the purposes of theatrical performance (or anything else for that matter), has also been given back to the land and its hidden populace, by whom we are always watched. 

The Kitchen performance was a sharing of our experiences as women in an isolated group, out in the woods, at night, without men or weapons, conjuring a communication with something we cannot see or understand. It includes textual contributions from myself and members of the ensemble Laurena Allan, Lindsay Hockaday, Eleanor Hutchins, Laura Stinger and Sarah Willis, with performances by Maurina Lioce, Linda Mancini, and Jessica Weinstein, music by Julie LaMendola, and Alexis and Lindsay Powell, accompanied by Sound Designer Keenan Hurley and his bandmates Tony Macht and Peter McNally. Costumes by Becky Hubbert, lighting design by Sophie Sotsky, set design by Elena Tilli. Dramaturgy by Clarinda MacLow, Stage Management by Molly Zimmelman with assistance from Leonie Bell, technical direction by Tavish Miller, and we are produced by Sarah Cameron Hughes.

Your FULLY TAX-DEDUCTIBLE contribution will directly support these artists, help us cover rentals of some very special props and make an archival video recording for posterity but also to help us garner interest from other presenters who might extend the life of the project and the production. We hope to bring this work to as many places as we can.

It is also worth mentioning that SASQUATCH RITUALS is a twin project, along with an experimental play with songs entitled THE SECURELY CONFERRED, VOUCHSAFED KEEPSAKES OF MAERY S., written and directed by Sibyl Kempson with music by Graham Reynolds, currently in development with residencies at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, and New Dramatists, winner of a 2016 Frederick Loewe Award for Musical Theater, and is set to premiere in Fall 2018, venue TBA. 

If you feel you'd like to help, but aren't able to make a financial contribution, we hope you'll consider sharing this page with others who you think would be interested in supporting. Either way, it will mean a great deal to us! 

Many thanks,

Sibyl Kempson & 7 Daughters of Eve

story:
Our Story

"Two minutes to midnight" is the title of the play these talented and determined kids, hope to be performing at the Worlds Festival of Children's Theater. It is a piece they created specifically for the Festival. It was written in the words of, and developed in the collaborative efforts by the actors, whom are all under the age of 14, and young adults, who are alumni of the Esartes program. All under the direction of Edward Daranyi, a volunteer director from the Stratford Festival of Canada. "Two minutes to midnight" narrates the ridiculously sad and universal reality of children and war.

Esartes has been quietly functioning for eight years in the rural communities of the municipality of Suchitoto. It offers a safe environment for the youth of these communities to discover creativity, self expression and skill building through theater arts workshops. Local children and young adults both participate in programing with a special focus on gender equality, conflict management and the construction of a culture of peace.

To let the children perform on the world stage and tell their story is our goal. El Salvador, once a  banana republic, has been systematically denied its right to development and self-determination, and recently disqualified as a sh * thole country. These youth believe differently and they have a story to tell and would like to showcase it to the world, showing of course, otherwise. For the past year they have been focused and working hard in preparing for this opportunity to attend the Worlds Festival of Children's Theatre. Not knowing if they are in fact going, has been a challenge to their great efforts. 

To date, half of the production process has already been raised. What they need is to still raise the other half, for things like airline tickets and transportation, insurance, travel documents and notarial expenses for the children and young adult chaperones.

Esartes is a project promoted locally by the Art Association for  Development. It has been in association with both the Stratford Festival, which transmits professional training and Cuso International, which facilitates volunteer support from Canada, since 2009.

We believe art can transform the world. If you do as well, we ask you to please support these children's efforts. 

From the bottom of their hearts they say MUCHAS GRACIAS.

story:
HELP US REACH OUR STRETCH GOAL OF $3,500!

Due to the generosity of our 63 backers, we have not only hit our initial goal of $2,000, but exceeded it! You've put your money where your mouth is, and now it's up to us to really make sure we turn it the freak out. And we can't wait to do just that! Now, we're expanding to a stretch goal of $3,500. Our initial goal was what we needed to make this happen at all - with our expanded goal, we'll be able to have better (read: larger) rehearsal spaces, provide better for our artists, and more!

 

Oscar has crafted himself into an icon. Oscar is Rihanna at the Met Gala and Lindsay Lohan in rehab. Oscar has given up on the distinction of reality and fantasy. Oscar thinks nothing can catch up with him.

WHAT ARE WE DOING?

OSCAR at the Crown is the story of Oscar Wilde’s creation, mystification, desecration, and eventual damnation – a kaleidoscope of what we are, who we want others to see, and what we make ourselves to be. It is an immersive nightclub pop performance detailing the rise and fall of one of history’s most flamboyant characters, along with his wife, his lover, and his followers. And at the same time, it’s about us, here in 2017, staring at our phones, wondering if our latest Instagram is going to flop and if the bombs have started flying yet.

After performing to sold out houses in its first iteration at the American Repertory Theater’s OBERON, OSCAR at the Crown is undergoing new developmental work and popping up in Brooklyn this December for a one-night-only work-in-progress performance. Over the course of a two-week rehearsal period, we’ll bring together a diverse group of performers to deepen and complicate the story, learn new music and choreography, and explore not only the world of Oscar’s 1890s, but the ways we all create and consume each other and ourselves today.

Check out some highlights from our first workshop production at OBERON:

 

WHERE DO YOU COME IN?

To make this new workshop happen we need rehearsal space, sound equipment, printed pages, and stipends for our talented team of artists. We don’t need much more than that, but in the spirit of Oscar Wilde and The Real Housewives… we’ll take anything we can get. To show our deep gratitude for your support of this project, we’ve got some great rewards we’re excited to share with you – from downloads of music from the show to social media takeovers and photos shoots to voice lessons.

What if we don’t reach our goal? That’s okay! We’ll work with what we’ve got, still do our work, and present this workshop version of the show to the best of our ability.

WHO ARE WE?

Mark Mauriello

is a Brooklyn-based performer and theater artist. Graduating from Harvard University, he has worked and performed extensively at the American Repertory Theater, including in Diane Paulus and Randy Weiner’s The Donkey Show and Taylor Mac’s The Lily’s Revenge. Original works: OSCAR at The Crown… (Creator/Oscar Wilde) and Julie Cooper (Creator/Director). Other performances include Little Murders (Marjorie Newquist), The Blast with You Are Here, The Rocky Horror Show (Dr. Frank-N-Furter), Clubland (James St. James), as well as nightlife performance in Boston, New York, and Berlin. Learn more at www.markmauriello.com and learn too much at @maarkm.

Andrew Barrett Cox

is a composer, lyricist, choreographer and performer working in New York. His music has been described as "electric, explosive, uniquely contemporary electronic pop." Since 2007, he has been composing in various genres of rock, metal, pop, electro pop, EDM, country, and orchestral music. His show Clubland as well as his original score for OSCAR at the Crown premiered at the American Repertory Theater's OBERON. To check out more of Andrew’s work, visit www.andrewbarretcox.com.

Garrett Allen

is a Brooklyn based director and video/performance artist. Their recent credits include In The Blood (Signature, assistant director), Henry IV Pt. 2 (Oregon Shakespeare Festival, assistant director), Samara (Soho Rep., assistant director), Tell Hector I Miss Him (Atlantic Theatre Company, assistant director), Orpheus in the Berkshires (Williamstown Theatre Festival, assistant director), Girls Play and Last Meal (Williamstown Theatre Festival, director). Their video and performance art works have been exhibited at Harvard, INDEX Festival @ Knockdown Center, Signal Gallery, and in several print/online publications. www.garrettcallen.com

Eleanor Regan

has produced work at the Edinburgh Fringe, the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, Studio Theatre in DC, and an abandoned burger restaurant in Carrol Gardens. All of her social media includes her middle name.

HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

If you’re not able to contribute financially, we still thank you for taking the time to check us out, support us, and gladly accept tweets, shares, likes, and more! #OSCARatTheCrown
story_txt: HELP US REACH OUR STRETCH GOAL OF $3,500!Due to the generosity of our 63 backers, we have not only hit our initial goal of $2,000, but exceeded it! You've put your money where your mouth is, and now it's up to us to really make sure we turn it the freak out. And we can't wait to do just that! Now, we're expanding to a stretch goal of $3,500. Our initial goal was what we needed to make this happen at all - with our expanded goal, we'll be able to have better (read: larger) rehearsal spaces, provide better for our artists, and more! Oscar has crafted himself into an icon. Oscar is Rihanna at the Met Gala and Lindsay Lohan in rehab. Oscar has given up on the distinction of reality and fantasy. Oscar thinks nothing can catch up with him.WHAT ARE WE DOING?OSCAR at the Crown is the story of Oscar Wilde’s creation, mystification, desecration, and eventual damnation – a kaleidoscope of what we are, who we want others to see, and what we make ourselves to be. It is an immersive nightclub pop performance detailing the rise and fall of one of history’s most flamboyant characters, along with his wife, his lover, and his followers. And at the same time, it’s about us, here in 2017, staring at our phones, wondering if our latest Instagram is going to flop and if the bombs have started flying yet.After performing to sold out houses in its first iteration at the American Repertory Theater’s OBERON, OSCAR at the Crown is undergoing new developmental work and popping up in Brooklyn this December for a one-night-only work-in-progress performance. Over the course of a two-week rehearsal period, we’ll bring together a diverse group of performers to deepen and complicate the story, learn new music and choreography, and explore not only the world of Oscar’s 1890s, but the ways we all create and consume each other and ourselves today.Check out some highlights from our first workshop production at OBERON: WHERE DO YOU COME IN?To make this new workshop happen we need rehearsal space, sound equipment, printed pages, and stipends for our talented team of artists. We don’t need much more than that, but in the spirit of Oscar Wilde and The Real Housewives… we’ll take anything we can get. To show our deep gratitude for your support of this project, we’ve got some great rewards we’re excited to share with you – from downloads of music from the show to social media takeovers and photos shoots to voice lessons.What if we don’t reach our goal? That’s okay! We’ll work with what we’ve got, still do our work, and present this workshop version of the show to the best of our ability.WHO ARE WE?Mark Mauriellois a Brooklyn-based performer and theater artist. Graduating from Harvard University, he has worked and performed extensively at the American Repertory Theater, including in Diane Paulus and Randy Weiner’s The Donkey Show and Taylor Mac’s The Lily’s Revenge. Original works: OSCAR at The Crown… (Creator/Oscar Wilde) and Julie Cooper (Creator/Director). Other performances include Little Murders (Marjorie Newquist), The Blast with You Are Here, The Rocky Horror Show (Dr. Frank-N-Furter), Clubland (James St. James), as well as nightlife performance in Boston, New York, and Berlin. Learn more at www.markmauriello.com and learn too much at @maarkm.Andrew Barrett Coxis a composer, lyricist, choreographer and performer working in New York. His music has been described as "electric, explosive, uniquely contemporary electronic pop." Since 2007, he has been composing in various genres of rock, metal, pop, electro pop, EDM, country, and orchestral music. His show Clubland as well as his original score for OSCAR at the Crown premiered at the American Repertory Theater's OBERON. To check out more of Andrew’s work, visit www.andrewbarretcox.com.Garrett Allenis a Brooklyn based director and video/performance artist. Their recent credits include In The Blood (Signature, assistant director), Henry IV Pt. 2 (Oregon Shakespeare Festival, assistant director), Samara (Soho Rep., assistant director), Tell Hector I Miss Him (Atlantic Theatre Company, assistant director), Orpheus in the Berkshires (Williamstown Theatre Festival, assistant director), Girls Play and Last Meal (Williamstown Theatre Festival, director). Their video and performance art works have been exhibited at Harvard, INDEX Festival @ Knockdown Center, Signal Gallery, and in several print/online publications. www.garrettcallen.comEleanor Reganhas produced work at the Edinburgh Fringe, the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, Studio Theatre in DC, and an abandoned burger restaurant in Carrol Gardens. All of her social media includes her middle name.HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?If you’re not able to contribute financially, we still thank you for taking the time to check us out, support us, and gladly accept tweets, shares, likes, and more! #OSCARatTheCrown

story:
A Full Run of Suddenly Mommy at Theatre Passe Muraille's Mainspace Dec 3-8, 2013.

Thank you to everyone who donated, shared our link, and supported us!! Tickets are now on sale via www.artsboxoffice.ca
Dec 3-8, 7:30pm shows and 2pm matinees on Wed, Sat and Sun.
Can't wait to see you! ThankYOU!

Suddenly Mommy! 

Every woman who's had a baby recognizes the moment she goes from "hey Sexy!" to suddenly, mommy. So, when a party girl finds herself with an "instant family", she has to navigate the pitfalls of new motherhood – and the advice of her supermodel friend, her own mother, and even Celine Dion – in order to have it all, whatever that means!

"Anne Marie Scheffler didn't think motherhood would be this hard. She thought she could be the sexy showbiz mom, with a baby in one arm, a movie script in the other. Her jarring realization otherwise makes for a humorous and entertaining show. Scheffler is a charismatic, sparkling performer."   - CBC Radio

That's the Concept, This is the Plan...

It's me! Anne Marie Scheffler. Writer/performer of 7 one-woman shows including "Not Getting It" which was turned into a one-hour comedy special for CTV/The Comedy Network. My latest show, Suddenly Mommy, is in rehearsals for a full run at the wonderful Theatre Passe Muraille Mainspace. With a refined script, set, and lighting, I'll be performing December 3-8.

So, this is a passionate, quick, short campaign. I've taken it on as a challenge to launch, produce, and perform this in one month’s time.

Concurrently, I’m touring “Spank!” (a parody of 50 Shades of Grey) across North America, and performing voice gigs and auditions, but my heart and soul is in my personal work. So I’m doing it!  Indiegogo is one of the ways I’m getting the word out, providing you “Tickets with Benefits” – so I can over-deliver -  and ensure this a great run. I guarantee this is going to be a great time! So make a donation/ get a ticket or a bunch and come out and play!

Exactly where the money is going!

THIS IS HOW $8707 BREAKS DOWN:

$4407 - Theatre Passe Muraille's Mainspace rent 
$3000 - for the set/sound/lighting design
$500 - set
$800 - advertising

This campaign isn't just a win-win, it's a win-win-win!

Any contribution of $20 or more gets you a ticket (or tickets) to the show.Or you can chose to donate your tickets to Sistering A Woman's Place, the women's shelter.

LAUGHTER IS THE BEST MEDICINE. YOU'RE HELPING TO HEAL THE WORLD! AND NOW YOU HAVE AN EXCELLENT EXCUSE TO GET OUT OF THE HOUSE AND COME SEE THE SHOW!!!! DRINKS AVAILABLE AT THE THEATRE!!!

You are supporting a hilarious and impactful show that changes the way society looks at mothers. If one parent is empowered by seeing Suddenly Mommy, then a difference is being made.  Plus you are showing kids - yours and mine - when you are passionate about creating art that will serve the world, you go and do it! Plus you can tell your husband you HAVE to go... it's for a good cause! Yours!!! And his!!! And the kids!!! You'll come back a happier mom!!!

If you can't contribute, that's okay! You can give support by sharing this campaign with your friends! Thank you from the bottom of my heart. xoxo AMS

“I was MOVED!! Like I laughed and I cried... you were completely admired and loved and honored. Your vulnerability was palpable. And such heart! It was very moving. THANK YOU for your incredibly inspiring work. And my girlfriend, who is not in the business, but is a mother of two boys, was floored. She completely related, and laughed, and we had a blast together. Thanks.”- David Ludwig


Anne Marie Scheffler

Anne Marie Scheffler is a professional actress, writer, voice
artist and comedian. She has created and toured seven
one-woman shows across North America. Her play Not
Getting It was made into a Comedy Network special for
CTV, for which she was nominated for a Canadian Comedy
Award. Her show Suddenly Mommy! has been mounted in
cities including Los Angeles, New York, and Toronto.
Anne Marie is a Second City Alumna (Toronto’s National
Touring Company), and has a long list of television and film
credits, including She’s So Funny, Adventures In Comedy,
and as a regular cast member on Real Men. She is currently
developing a TV series based on her live shows with
renowned writer Rosie Shuster (SNL).

Anne Marie is also the co-writer and co-star of Spank! The
Fifty Shades of Grey parody, which recently ran in Las Vegas and
is touring US and Canada. An award-winning screenwriter,
she does funny commercials and she’s the voice of Sail The
Outdoor Superstore. You can see her on TV, writing and
performing at comedy clubs and festivals. She’s that funny
blonde girl!

“You were beyond amazing. Every single beat, every moment was captivating, funny, really profound. OMG.” - Joe Bodelai

story:
The Play

I am a junior playwriting student at Ball State University with a passion for storytelling, theatre, and unique ways of expressing the ingenuity and creativity of the human spirit. Several years ago I started writing my first full-length play, which I based on the poem "anyone lived in a pretty how town" by e e cummings. It tells the story of a visionary born into a strictly regulated and oppressive society and his growth into a catalyst for lasting change in the town. The story is old, but the manner in which it is told is totally new--the language is informed by e e cummings' distinctive style of repurposing words and changing the way we think about communication. 

The play has had several readings and revisions, and next semester myself and a group of student directors, stage managers, actors, and designers will come together to mount the first full-scale production the show has had. I am thrilled to have so many talented and dedicated artists working with me to make this happen. But we are, after all, college students, and our disposable income is sadly lacking. So we're reaching out to the larger arts community in the hopes that we can raise enough to support this ambitious undertaking.   

What We Need & What You Get

We're keeping our production budget as frugal as possible, but there are a few essentials that we will need.

  • Printing up posters for both auditions and performances to drum up interest and support in our community
  • Printing up programs
  • Purchasing design elements such as costumes and props
  • Renting a space for our final performance
If you contribute to the project, there are several perks you could enjoy:
  • Your name included in the program as a contributor
  • A handwritten thank-you card 
  • A poster signed by the cast and crew
  • A prop or costume piece from the show 

The Impact

Your contribution will not just be supporting live theatre and new works. You will be helping student directors, stage managers, actors, and designers take advantage of an opportunity to develop their skills and put their training into practice. This is not a project that our school has tasked us with--we are figuring out how to make this production happen on our own. In many ways, this project is a test of the skills we've been developing in the classroom. We are proactively creating our own opportunity, which will aid our development as independent new theatre artists. 

Even if you are unable to contribute monetarily to the project, please consider sharing this page and getting the word out! Thank you!!

story:
Vienna is in chaos. The brothels have been left to flourish, and now the Duke has mysteriously left the city, leaving Angelo, his pious deputy, to clean things up. However, when the virtuous Isabella, comes to plead for the life of her brother, a man Angelo has condemned to death, he must make a choice, between justice and desire.

HT Theatre are bringing one of Shakespeare's 'problem plays' - a complex masterpiece shot through with power, faith and lust as our classical debut to Barons Court Theatre this December

Why do you need money?

There are lots of talented actors who leave drama school and university every year and look for a place to practise their craft - frequently the London fringe. However, it is becoming more and more common for actors to be expected to work long hours with little, or or much more likely, no pay.

And frankly, we hated that

When we set up HT we wanted to provide an opportunity for actors like us to work on a project without financial worries to give a stellar performance that audiences like you deserve. Getting a paid job in the industry would also qualify our performers for Equity membership (the actors union), which provides a host of lovely things such as insurance and support. It is a benchmark for any performer to achieve and something to be immensely proud to be a part of!

We've been very fortunate to have some free rehearsal space donated by Bird College and the University of Greenwich, but it's still a huge challenge to raise enough money to pay a company of ten actors and a production team even minimum wage. Which why we need you lovely folks!

So, the money is going on...

Actor's Wages

Production Team Wages (Lighting, Film Crew etc)

Marketing

Set & Costume

Who are we?

Director - Jaclyn Bradley

Theatre Credits include - The Boudiccae (ICC Birmingham), The Forgotten Millions (EM Forster Theatre, Tonbridge), The Answer to Life, the Universe and Nothing (Hen&Chickens), Othello (London Theatre), The Women of Troy/Mervyn Peake Festival (Both Blue Elephant Theatre), Electra (The Space), Honk! (OFS, Oxford). 
Film credits include - Darren Has A Breakdown (Maws Productions) and Gruesome Tales for Men and Women (Huge Productions) 


The Cast

Angelo - Adam Cunis

Adam trained at Exeter University, where he gained a BA in Drama and an MA in Staging Shakespeare. His theatre credits include Mars inThe Woman in the Moon(The Dolphins Back); Bartus/ Mountsorrell inThe Massacre at Paris(The Dolphins Back); Gratiano in The Merchant of Venice (Lazarus); Horatio in The Spanish Tragedy (Lazarus); Provost in Measure for Measure (Immersion); Jean in Miss Julie (the AKZE Daggy) and David in Rubber Dinghy (LOST Theatre; One Act Play Festival winner 2013). He has also undertaken roles for Shakespeare’s Globe’s Read Not Dead project. His voiceover work includes clients such as Mitsubishi,Red Bull,Gillette,Random House and Just for men

Isabella - Leah Lawry-Johns

Leah trained at the Court Theatre Training Company. Theatre includes Lucienne in An Absolute Turkey, Sarah in The Accrington Palsand Margaret/Antonia in Much Ado About Nothing (N1 Theatre).Emilie in Anatol (Marinoni),Olivia in Twelfth Night (Gap Theatre), Rosie in Arden City, Nick in Success and Eva in Chatroom (Lanfranc) and Rachel in Up On Fordham Hill (Hags Ahoy).

Film includes The Other Side Of Daylight, The Apprentice and The Flight Of Iro And Casper.

Duke - Jonathan Curry

After a varied life that has taken him through music, political activism, performance poetry, art promotion and historical research – living in Cuba, Spain and Britain – Jonathan finally discovered that histrue vocation lay in acting. Having trained at the City Lit Drama School (2-Year ProfessionalActing Diploma), his recent stage appearances includePolonius inHamlet (RSC The Dell), and Tommy in Capture the Flag (Etcetera Theatre

Mariana - Natalie Harper

Natalie trained at Bird College of Dance, Music and Theatre Performance in Acting for 2 years. Her credits include Plastic (Pensive Federation), Richard III (Lazarus Theatre Company), The Answer to Life, the Universe and Nothing (HT Theatre), Orion's Hat (Tristan Bates Theatre) and The Libertine (Greenwich Theatre)

Lucio - Joshua Jewkes

Josh studied Acting at the Bridge Theatre Training Company. Since graduating in 2013, he has worked with various Theatre companies, mainly coveringclassical texts. His previouscredits include Maltravers inEdward II, Brutus inJulius Caesar, Hastings inRichard III, and Lorenzo/Salerino inTrial of the Jew Shylock. This marks the first time Josh will be reprising a character, as he had previously played Lucio during his training in a full length production ofMeasure for Measureperformed at the Cockpit Theatre, London.

Claudio - Rob Fellman

Rob studied Drama at Exeter University, where he specialised in Acting and Dramaturgy and landed his first lead role in Harbinger Theatre Company's production of Macbeth. After forays into the world of Writing and Directing, he found himself inexplicably drawn back to performing, and appeared in many productions including Ayn Rand's The Night of January 16th, Ron Hutchinson's Rat in The Skull, and Dennis Kelly's Love and Money. Upon graduating, Rob co-founded Atlas Theatre Company, and went on to co-create the Vortext Collective, an ongoing experimental performance-text project and think-tank. 

Provost - Carly Jukes

Carly trained at Drama Studio London. Her recent credits include Friar Francis / Grey in Work Bard, Play Bard, (Smooth-Faced Gentlemen, Pleasance Theatre), Lady Cynthia Muldoon in The Real Inspector Hound'’, (The Wonder, Upstairs at the Gatehouse) and Saturninus, Titus Andronicus, Smooth-Faced Gentlemen, (Theatre Royal, York)

Abhorsen - Martin Sales

Martin trained at The Court TheatreTraining Company. Theatre credits include: Lipstick and Scones (Venture Wolf Productions), Nabokov in Lolita (Theatre Collection), Macbeth (Courtyard Productions), Comedy of Errors, A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Julius Caesar (The Principal Theatre Company), The Merchant of Venice (Goodmann Productions), Bosola in The Duchess of Malfi (N1 Theatre Company), Captain in The Love of the Nightingale (N1 Theatre Company), and Hatch in The Sea (Court Theatre Company). Film credits include: Omission (dir. Harry Matthewson). Voiceover work includes Donate Mobile.

Pompey - David Gurney

David graduated from East 15 Acting School in 2012. Stage credits include: Banquo in Macbeth, Bottom in A Midsummer Night’s Dream, Sherlock Holmes in The Sign of Four, Iachimo inCymbeline and Jack in Condemned to Live. Film includes: One Way to Go, Nyctophobia andThe Wrong Goodbye. David has appeared in two TV programmes and several corporate and training videos. He works as a voice-over artist and has lent his voice to multiple productions. He is currently working on an audio book version of The Hound of the Baskervilles by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

Risks & Challenges

As with any theatre production, there are risks involved. But the bottom line is this - we have a very talented and enthusiastic team who will work our hardest to make this show the best we can!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Tell your friends! We love chatting with new people about our work.

Dennis Kelly's Love and Money. Upon
graduating, Rob co-founded Atlas Theatre Company, and went on to co-create the
Vortext Collective, an ongoing experimental performance-text project and
think-tank. 
Provost - Carly Jukes



Carly
trained at Drama Studio London. Her recent credits include Friar Francis / Grey in Work Bard, Play Bard, (Smooth-Faced
Gentlemen, Pleasance Theatre), Lady Cynthia Muldoon in The Real Inspector Hound'’, (The Wonder, Upstairs at the Gatehouse)
and Saturninus, Titus
Andronicus, Smooth-Faced
Gentlemen, (Theatre Royal, York)
Abhorsen - Martin Sales




Martin
trained at The Court TheatreTraining Company. Theatre credits include: Lipstick and Scones (Venture Wolf Productions), Nabokov in Lolita (Theatre Collection), Macbeth (Courtyard Productions), Comedy of Errors, A Midsummer Night’s Dream,
Julius Caesar (The Principal Theatre Company), The Merchant of Venice (Goodmann Productions), Bosola in The Duchess of Malfi (N1 Theatre
Company), Captain in The Love of the
Nightingale (N1 Theatre Company), and Hatch in The Sea (Court Theatre Company). Film credits include: Omission (dir. Harry Matthewson).
Voiceover work includes Donate Mobile.
Pompey - David Gurney


David graduated from East 15 Acting School in 2012. Stage
credits include: Banquo in Macbeth,
Bottom in A Midsummer Night’s Dream,
Sherlock Holmes in The Sign of Four,
Iachimo inCymbeline and
Jack in Condemned to Live. Film
includes: One Way to Go, Nyctophobia andThe Wrong Goodbye. David
has appeared in two TV programmes and several corporate and training videos. He
works as a voice-over artist and has lent his voice to multiple productions. He
is currently working on an audio book version of The Hound of the Baskervilles by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

Risks & Challenges As with any theatre production, there are risks involved. But the bottom line is this - we have a very talented and enthusiastic team who will work our hardest to make this show the best we can!

  Other Ways You Can Help Tell your friends! We love chatting with new people about our work.

story:
Short Summary

Our vision is to initiate and successfully run three brand new shows on Fridays and Saturdays and launch a tourist-focused church on Sunday mornings, at an already established theater in Pigeon Forge Tennessee, called "Tribute Theater".  This is phase one of our master plan, which is to eventually own and operate our own theater/ministry center full time, in our own facility.  The shows we have planned are all faith based, in that they are either entirely Gospel in nature, OR (in the case of our featured show) a clean, safe, family friendly secular show, that will showcase a "ministry moment" where we will give a small yet effective testimony near the end of the show.  In EVERY show, we will invite people to Sunday morning church service.  Our shows are outlined below:

  • FREE MORNING GOSPEL SHOW - With Dustin Jenkins, at 10:30 AM.
  • THE GARY WINNINGHAM SHOW - Also free, and Gospel, at 2:00 PM.
  • SMOKY MOUNTAIN FRONT PORCH VARIETY SHOW - 4:30 & 7:00 PM.

Our feature show will have a price tag of $24.95 per ticket, BUY ONE GET ONE FREE!  At this value, we should easily fill seats up throughout the entire fall.


What We Need & What You Get

We've funded approximately HALF of what we need already, but still have some expenses to cover prior to opening.  Here's a breakdown of what we still need, and the cost of each item.

  • Video Projector and Screen: $500
  • Digital Grand Piano (committed but not yet paid for): $1,200
  • Initial Order of 5,000 Show Brochures: $500
  • Initial "Navigator Magazine" Show Ad: $2,100
  • Show and Church Ad In LOCAL Magazine: $1,200
  • 2 Separate Tourist Outreach Postcards for Church services
    (1000 qty each): $200
  • First Month Of Television Commercials For Shows AND Church, Through Tourist Based Visitor's Channel: $700
  • Prop Building Budget: $1,100

The gift  you give will help us establish a ministry-based journey of church services AND fun family friendly shows, that will touch the lives of countless, and plant seeds that no one could imagine.  People will come to our shows that wouldn't grace the door to a "conventional church".  Thus, we have the opportunity to REACH people that would normally not be reachable.  You can be a VITAL part of that.  But, in addition to the joy of blessing others, We have VARIOUS gifts to bless you back with, if you can and will give to help us reach this very important goal we have - and we have them on several different levels.

  • Gift Of $20 or More:  Four FREE Tickets To Our Feature Show, "The Smoky Mountain Front Porch Variety Show, usable ANYTIME this year.  Just pre-reserve your seats.  That's LESS than half of our already low ticket price.
  • Gift Of $100 Or More (Option One):  Four FREE SEASON PASSES usable for this fall, plus ALL YEAR next year.  That means ANY SHOW we put on, you, along with 3 other people get in completely FREE!  Our normal price PER season pass for one year is set at $100 EACH!  That means you're getting 4 at the price of 1.  Our thank you to you for being our PREMIUM Partner.
  • Gift Of $100 Or More (Option Two):  1 FREE Custom Track, from Dustin Jenkins Nashville, and a locked in price guarantee for as many tracks as you need and can order in the span of 1 year, whether orchestrated or not, for $100 each thereafter.  The money this gift could save you is UN-calculatable.
  • Gift Of $500 Or More:  You're our LIFE LONG PARTNER!  You'll get a 3 LIFETIME Season Passes, for the life of our theater and ministry, getting you in to every show we ever produce for life.  In addition, you'll get a special copy of EVERY recording, video and publicity photo/poster we ever produce for the theater, during the pre release time.  That means you'll get yours BEFORE we put it on the table. 


Please consider helping us do this.  Your gift of ANY amount will help us accomplish the goal of reaching others for Christ.


    The Impact

    6 Years ago, God gave me a vision:  To Reach the WORLD from Pigeon Forge Tennessee.  Our primary purpose?  Ministry and Outreach.  We're establishing a church that will reach untold numbers of people.  People come from ALL OVER THE WORLD, to visit Pigeon Forge.  That gives us an opportunity to be a TRUE international ministry from one location.  Our goals are:

    • To provide affordable, clean FAMILY FRIENDLY entertainment to those who come to pigeon forge on vacation, meeting two needs for families on a practical level.
    • To utilize those shows to sow seeds of faith into those people DURING the shows, and draw people IN to our Sunday morning church services so they might hear the Gospel of Jesus Christ.
    • Ultimately use what God has given us to reach people for Christ, so that the Kingdom Of God might be increased, souls might be saved, and lives changed eternally.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.  Here are a few other things you can do to help us:

      • Volunteer with things we need locally, to help reach the people we're trying to reach.
      • Help Us SPREAD THE WORD!  Share this campaign with all your friends on facebook.  Encourage others to give, and help us get this rolling on time!


      The "What If's"

      We've been asked, "What if we donate and something happens that you CAN NOT open this year, due to falling short of your financial goal, or other issues unavoidable?"

      The answer is this:  We will simply forward the use of those funds given towards NEXT year's opening, which would likely be the end of March 2015.  The simple point is, we ARE going to open this show and ministry!  God has given us the vision and we're going to follow it.  We THINK we know the timing, and have made plans accordingly, however, we all know that things like this are in HIS perfect timing.  Rest assured though, that your funds will be put to good use, and the use that they are meant for.

      We prayerfully hope to have you join us in this journey.  God Bless!

story:
Short Summary

We are a group of young international artists who are passionate about dance, music and filmmaking. In our project, we are combining these artforms to bring them to a broad audience of art lovers as well as people who might not otherwise have access to these artforms. After having created multiple ballets for professional companies around the world, Filipe Portugal is now creating a new choreography specifically for the screen. The ballet will be performed by Emma Antrobus and Luca D’Amato to the piano piece Kaleidoscope by Adriàn Berenguer. Nicole Davidson is the producer and director of this short dance film, which will be filmed by Saro Tschan and Karim Fawaz. Last but not least, Lixel Müller will be doing the sound design for our project. Find out more about what we need and who we are in the sections below!

What We Need 

This is a non-profit project.
To create this film we need 5000.- CHF to cover the following costs:

  • Film location rental (cost: 2000.- CHF)
  • Equipment rental & Transportation (cost: 2000.- CHF)
  • Festival fees (cost: 50.- CHF per submission)
  • IndieGoGo fee

Any extra funds raised will go towards additional festival fees for further promotion of the film.

The Impact

The creation of dance films is an opportunity to make ballet more universally accessible to people that would otherwise not have the means of experiencing the beauty of this artform. The genre of dance for film is especially fascinating because it brings various artists and mediums together. When this project is completed, the film will be submitted to national and international film festivals around the world

Meet Our Team

Producer & Director: Nicole Davidson is a Swiss artist with Italian and American roots. She started acting, singing and dancing when she was four years old. As a member of the Zurich Opera Children’s Choir between 2001 and 2011, her interest and passion for the world of theater and film grew with every production she took part in. With a desire to learn more about filmmaking, Nicole studied film and visual effects at the SAE Institute in Zurich. She received her bachelor's degree in Digital Film Production from the institute in 2019. During her studies, she started exploring the boundaries of her creativity more seriously by devoting herself to various art projects outside of school. Her work is characterized by the merging of different art forms, such as ballet, film and photography.

Choreographer: Filipe Portugal was born in 1978 in Lisbon where he studied ballet at the National Conservatory of Portugal. After finishing his studies he was invited by the director Jorge Salavisa to join the National Ballet of Portugal as a member of the Corps de Ballet. He left the company as a soloist after six years to join the Ballett Zürich under the direction of Heinz Spoerli where he danced for seven years. He left Ballett Zürich as a principal dancer to return to Portugal with the same category but his stay was only for a short period of time. A year and a half later he returned to Zürich where he is still dancing as a principal dancer under the direction of Christian Spuck.

Dancer: Emma Antrobus comes from Australia. She studied at the Lamont Dance Theatre, at the Conlan College in Sydney and at the Ballett Akademie of the Hochschule für Musik und Theater in Munich. She joined the Junior Ballett Zürich in the 2017/18 season and danced in choreographies by Christian Spuck, Edward Clug, Crystal Pite and Ohad Naharin. She is currently a dancer at Ballett Zürich.

Dancer: Luca D’Amato is from Italy and was trained at the Tanz Akademie Zürich. He was the winner of the Spoleto Competition in 2015 and of the Tanzolymp Berlin 2018. He is currently a member of the Junior Ballett Zürich.

 

Directors of Photography: Saro Tschan & Karim Fawaz are the CEOs and founders of Weframe. Their work as filmmakers combines technology and art by creating videos with modern motion control technologies.

 

Sound Designer: Lixel Müller is an audio engineer based in Switzerland. He received his audio engineering degree from the SAE Institute Zurich and has worked on various film and music productions.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please join us for this campaign! No amount is too small to help support this project.

Can't contribute money, but would like to help? 
Please share this campaign with others and help us get the word out!

story:
**Don't forget to check out the Gallery!**

Campaign Purpose:

This campaign will help help our organization with daily costs during this rough economic time. Putting together & preparing for each show is an art in itself. Most props are hand made by our props master, sets painted & built by our Scene Shop Artists, and costumes hand stitched by our awesome Costume Shop Crew.

  • Last month, we spent roughly $190,000 just on expenses & payroll. That doesn't include the cost of royalties paid on show rights.
  • Our Theatre has been a gathering ground for locals and travelers for 10 years. We hold many events, and allow our space to be used for things like Wedding Receptions, Baby Showers, Rotary Meetings..etc
  • Our Gift Shop Staff and Patron Greeters are all volunteers.
  • We offer scholarships to our summer academy program
  • If the goal is not reached, all funds will still go towards Theatre costs to help keep us afloat!
The company is staffed with an amazing & hard working crew; from Servers, Cooks & Bartenders to Marketing, Patron Services, and Production. Some of our staff put in an an average of 13 hours per day! Between show rehearsals to all technical aspects of putting a show together, it can get pretty exciting around here!
Our theatre has hit some rough times lately, as most businesses do.
But being a not-for-profit, we keep our ticket prices & meal prices at a minimum. We do not raise our prices.
We thrive when successfully serving our patrons, knowing that they leave our theatre satisfied & happy.Please spread the word & support the Arts!!
The Story Behind The Arizona Broadway Theatre

When construction began in late fall 2004, ABT's founders – Kiel, Cassandra, Ronald and Penelope Klaphake – expected the theatre to be completed by September 2005. Construction delays, however, caused a slight detour on the theatre's way to settling in at 7701 W. Paradise Lane. We forged ahead and opened our first show, "Anything Goes", in a large pavilion (okay…tent) at the Peoria Sports Complex. Our patrons experienced food prepared in a dugout kitchen, an array of daytime and nighttime temperatures, baseballs landing on the roof, and street sounds at the most inopportune times. (Not to mention one heck of a show!) But, our customers endured (as did our employees) and we finally opened in our new facility on January 3, 2006.

"Anything Goes"

Sellout crowds packed the new theatre for our second show, Brigadoon. At this time, our 3,000-square-foot kitchen wasn't complete, and meals had to be catered in. The best staging area for this activity was our expansive scene shop. Thus, ABT had to purchase or rent sets until the kitchen became fully functional. It wasn't until our fifth production, H.M.S. Pinafore, that the kitchen, scene and costume shops were all up and running as initially planned. (Prior to the building's completion, the costume shop had been located in our costume director's apartment: five sewing machines in the living room and a work table in one of the bedrooms!)

"H.M.S Pinafore"

Despite the obstacles and delays, ABT announced an ambitious second season to the delight of its knowledgeable and loyal patrons, and, during the summer of 2006, kicked off its Academy for Young Performers aiming to enrich the lives of children through the performing arts.

Academy for Young Performers

Season Two opened – on time, and rather ironically – with How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. The Encore Room, a multi-purpose banquet space located off the lobby, was unveiled in November 2006 for holiday parties and special events. ABT initiated its 1st Annual Toys For Tots campaign at its Christmas Tree Lighting and presented a spectacular New Year's Eve Gala to a sold-out audience.

Father time marched on, curtains were raised and lowered, and even greater numbers of audience members responded by becoming season subscribers, recognizing ABT's commitment to excellence (as well as the benefits awarded to subscribers!). The all-time favorite Grease enjoyed an extended-run to sell-out crowds (proving that people do live in the Phoenix area in the summer) and Pump Boys & Dinettes gracefully closed out our second season, which welcomed some 97,000 customers.


The ariZoni Theatre Awards of Excellence announced its nominations, and ABT garnered 24 nominations, a significant feat in its first year of eligibility, and went on to win in seven of 13 categories.

Little Shop of Horrors opened Season Three, showing off some of ABT's advanced stage capabilities by incorporating a trap door and a multi-level set. The holidays were abuzz with activity: tap shoes were flying with Crazy for You; ABT performers shown brightly among the 1.5 million lights of Glendale Glitters; Peoria Unified School District students entertained guests in the lavishly decorated lobby; and the Encore Room took on an added dimension by becoming a venue for Mystery Dinner Theatre and a special Holiday Cabaret.

As 2008 approached, ABT created a new not-for-profit organization--the ABT Performing Arts Association, Inc.--and on January 1st the founders literally and seamlessly turned the keys to the theatrical operation over to the new entity. With a Board of Directors in place, the Association is now responsible for the day-to-day activities of the theatre. This approach allows ABT to apply for grants from foundations and governmental sources, to lower its operating costs and to attract sponsorship and advertising dollars.

Productions of the hit show Fiddler on the Roof, followed by Jekyll & Hyde, Ain't Misbehavin', The Music Man and Nunsense rounded out our third season, and ABT presented its milestone 1,000th performance.

ABT continues to strive to be a different kind of dinner theatre, presenting you – our loyal patrons – with a venue unique to the Northwest Valley.
May the curtain continue to rise.

and went on to win in seven of 13 categories. Little

 stage capabilities by incorporating a trap door and a multi-level set. 
The holidays were abuzz with activity: tap shoes were flying with Crazy 
for You; ABT performers shown brightly among the 1.5 million lights of 
Glendale Glitters; Peoria Unified School District students entertained 
guests in the lavishly decorated lobby; and the Encore Room took on an 
added dimension by becoming a venue for Mystery Dinner Theatre and a 
special Holiday Cabaret. As 2008 approached, ABT created a new 
not-for-profit organization--the ABT Performing Arts Association, 
Inc.--and on January 1st the founders literally and seamlessly turned 
the keys to the theatrical operation over to the new entity. With a 
Board of Directors in place, the Association is now responsible for the 
day-to-day activities of the theatre. This approach allows ABT to apply 
for grants from foundations and governmental sources, to lower its 
operating costs and to attract sponsorship and advertising dollars. Productions
 of the hit show Fiddler on the Roof, followed by Jekyll & Hyde, 
Ain't Misbehavin', The Music Man and Nunsense rounded out our third 
season, and ABT presented its milestone 1,000th performance. ABT
 continues to strive to be a different kind of dinner theatre, 
presenting you – our loyal patrons – with a venue unique to the 
Northwest Valley. May the curtain continue to rise.

story:
Who We Are

UBCimprov has been an Alma Mater Society Club at the University of British Columbia since 1999. Based in Vancouver and possessing a sizable Alumni population, UBCimprov has become a launching pad for young improvisers and the next generation of Canadian comedians. Last year we became the first Canadian team in the College Improv Tournament, going to the Chicago finals with a Wild Card bid. This year they once again broke new ground, becoming the first Canadian team to come in first at a College Improv Tournament Regional, with unanimous first place votes from all five judges.

What You Can Do

With great power comes great responsibilities. Now that we have earned our seat in the Chicago finals, we have to get there. That requires funding for transportation and lodging for our team. Unfortunately passion and talent aren't enough to fly to Chicago. Trust us. We tried. The airlines told us that "dedication isn't acceptable currency." So this is where you come in. Every dollar gets us that much closer to funding this trip and representing our school, city, country, and the Pacific Northwest in Chicago.

The Impact

Vancouver has it's own style of Improvisational Theatre. Like many groups in the Pacific Northwest, we are funny, clever, witty, and good looking. However, we spice the pot up a little bit with something we think is pretty unique to Vancouver improv and UBCimprov: sentimentality. We try to tell meaningful stories with characters the audience loves. Through the guise of improv we explore our own lives, question our own beliefs, share our personal thoughts, and experience journeys that change our lives. By performing on stage we hope to share what we learn with our audiences. By performing in Chicago we hope to spread the love and therapeutic value of Vancouver improv with Improvisers around the continent.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially you can still help us out! Send this campaigns to your friends! You can also email us at UBCimprov@gmail.com if you have any ideas of other ways to contribute!

Thank you.
