story:
SOUNDWAVES: The Passion of Noor Inayat Khan at FringeNYC 2013

 

What is it all about?

Based on a true story, SOUNDWAVES: The Passion of Noor Inayat Khan is a play about a young Sufi woman of Indian descent, a children’s writer, musician and daughter of a great Indian musician and Sufi master, who flees her father’s spiritual center in France in before the Nazi onslaught. This devotee of Gandhi’s non-violence re-emerges as the heroine of the French Resistance known as “Madeleine” – and one of the most highly honored heroes of the struggle against Nazism in France and England – whose only weapons was a radio.

SOUNDWAVES: The Passion of Noor Inayat Khan was presented in October 2012 as a staged reading in “readers theatre” format at the Brecht Forum in New York's West Village.

The international Italian theatre information/review website Teatroteatro.it praised the performance for “[...] mov[ing] between detailed historical description, on the one hand, and the parallels of spiritual and Islamic mysticism on the other,” and concluded that “[...] SOUNWAVES fascinates and enchants the audience with the beauty of its text and the energy of its cast.”

The play is a homage to Noor Inayat Khan and functions as a reminder of the power of Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of non-violent resistance. Noor is a symbol for spiritual and moral values in times of crises, a paradigm for the fight against evil without losing one's integrity.



With your support, we can re-enact the life of this extraordinary woman!

 

Who are the masterminds? 

SOUNDWAVES: The Passion of Noor Inayat is presented by Bridge Theatre Group, an ensemble formed in 2012 to produce international works, or works that seek to explore the potential for building bridges between peoples and cultures, especially in times of stress, war, and conflict. www.bridgetheatregroup.com

 

Meet the creative team!

Joe Martin (author) is an author, playwright and theatre director whose theatre works have appeared on stages in the US, Mexico, Canada, and Europe.  For his work in translation and playwriting he has been recipient of grants from NYSCA, the Rockefeller Foundation, and the DC Commission on the Arts. He has created productions abroad as a three-time Fulbright theatre grant recipient in Eastern Europe and the Middle East.  His plays include The Dust Conspiracy, The Receiver, Anatole’s Lover, El Trato (with Juan Tovar), Rumi’s MATHNAVI, The Match Girl’s SNOW QUEEN, and his translations from Swedish, Norwegian and Spanish include the plays in his collection Strindberg—Other Sides: Seven Plays.  He is currently Senior Lecturer in Theatre at Johns Hopkins University and Fellow in Arts and Peace at the School of International Service in Washington, DC.

Adrian Roman (director)is a New York based director born in Romania. He graduated from Columbia University, School of the Arts with an M.F.A in Theater Directing and from the University of Cluj, Romania, with an M.A. in Performing Arts. He staged numerous plays in Romania at the National Theater, including plays by authors like W. Shakespeare, Yasmina Reza and A. P. Chekhov. In New York he staged The Lesson by Eugene Ionesco (Riverside Theater), He/She by Nanna Mwaluko (Nuyorican Poets Café), The Redevelopment by Vaclav Havel (Columbia University) and Hurt by Saviana Stanescu (Manhattan Repertory Theatre). He was a faculty member of the Academy of Theatre and Film in Cluj, Romania and studied philosophy at Delhi University in India while researching classic forms of Indian Theatre at National School of Drama.

Maitreya Padukone (featured musician)was inspired and initiated in the art of Tabla playing by the late Pandit Nikhil Ghosh. He has accompanied several eminent Indian classical vocalist and instrumentalists in NYC like Steve Gorn, Dr. Rajiv Taranath, Sheila Dhar. He is the co-founder and Executive Board member of the Raga Music Circle of NYC, a non-profit member organization that organizes concerts of visiting eminent artists from India as well as up and coming musicians since 1999. He is a Dental consultant to the Jazz Foundation of America and provides pro bono Dental treatment to struggling Jazz musicians. He maintains a busy Dental practice in NYC. 

Catherine Gasta (movement director) is proud and excited to be a part of Soundwaves. Trained in multiple disciplines; theater, mask, puppetry, dance and mime Ms. Gasta brings dynamic movement to productions; from realism to grotesque. Ms. Gasta was a founding company member of Washington DC's award winning physical theater, Synetic Theater, for eight years. Led by Paata and Irina Tsikurishvili, Synetic Theater's cinematic stage style uses ensemble movement, mime and dance to create one of a kind theatrical experiences. Now in NYC for seven years, Ms. Gasta is working as a mime, choreographer, sketch comedy writer and performer. BA in Theater with a Minor in Dance from Point Park University, National Theater Institute at Eugene O'Neill Center, National Puppetry Conference and Michael Chekhov Conference. 

Leonie Ettinger (production manager/assistant director) is a New York based multi-disciplinary theatrical artist. She has worked on productions in Germany, Israel and the UK including FFT Düsseldorf and The Tricycle Theatre, London. New York City collaborations include: The Civilians, Poetic Theater Productions, LEIMAY, Urban Stages, Residency Unlimited, The Brecht Forum, undergroundzero, Immigrant Artist and Scholars in New York (IASNY), The Private Theater with John Gould Rubin, and La MaMa ETC with Everett Quinton. She recently appeared in Hurt by Saviana Stanescu at Manhattan Repertory Theater and in Here We Are at the Living Theatre under the direction of Judith Malina. She is the Producing Artist of Raised Spirit Theater, an Associate Artist of The Shades of Gray and a member of The Living Theatre ensemble. B.A. Anthropology and Media, Goldsmiths College - University of London; M.F.A.-Equivalent, Stella Adler Studio of Acting. (www.leonieettinger.com)

 

Sarah Weeks (stage manager) is excited to work in Soundwaves. A recent graduate of Fordham University Lincoln Center, she currently works for DRTheatricalManagment. Her recent theater credits include stage management for Regroup Theater's 1931 and Fordham University's Good Person of Szechwan. Recent production assistant credits include Carl Andress Bunnicula, Evan Bergman Love Therapy, and Kevin Del Aguila The Velveteen Rabbit. Gratitude goes to Soundwaves team, Fringe Festival staff, and Rosa Mexicana.  

 

Maxine Mattana (production assistant) recently graduated from Sarah Lawrence College where she studied Theatre and Literature. At Sarah Lawrence she both directed the first act of the play Bachelorette by Leslye Headland, and was granted a staged reading of her own play entitled Drama Queen Soiree. She also acted and performed technical duties in multiple productions. She has worked at 45 Bleeker and The Signature Theater Company, both in New York City, as well as at PW Productions in London. She is thrilled to be involved in this production!  

 

 

The cast includes Soraya Broukhim*, Tony Crane*, Maya Helena de Bresser, Ana Grosse*, Arooj Majid, Anna Marie Sell*, Kesav Wable, Perri Yaniv*. Zenon Zeleniuch*.

 

*these Actors are appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association.

 

 

Support these amazing artists!

 

All of your money goes directly to the performers and the production!

 

With your support we can portray this inspirational story in the quality that it deserves!

 

$ 785 pays for the Fringe participation fee including insurance 

$ 2000 pays our rehearsal space

$ 1600 pays for our set

$ 1200 pays for our costumes

$ 565 for pays for PR (fliers & posters)

$ 3850 pays honoraries à $350 each for 11 AEA cast members (Equity guidelines)

 

$ 10 000 TOTAL

 

 

To express our gratitude, we'll make you part of the French resistance! You can also take a lesson of choice, read as if there was no tomorrow, get your teeth fixed or indulge in authentic Indian cuisine!

CHECK OUT OUR PERKS!

 

What else? Come and see our show!

 

SOUNDWAVES: The Passion of Noor Inayat Khan runs Sunday18 @ 7:45-10:00, Monday 19 @ 4:15-6:30, Thursday 22 @ 2:00-4:15, Friday 23 @ 9:00-11:15, Sunday 25 @ 3:00-5:15 at Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural & Educational Center's Flamboyan Theatre as part of FringeNYC's official selection. 

 

 

Tickets:

$15 in advance sales

$18 at the door

$10 tickets for children under 12/seniors above 65

 

Available online at http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=S#SOUNDW or by calling 866.468.7619 starting July 19.

 

The New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, with more than 200 companies from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues. FringeNYC will celebrate its 17th Anniversary August 9th - 25th, 2013. www.fringenyc.org  

 

Other ways you can help!

 

Already given at the office? Can’t contribute monetarily? Don't despair! You can still play a pivotal role by helping us spread the word! You can forward this link to family, friends, strangers, and enemies. Use the Indiegogo share tools built into this page to share directly through Facebook, Google+, Email and Twitter!

 

Every dollar earned is another dollar going into the hands of a hard-working artist.

 

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR SUPPORTING OUR CAMPAIGN!

story:
Sierra Madre Playhouse, located in Sierra Madre, California, asks for your support to help us mount The Joy Luck Club, a specific and universal story by Susan Kim adapted from the novel by Amy Tan. The story is an intergenerational tapestry of stories of immigrant mothers and their American daughters.

Located in the San Gabriel Valley, the Sierra Madre Playhouse, draws from the rich cultural traditions of local residents.  Over some forty theatrical seasons, experience tells us that audience members' own stories enrich and expand the work on stage.  This is a dialog between actor and audience member that makes theater such an enduring artistic tradition.  We are anxious to offer The Joy Luck Club to the Chinese and Chinese-American residents of our community, in particular, yet equally, every audience member representing other cultural roots to join in its universal wisdom.

We are thrilled that Tim Dang returns to direct THE JOY LUCK CLUB at Sierra Madre Playhouse. Having previously run East West Players, the longest running theater of color in the United States and the largest producer of Asian American artistic work, he continues to share the rich cultural experience of the Chinese in America with the greater community that is vital to his work as a director as well as a long-time activist in cultural equity and inclusion.

What We Need & What You Get

Sierra Madre Playhouse is seeking to raise $15,000 from this campaign that is over and above the average cost of a non-musical production at our intimate theater due to the large cast size of eleven that this production requires. There are also technical elements of this production that make this an expensive undertaking such as:

  • Video projections to convey a cinematic sweep of time and space as we segue from story to story.
  • Period costume designs to portray the dress from 1920s China to 1980s America.
  • A cast size of eleven that will be paid under the 99-seat Actors Equity Plan.

In return for your generosity of a tax-deductible contribution, some of the exciting perks of being able to share these heartwarming stories - some hilarious, some heartbreaking - includes email updates about the production process from the first day of rehearsal through Opening Night, a production program autographed by the cast, an exclusive invitation to a rehearsal, and tickets to a performance of the production. We want to include you as part of the Joy Luck Club Family.

We feel confident that we will reach our goal of $15,000. In fact, we are prepared to expand our goal to include other engagement activities that will help to build bridges with the surrounding communities through post-performance talkbacks, "meet the artists" forums, an informative lobby exhibit about the Chinese in America, and an opportunity for a film series about the Chinese American experience during the run of The Joy Luck Club.

The Impact

Your financial support will contribute to ensuring a top caliber production of The Joy Luck Club with artistic integrity that is the cornerstone of Sierra Madre Playhouse's artistic mission.

Your support will enable Sierra Madre Playhouse to expand our reach to surrounding neighborhoods such as Pasadena, Arcadia, San Marino, and other San Gabriel Valley cities by sharing stories familiar to the Chinese and Chinese American communities.

Your support will entertain, educate, and enlighten all who walk through the doors of the Sierra Madre Playhouse through your participation in cultivating and deepening relationships with our neighbors.

Risks & Challenges

The importance of "art" is that "art" tells a story. Art is all about the story. Through stories (and The Joy Luck Club has many stories), we can start the dialogue between all of us on many issues. The art brings us together to understand different points of view. Sierra Madre Playhouse is taking this step to build our community, our neighborhood, and to build relationships. Our world needs to build community, and what better way than through art.

*The Joy Luck Club may be too specific for me to connect to.

Though The Joy Luck Club is about the relationships between four Chinese immigrant mothers and their four American daughters, there are universal themes that come out of the specificity and authenticity of these stories. The stories are so touching that every adult daughter (and son) who has a deep relationship with their mother can relate to in a multitude of ways. The stories on stage guide the audience member through their own tapestry of life stories. Through The Joy Luck Club, you will experience your own tapestry of life stories.

*There is a lot of TV, film and theater productions competing for my time.

Sierra Madre Playhouse is committed to artistic integrity. Our past productions have been recognized by both theatre reviewers and audience members of the quality of our theatrical offerings. Your time will be well spent experiencing The joy Luck Club at the Sierra Madre Playhouse.

Tim Dang will direct the stage production of The Joy Luck Club. He is the producing artistic director emeritus of East West Players, the longest running theater of color in the United States and the largest creator of Asian American artistic work for the stage, having run the organization for 23 years. An excellent design team has been assembled to support the vision of the play. Tim is a director with great sensitivity bringing his unique talent to the production making it more than a play about the Chinese-Americas experience but a great play with universal appeal about intergenerational family relationships.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please help spread the word to your friends about our fundraising campaign and our production of The Joy Luck Club scheduled to open in late August in Sierra Madre, CA. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo tools!

    And if you want to share your expertise in volunteering to help with the promotion or mounting of this production, please contact us at www.sierramadreplayhouse.org.

    Thank you so much!

In fact, we are prepared to expand our goal to include other engagement activities that will help to build bridges with the surrounding communities through post-performance talkbacks, "meet the artists" forums, an informative lobby exhibit about the Chinese in America, and an opportunity for a film series about the Chinese American experience during the run of The Joy Luck Club.

The Impact
Your financial support will contribute to ensuring a top caliber production of The Joy Luck Club with artistic integrity that is the cornerstone of Sierra Madre Playhouse's artistic mission.
Your support will enable Sierra Madre Playhouse to expand our reach to surrounding neighborhoods such as Pasadena, Arcadia, San Marino, and other San Gabriel Valley cities by sharing stories familiar to the Chinese and Chinese American communities.
Your support will entertain, educate, and enlighten all who walk through the doors of the Sierra Madre Playhouse through your participation in cultivating and deepening relationships with our neighbors.

Risks & Challenges
The importance of "art" is that "art" tells a story. Art is all about the story. Through stories (and The Joy Luck Club has many stories), we can start the dialogue between all of us on many issues. The art brings us together to understand different points of view. Sierra Madre Playhouse is taking this step to build our community, our neighborhood, and to build relationships. Our world needs to build community, and what better way than through art.
*The Joy Luck Club may be too specific for me to connect to.
Though The Joy Luck Club is about the relationships between four Chinese immigrant mothers and their four American daughters, there are universal themes that come out of the specificity and authenticity of these stories. The stories are so touching that every adult daughter (and son) who has a deep relationship with their mother can relate to in a multitude of ways. The stories on stage guide the audience member through their own tapestry of life stories. Through The Joy Luck Club, you will experience your own tapestry of life stories.
*There is a lot of TV, film and theater productions competing for my time.
Sierra Madre Playhouse is committed to artistic integrity. Our past productions have been recognized by both theatre reviewers and audience members of the quality of our theatrical offerings. Your time will be well spent experiencing The joy Luck Club at the Sierra Madre Playhouse.
Tim Dang will direct the stage production of The Joy Luck Club. He is the producing artistic director emeritus of East West Players, the longest running theater of color in the United States and the largest creator of Asian American artistic work for the stage, having run the organization for 23 years. An excellent design team has been assembled to support the vision of the play. Tim is a director with great sensitivity bringing his unique talent to the production making it more than a play about the Chinese-Americas experience but a great play with universal appeal about intergenerational family relationships.


Other Ways You Can Help
Please help spread the word to your friends about our fundraising campaign and our production of The Joy Luck Club scheduled to open in late August in Sierra Madre, CA. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo tools!
And if you want to share your expertise in volunteering to help with the promotion or mounting of this production, please contact us at www.sierramadreplayhouse.org.
Thank you so much!

story:
ALL TRANS VARIETY SHOW

Some of NYC's finest transgender musicians, dancers, comedians, actors, and performance artists share an intimate evening onstage at Under St. Marks July 2, 2015 as part of the Queerly series produced by Horse Trade, a 2015 Obie-winning company.

  • The evening is curated by trans curators, nearly all of the material is written by trans writers, directed by trans directors, and, of course, performed by trans performers. 
  • Agents, Casting Directors, Playwrights, Directors, and Talent Managers have asked to attend to get an idea of who's who in trans performance- an opportunity that will lead to better representation of trans folks in casting.  
  • TIX ON SALE HERE

WE NEED YOUR HELP

So here's what's cool about this fundraiser:

  • Each performer, writer, and member of this show's team have set their own fees (within reason), making our goal $1500. This money will go towards paying the performer's fees, and if we go over, the performers and curator will split the bonus. 
  • Perks? You want perks? We got perks. We got all kinds of perks. We've got even more than are listed on that there sidebar. They're coming soon, tune in to our updates!

THE PERFORMERS

CATIRIANA REYES
BRYN KELLY
TYLER FORD
MAYBE BURKE + EVE LINDLEY
MARS HOBRECKER + LEAH JAMES
LUZ CRUZ
JAYNE HENSON
WINTER LAIKE
TORII PASTERNAK + MORGAN SULLIVAN  (writ/fight chor JESSE GEGUZIS, dir MAYBE BURKE)
JAX JACKSON
AND MORE!

Risks & Challenges

Well, I'm going to pay my performers whether you help me or not. 


NO MONEY NO PROBLEM!

Make some noise about this campaign and the show by sharing this campaign OVER AND OVER AGAIN UNTIL YOUR FRIENDS ALL BLOCK YOU. 

If you have a skill or something to offer as a perk you'd like to donate, contact jax@jaxjackson.com and we'll set it up!
TIX ON SALE HERE!!!

story:
The Emperor's New Clothes

Our old uniform has served us well, but after over five years of daily use on the streets of San Francisco, it is threadbare and worn to tatters. A new uniform must be custom made at a considerable cost and we do not have the necessary funds in the Imperial Treasury to cover the expense. Therefore, we a turning to our loyal subjects for their assistance. 

What We Need & What You Get

A new uniform is custom tailored and costs approximately $1,000. It is authentic to the period and to what we wore in the 1800s. It is a Civil War era Junior Officer's frock coat and is estimated to last for five years of use. 

We are offering unique perks for this campaign, including free tours, private tours, lectures, and will even place your name in the uniform!

story:
The Creation

The Monstress Mess production of 'The Stronger' is a theatre performance which replicates the way the human mind functions on the stage; both through the way the text is structured and through the design elements. A psychological puzzle and an immersive blow-your-mind live experience. 

The story ultimately hinges on the link between perception and reality: how well do we really know the people closest to us? How well do we really know ourselves? Think Groundhog Day for the Berlin elite. The audience are trapped in a time loop with the guests present at the bourgeois Christmas networking benefit at the luxury Charlottenburg apartment of Mr and Mrs X. 

1 Text. 2 Women. 4 Versions. 

Why is Strindberg in a time loop?

The setting for this Monstress Mess production is: Christmas, 2019, Berlin. Strindberg originally wrote the play in 1888. He was writing about, what was a new problem at the time; the way we trap ourselves in a cycle of thought and a pattern of behaviour which we cannot escape from. He was predicting a mental health epidemic at a time when people were moving away from the structure of religion, tradition and more pressing for Strindberg; the rise of the emancipated woman threatening the male dominance of society. 

The story centres around the relationship between married Mrs X and single Miss Y, who once had a very close relationship but something happened causing them to drift apart which they have never spoken about...until the play begins. The inspiration for the time loop came from Strindbergs ideas on cycles of thought and the process before a confrontation that everyone experiences (whether consciously or unconsciously) where you imagine what you might say to this person and how they might react. You also imagine multiple possible reasons for them to act the way that they did. In this production the audience will have front row seats to this process in Mrs X's mind playing out on the stage. We will be observing her stream of consciousness. The avatars of her loved ones and acquaintances will show us the power and the possibilities of the imagination. 

The Details

The Stronger will premiere on May 2 at Brotfabrik in Berlin. We have chosen the venue due to its immersive qualities; it allows us to take our audience on a journey on which we can reveal secrets along the way. 

Director Rebecca Scott has been exploring the possibilities, and pushing the relationship, between theatre and psychology throughout her studies and career. Rebecca was born in Sydney Australia in 1988. She lived and studied as an actress in Sydney (Actors Centre), New York (Lee Strasberg Institute) and London (RADA) before coming to Berlin to study theatre directing. However her most important education was working with renown Australian acting coach Annie Swann. 

Whilst transitioning into directing in Sydney, Rebecca completed directing internships at the Ensemble Theatre, Sydney Theatre Company, Sport for Jove and the John Bell Shakespeare Company. In the last 3 years she was granted directing internships working with Katie Mitchell at the Schaubühne Berlin and the Deutsches Schauspielhaus Hamburg, and with Barrie Kosky at the Komische Oper. She has also worked as an assistant director to Kim Hardwick of White Box Theatre Sydney, Erman Jones of the Berlin English Repertory Theatre and Glen Sheppard in Berlin. In April 2019 she directed a production of Chekhov’s ‘The Proposal’ at Studio 800a Berlin. 

The Collaborators

The Stronger pulls together inspired collaborators from across the globe. 

Producer/Director - Rebecca Scott - Australia

Producer/Actress - Lucie Aron - France

Producer/Actress - Judith Shoemaker - Germany/America/England

Scenographer - Nina Kay - Denmark

Composer/Sound Designer - Snorre Søjønst Henriksen - Norway

Actor - Anton Pohle - Germany

Costume Designer - Nuria Gregori -Spain

Videographer - Zee Marla Osh - Poland

Photographer - Sebastian Matthias Weißbach - Germany

The Challenge

The scale of this project is massive and involves an array of artists, storytelling professionals and technical equipment. The funds for the execution of the project are the primary challenge we are facing at the moment. Contributions we collect will be arranged to cover various parts of the project, as all are interdependent to pull off the production. To be able to pay these professionals and cover our expenses in putting on the show we need at least 10,000 euros.  It is important for us to be able to pay our team what they deserve for their artistic contributions to the project. 

Where is that money going?? Here are just some of the costs. 

- Rehearsal space 

- Costume materials 

- Venue hire

- Artist fees

- Lighting & Sound Equipment Hire Rental

- Set Materials & Labour to built it

- Photography & Videography

We are working insanely hard to develop the first phase of the project as low-cost and budget-friendly as possible. It is very important for us to be able to document our work, with good quality photography and videography, to allow us to apply for other types of funding in the future and so we do not need to rely on only support from our community in the future. 

We have developed amazing perks so that you will not only invest in a great team but you will also get something unique back in return - sponsored by our wonderful and generous community of artists who want to support us.

We also want you to feel as proud to be part of The Stronger as we are.

The Support

We also know that not everyone will have the means to donate. If you are able to share support in other acts of loving kindness, we would super appreciate:

Sharing the campaign link with your friends via email, text, social media - every dollar counts

Talk about The Stronger online - share the visuals (i.e the campaign videos) for promotion

Follow Monstress Mess on Facebook and Instagram for production updates that could be relevant to you - (maybe we even tour The Stronger to your part of the world!)

In any case, your support in whichever form, means the world -- both the physical and virtual 

Yours,

The Monstress Mess Team

story:
Dusk and Melon is an evening length show created by Tara Lynch and Franklin Barefoot. The performance is a retrospective on the presentation of societal roles, human development and relationship dynamics. The work presents the ups, downs, and mismatching middles of progress. Please consider donating to this evening of work and more importantly, attending if you can. We feel, personally, that it is something you won’t want to miss! All donations will go towards renting performance space, paying the talented dancers, lighting, costumes etc. Thanks for your support!

Judson Church : April 3 & 4, 2015

www.duskandmelon.com

Starting artists face many challenges.  We have been fortunate to have coordinated such a great performance venue and beautiful dancers.  Our biggest challenge has been finding the faith to take this step, a first evening length, self produced performance.  We have taken the first step, but cannot do it alone.  We ask you to join us on the journey!

story:
Introduction

Howdy folks, Clint Orr here.  Go ahead and Google me, I'll wait right here...
I'm the founder and executive director of The California Country Dance Foundation. 
This campaign's goal is to raise enough dough to host the largest country dance event in the history of Santa Barbara County at the Earl Warren Exhibition Hall. 
The venue has 22,000 sq. ft. under roof, so capacity is over 2,000.  With 2 bands, 4 DJ's and 6 dance instructor's, it'll be amazing.  I'll book a Wednesday in January if all goes well and I'd love to take every available Wednesday of 2016.
To focus attention on the subject and help fund our nonprofit corporation I wrote a book titled "How To Dance With California Cowgirls".  Proceeds from this book will go to the CCDF 
Our mission is "To cultivate, strengthen and sustain a new found appreciation for, and participation in, couples dance by subsidizing country dance events and lessons".  Additionally, we are here to "create meaningful employment in the art of couples dance" and "establish and maintain accredited dance classes in the California Community College system"
This project represents my first crowd funding effort and my first paper printing- delivered straight to you, signed and guaranteed by yours truly.  I will endeavor to have them delivered for Christmas gifting - how fun!
The eBook is available right now for $2.99 at Amazon.  The eBook graphics are weak, but the words are awesome (in my opinion).  Please buy it and tell your friends to get it too.  Once you've read it, hopefully you'll want the real handbook.  
The actual handbook is more outrageous, more dramatic and more fun to read.
With the help of those that believe as I do, we're gonna "book" this event.  Get it?  I wrote that one all by myself...

Perk Mathematics

What I'd like to attain is $16,995.  The California Country Dance Foundation is not directly involved at this time, there are no tax deductions from perks.  
No wait, go ahead n tell those nice folks at the IRS that you claimed it as a tax deduction to Clint Orr cuz I'm a charity case - see how that works fer ya. Everybody from this paragraph down has to grow a doggone sense a humor.
Overall the perks are priced to come in at or near 60% cost with 40% net to the project.
The $25 Poster and Stickers package will be a break even loss leader that helps to advertise our journey.
Cash donations will hopefully break us even at 50 - 50. 
I'll need about $7,500 for deposits for the big night; the cost of perks and their delivery should match  the $7,500 outlay;  Toss in $1,995 for direct costs such as Indiegogo and I came up with  a $16,995 campaign.
With $7,500 I will book the Earl Warren Big Event below.  If we raise less, we set our sights on a smaller gathering (or incur a little debt and do it anyway).  If we raise more we book more events and give away used trucks or somethin.

The Big Event

We're gonna rent the Earl Warren Show Grounds Exhibition Hall on a Wednesday in January if possible.  Teens are $3 for admission, adults run $5 big ones.  Free parking and Free lessons with admission, stay tuned for more details.
Portions of the event will be taped for a TV/radio pilot and offered to the best bidder (not highest),  Turnout should be strong, door prize entry will be given to those that take lessons.

My Qualifications

ACCOUNTANT   Graduate Long Beach State
AUTHOR              This Book and others comin up
BROKER               California Real Estate - closed over 300 transactions
CLEAN RECORD Bathing habits aside, ain't no dirt on me or my DMV record
COWBOY             Ropin n ridin skills questionable, but I kinda look like one
DANCER              Best in town.  Ask Shawn Parr.  Danced 47 nights in a row
EXECUTIVE         Director and founder of The California Country Dance Foundation
OVER CONFIDENT  Weakness or strength, beyond any doubt, absurdly so
PASSIONATE     I've told a boatload of people to kiss my butt - no kidding!
PRODUCER         Time Warner, Cox and Comcast public access TV
ROCK STAR        Renown for expertise at stacking happy rocks and debris
SALESMAN         That I am, you're reading this
TEACHER             This part is BS. I'm a has been show off in admin now
TV STAR               Move over Huell Howser, Clint Orr's got a California show too 
Future Projects

THE RENDEZVOUS HONKY TONK in the historic Newport Beach Balboa Pavillion (my next crowd funding campaign)

THE AIRPORT HONKY TONK of Santa Barbara (Goleta) 

THE GOLDEN BEAR Dance Hall Theater in Huntington Beach

THE HUNTINGTON BEACH INTERNATIONAL SURFING MUSEUM, HB

story:
With the ALL GIRL PROJECT, the Chicago Mammals are committed to creating unique opportunities for Chicago actresses to play roles that are rarely if ever performed by women. 



Your support will go into our world premiere production of ALL GIRL DRACULA. That support is essential so that we may bring a quality to this project that equals or exceeds our recent projects like ALL GIRL MOBY DICK, ALL GIRL EDGAR ALLAN POE and ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN. Those productions were "monsters" to produce, but with the help of our friends and fans, they came together wonderfully. We hope that you’ll help us once again to continue in that "vein" with ALL GIRL DRACULA ;) 



Since 2010, the Chicago Mammals and the All Girl Project have been dedicated to producing work that give women the choice to pick any role they want from the western canon regardless of whether that role was written as a man of woman.
The result has been productions that embrace, enable, and encourage women to investigate and embody some amazing characters from our literary heritage. Ishmael, Ahab, Queeqeeg, Starbuck, Victor Frankenstein, Frankenstein's Creature, Dracula, Van Helsing, Edgar Allan Poe's perverse Imps and Narrators... these are just the beginning of our aspirations! The women of Chicago's vibrant storefront theater scene have told us that this kind of cultural endeavor is more of the type of theater that they want. We hope you'll help us continue to bring it to Chicago audiences and beyond.


Did you know that the All Girl Project is spreading across the country? All Girl Frankenstein, first produced in Chicago in 2013 will get it's Florida premiere this fall at the Hippodrome Gainesville. Help us to continue to create these opportunities for women in Chicago and Beyond!

Realizing classic literature which uses elaborate elements of sci-fi and fantasy requires lots of resources. We need your help getting the costumes, a new video projector, lighting equipment, additional technical tools and design elements. Also we need your help to keep our Zoo Studios doors open, a safe place to mold and shape this amazing play and share it with our audience. Thank you for helping us realize this goal.
story_txt:
With the ALL GIRL PROJECT, the Chicago Mammals are committed to creating unique opportunities for Chicago actresses to play roles that are rarely if ever performed by women. 





Your support will go into our world premiere production of ALL GIRL DRACULA. That support is essential so that we may bring a quality to this project that equals or exceeds our recent projects like ALL GIRL MOBY DICK, ALL GIRL EDGAR ALLAN POE and ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN. Those productions were "monsters" to produce, but with the help of our friends and fans, they came together wonderfully. story:
So, What's This All About?

Robert Moses' Kin Dance Company has been invited to perform in India for the first time in Company history. Our presence is requested on behalf of Sapphire Creations and performances will be included in the INTERnational Festival of Alternative and Contemporary Expressions (INTERFACE) 2014.  In order to fund this first-ever international tour to India, we are turning to our beloved RMK community to help us cover the costs of traveling nearly the entire globe to showcase Robert Moses's one-of-a-kind approach to contemporary dance and developing this brand new work. 

Photo Credit: RJ Muna

The Nitty Gritty

Robert Moses' Kin's 20th Season is here! In celebration of our two decades of consistently offering compelling, powerful and unique work, RMK is on the cusp of a performance season like no other. Commissions, travel, collaborations, educational partnerships - they are all lined up in what will truly be a season of firsts. Fitting to this theme of firsts is this invitation from Sapphire Dance, Eastern India's only experimental dance company that exudes a ready awareness of contemporary global concerns, to perform at the INTERFACE 2014, a biennially running festival since 2002. The festival is a major event in the cultural calendar of India, covering all artistic disciplines of performing and visual arts. 

We are sending Robert Moses along with 4 Company Dancers. They will travel to 3 different cities along the 12-day tour: New Delhi, Chandigarh, and Calcutta In addition to performing on this multi-city tour, RMK will have opportunities to teach young people who may not otherwise have access to such high-quality instruction from an international, professional choreographer and instructor. Exciting, right? We are honored at the chance because aside from performing, teaching the next generation is one of our favorite things to do!


What We Need & What You Get

To put it simply, we're looking to you, our KIN, to help offset the costs that come with this opportunity. Your support will allow us to purchase plane tickets, adequately compensate dancers for performing after traveling such a great distance, and ultimately put our secured grant funding to use in producing the most innovative and masterful season possible here in SF.


Financial Breakdown

Plane Tickets - $5,500 

Visa Applications - $1,000

Per Diem & Appropriate Dancer Pay - $1,500

Even if we don't reach our $8,000 goal, we will still use whatever costs come in to pay the touring dancers and to offset our season production costs. If we DO reach our goal, the extra funds will go towards dancers - who else, we'd be nowhere without them! - as well as set pieces and other finite TBA costs for the season.


The Impact

There is no other dance company as dedicated to diversity of dancers and to genuinely highlighting both what is unique and universal about the human experience. This word cloud was generated from our 2014 season, RISE. These words represent an array of how people felt walking out of an RMK performance: Your contribution to this opportunity is more than just helping Robert Moses' Kin showcase our work in India. At stake here is also an opportunity to help people be truly moved; to help them experience the powerful feelings that come from watching such beautiful dance.

Finally, we are committed to our KIN! - You, the audience make our seasons possible through your attendance and support. We couldn't be more eager to join forces with you in our mutual appreciation of this work.


Risks & Challenges

We are very grateful to our long-time granting partners for their support, including but not limited to SF Hotel Tax Fund/Grants for the Arts, The Hewlett Foundation, and the Kenneth Rainin Foundation. Although we have these very dedicated funders who are committed to the company's vision, there aren't funds in the bank just waiting to be spent for an opportunity like this. We need community support to make sure we can take advantage of opportunities like this that come our way but still have the bandwith to produce powerful and beautiful dance here in San Francisco. We and are reaching out to the community so that for such a special occasion, we're not reaching into the funds we plan to use to produce our 20th season.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute today, 

1) you have until September 6th... maybe save a few coffees? :), 

and 

2) non-monetary support is always welcome as well. 

  • Please get the word out and make some noise in the social media ethers about the big things RMK is up to! 
  • Feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools to share the campaign most quickly with friends or colleagues.


NOTE: INDIEGOGO TAKES 6% OF OUR FUNDS RAISED. IF YOU'D LIKE TO GIVE AND DON'T NEED A TAX DEDUCTION, INQUIRE AT jhill@robertmoseskin.org or donate on our Network for Good page.

story:
Death Goes on Strike

Around 1943 the composer Viktor Ullman and librettist Peter Kien were prisoners in a Nazi concentration camp where they composed a beautiful and darkly funny allegory about mechanized war where the character of Death, feeling quite put out at the extra work, goes on strike. When the Nazi's found out they shut down rehearsals and eventually sent both men to Auschwitz where they were murdered.

  • Hi, I'm Aaron Vega. I've been creating theatrical pieces since I was old enough to tell stories and I'm excited to create this piece for Denver audiences in such an unexpected locale.
  • The opera DER KAISER VON ATLANTIS is startlingly relevant to our culture today. By making older pieces new again with exciting designs, concepts and comfortable locations, we can renew discussions to issues that still plague our modern society. And, hopefully, find resolutions through humor and imagination.
  • By funding this project through small donations we're able to stay true to our mission of being dedicated to integrity and design and provoking the imagination through socially relevant storytelling.

This is our first project in the Denver area and we are excited to bring this " high-brow bar art" to this exciting arts community.

The Impact

It's easy to find live entertainment, but it's not as easy to find live entertainment that has integrity.

  • It's easy to dismiss opera, theatre or puppetry as non-essential to society. With so many problems plaguing our world why should you throw money at a puppet opera in a bar? The answer is easy. Because good Art makes our society a better place. It's that simple.
  • By funding artists with proven track-records of high-quality performance and design you're contributing to everything that makes Denver fun, funky, and worth living in. Not only is the show entertaining but it stirs conversation, and conversation stirs change and change creates a better society. With top-notch designers, singers, director and puppeteers you'll enjoy this opera, think deeply, and have a drink in your hand. That's something worth supporting.
  • Join us in our adventure to make high-quality Art in accessible locations. It's the future of live theatre and you'll be happy with what we can create together.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the nitty-gritty:

  • While live entertainment can often be quite expensive to produce we're only asking for $7,000. This project is a labor of love and we're dedicated to keeping the focus on the art. These funds will go toward stipends for the artists involved but also toward a compact and flexible lighting and sound system that will allow us to bring pieces like this one to locations where Denver folks want to go anyway.
  • We've got tickets to the show, personalized videos and even specialty cocktails for donors! So jump on in and give what you can.
  • If we don't reach our goal the funds we raise will go into our general fund where we can use them to reach out to more donors in the future to make this project happen. We're tenacious and won't give up.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you don't have a dollar to your name you can still help us by spreading the word for the campaign. We don't have a development department and a full-time staff so we're delegating that fun job to YOU!
  • So click, share, text, repost and help us raise the funds we need to bring this reimagined take on a classic to life!

Best,

Aaron Vega

story:
INK at The Samuel French Festival

It’s not an ordinary tattoo!

Fran, a single-mother is enraged when David, her high-school aged son, decides he’s getting a tattoo.

Inspired by a true global controversy, INK brings the controversy home. The stakes are high; the story, immediate and intensely personal.

Who are you?

I’m R. David Robinson, the playwright and producer. My short play, INK will receive its world premiere at The Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival, selected out of more than 800 submissions from around the world. It’s a prestigious festival. See my festival bio and interview: http://oob.samuelfrench.com/index.php/ink-by-r-david-robinson/

 Tell me more…

INK will be presented on Tuesday July 23rd at 8pm on Theatre Row at The Clurman Theatre in New York City. One performance only! If we're selected as finalists, we'll present again on Saturday July 27th. Six plays will be selected for publication and licensing by Samuel French, Inc. The six winning plays will then be presented in an encore performance on Sunday, July 28th.

 Why do you need this campaign?

I urgently need to raise the essential funds to mount INK, produced independently without support from any educational, arts or not-for-profit institutions. The turn-around from notification to performance was just too brief to get not-for-profit status and I urgently need funds to fulfill professional responsibilities and insure that our company members have what they need to create with pride in an atmosphere of dignity and respect. INK is an Equity Approved Showcase. While your contribution will not be tax deductible, it will be greatly appreciated.

 So what do you need?

We need funds for:

  • Rehearsal Space*
  • Transportation Reimbursements*
  • Company Stipends/Honorariums
  • Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts (VLA) consult
  • You!

If we exceed our goal, your contribution will help us cover:

  • Research field trip to a local museum
  • Tickets for industry friends as a “thank you” to those who’ve been instrumental in INK’s development (the demand for tickets is so great, we do not get standard industry comps)
  • Establish not-for-profit status in order to produce future projects

Who are “We?”

The Company:

Domenica Galati† (Actor: Fran)  Mrs. Frank in “The Diary of Anne Frank” (Chenango River Theatre); Queen Elizabeth from Richard III in “War of the Roses” (HB Ensemble). Film work includes: “Peanut Butter & Jelly” (2013 Tribeca Film Festival selection). She studies with Austin Pendleton.

Dino Petrera (Actor: David)  “Satire Off-Broadway” (Producers’ Club); “Eventually Yours” (Culture Project). Upcoming: “Mirror Mirror” (Tunnel Theatre), “Caihong City” (Shiver Studios). Training: Niagara University (BFA).

Joshua Lombard (Director)  “Bridal Shower” (Fresh Fruit Festival), “Miss Fortune” (short film); “The Recruiter,” (Editor, aired on HBO).

R. David Robinson†(Playwright/Producer)  Playwright: Short works include, “INK,” “Universal Utility Fund” and “Cocooning.” Producer: “Unresolved” (The Open Gate Human Rights Theatre); “The Vanek Plays” (i-589 Theatre); “Broadway for a New America” (Creator). This Fall, R. David will play Big Daddy in “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” directed by Austin Pendleton for Mississippi Mud Productions. See my festival bio and interview: http://oob.samuelfrench.com/index.php/ink-by-r-david-robinson/

How else can I help?

Come see our show! – In the NYC area? See INK at The Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival on Tuesday July 23rd at 8pm on Theatre Row at The Clurman Theatre in New York City. If we’re selected for the finals on Saturday July 27th  or if we win on July 28th, we’ll notify you immediately via email and INK on Facebook. While we’d love to thank contributors with a perk of free tickets, we can’t. The venue is just too small, 99 seats, and we can’t guarantee ticket availability.

I’m nowhere near New York/I’m broke/What else can I do?

Please help us spread the word about this campaign - email your friends, your co-workers and your family! Like INK on Facebook! Help us get the word out so we can reach our goal!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to post about us on all your various social media!

* Actors Equity requirement

† Member: Actors Equity

Thank you for taking the time to learn about INK and our journey to the Samuel French Festival. I’m deeply grateful! — RDR

story:
“High art can be, and indeed should be, entertaining.  The wonder of dancer Ze’eva Cohen…was that she not only accepts this principle, but achieved a flawless balance between intellectual and venal considerations…  It was one of the most immediately appealing and impressive dance debuts San Francisco has seen in years.

There is high art for you…  Cohen is a genius in the field.” 

            --"She Makes You Think of Isadora," San Francisco Chronicle, August 1978


The Subject of the Documentary

The documentary, Ze’eva Cohen: Creating a Life in Dance, describes how it was possible to thrive artistically and even survive economically as an independent artist in the world of dance.

The film encompasses her life as a dance student in pre-independent Israel to her work in the USA: as soloist with Anna Sokolow's Dance Company; her pioneering solo repertory concerts; as dancer and choreographer for her company, Ze'eva Cohen and Dancers; and for some of the twenty-nine national and international companies with whom she worked.  The film also documents her important educational work at Princeton University, whose dance program she founded and directed from 1969 to 2009.

The Beginning of the Project

The collaboration of dancer and choreographer Ze’eva Cohen and film editor and producer Sharon Kaufman, a former senior editor at ABC television, expands on and further develops a film they co-produced for a private showing in the spring of 2010 for a retirement tribute concert celebrating Cohen’s contributions to the dance program at Princeton University.

The two met in 2009, when they were each about to retire from 40 years of work in their respective careers; Ze'eva was hoping to find an editor to help create a short documentary of highlights from her career that began in the 1970's to be shown at her retirement gala. The goal of that project was to communicate to the Princeton University community the breadth of Ze’eva’s career in dance outside of academia.  At the same time, Sharon was exploring creative possibilities after years of editing for ABC's "20/20." Thus, the project was born.

The audience response to the film was overwhelmingly enthusiastic, and it became clear that the 25-minute documentary could become the basis of a legacy project covering Ze’eva Cohen’s fifty years of work, not only as a luminary dancer and choreographer, but also as a pioneer in building a comprehensive dance program in a widely respected university dance program.

To more fully detail and explore her contributions to dance, the documentary will demonstrate how Ze’eva was able to produce highly original work while building a serious dance program in an elite academic environment.

Current Status of the Project

In early 2013, Cohen and Kaufman set out to complete their documentary, which now includes historical highlights of the Princeton dance program and interviews with four unique dance artists who studied under Cohen at Princeton University. Since leaving Princeton, these artists, Jose Mateo '74, David Rousseve '81, Jill Sigman '89 *98, and Mariah Steele '06, have themselves been creating important, challenging, and thought-provoking work with their own dance companies.

Audience for the Documentary

This documentary will illuminate the life of an artist from the 1960s - 2013, and will, by example, influence and inspire future generations of artists in dance, lovers of dance, and those who might choose any independent artistic journey.

Financing of the Project to Date

To date, the costs of producing the original film total $18,900. A $6,500 grant from Princeton University in 2009-10 helped advance the project, and the balance of $12,400 was financed by the Ze’eva Cohen Dance Foundation, a not-for-profit arts organization.

How Your Contribution Will Help

In order to complete the documentary, Ze'eva Cohen: Creating a Life in Dance by early 2014, we will need to raise a minimum of $10,000.

The Ze’eva Cohen Dance Foundation is a registered 501c3.  All donors will receive a tax-deductible receipt from Indiegogo for their contribution to this project.


Biographies Of The Team

Ze’eva Cohen is a dancer and choreographer who retired as Head of Princeton University’s Dance Program, which she founded and directed since 1969. Cohen was born in Israel where she started her dance career.  In 1963, she won a scholarship to study at the Juilliard School in New York, and danced with The Anna Sokolow Dance Company.  Cohen was a founding member of Dance Theater Workshop and in 1971 initiated her Solo Dance Repertory Programs. In 1983 she founded Ze’eva Cohen and Dancers. Cohen has also worked as guest choreographer with many national and international dance companies, including The Boston Ballet, Munich Tanzprojekt, and Batsheva and Inbal Dance Companies of Israel. One of her last creative ventures, started in the mid 1990’s, was Negotiations and Female Mythologies - programs dealing with cultural, political, and social issues, focusing on women’s myths and lives.

Sharon Kaufman made her producing debut with Ze'eva Cohen: Creating a Life in Dance. She has enjoyed a long career as a film and video editor at ABC Television's 20/20, Prime Time, Turning Point, Close-Up, and Dateline NBC.  Sharon edited CBS's athlete profiles for their coverage of the 1992 Winter Olympics in France, and was the supervising film editor for the PBS series Heritage: Civilization and the Jews, as well as editing many other news magazine stories and long-form documentaries. She has been the recipient of numerous awards, including an Emmy and The Polk Award. Sharon is now an independent producer/videographer/editor, focusing on music and dance.
story_txt:
“High art can be, and indeed should be, entertaining.  The wonder of dancer Ze’eva Cohen…was that
she not only accepts this principle, but achieved a flawless balance between
intellectual and venal considerations…  It
was one of the most immediately appealing and impressive dance debuts San
Francisco has seen in years. There is high art for you… 
Cohen is a genius in the field.”             --"She Makes You Think of Isadora," San Francisco Chronicle, August 1978The Subject of the Documentary
The documentary, Ze’eva Cohen: Creating a Life in Dance, 
describes how it was possible to thrive artistically and even survive 
economically as an independent artist in the world of dance.The film encompasses her life as a dance student in pre-independent Israel to her work in the USA: as soloist with Anna Sokolow's Dance Company; her pioneering solo repertory concerts; as dancer and choreographer for her company, Ze'eva Cohen and Dancers; and for some of the twenty-nine national and international companies with whom she worked.  The film also documents her important educational work at Princeton University, whose dance program she founded and directed from 1969 to 2009.
The Beginning of the ProjectThe collaboration of dancer and choreographer Ze’eva Cohen and film editor and producer Sharon Kaufman, a former senior editor at ABC television, expands on and further develops a film they co-produced for a private showing in the spring of 2010 for a retirement tribute concert celebrating Cohen’s contributions to the dance program at Princeton University.The two met in 2009, when they were each about to retire from 40 years of work in their respective careers; Ze'eva was hoping to find an editor to help create a short documentary of highlights from her career that began in the 1970's to be shown at her retirement gala. The goal of that project was to communicate to the Princeton University community the breadth of Ze’eva’s career in dance outside of academia.  At the same time, Sharon was exploring creative possibilities after years of editing for ABC's "20/20." Thus, the project was born.The audience response to the film was overwhelmingly enthusiastic, and it became clear that the 25-minute documentary could become the basis of a legacy project covering Ze’eva Cohen’s fifty years of work, not only as a luminary dancer and choreographer, but also as a pioneer in building a comprehensive dance program in a widely respected university dance program.To more fully detail and explore her contributions to dance, the documentary will demonstrate how Ze’eva was able to produce highly original work while building a serious dance program in an elite academic environment.

Current Status of the Project
In early 2013, Cohen and Kaufman set out to complete their documentary, which now includes historical highlights of the Princeton dance program and interviews with four unique dance artists who studied under Cohen at Princeton University. Since leaving Princeton, these artists, Jose Mateo '74, David Rousseve '81, Jill Sigman '89 *98, and Mariah Steele '06, have themselves been creating important, challenging, and thought-provoking work with their own dance companies.
Audience for the DocumentaryThis documentary will illuminate the life of an artist from the 1960s - 2013, and will, by example, influence and inspire future generations of artists in dance, lovers of dance, and those who might choose any independent artistic journey.

Financing of the Project to Date
To date, the costs of producing the original film total $18,900. A $6,500 grant from Princeton University in 2009-10 helped advance the project, and the balance of $12,400 was financed by the Ze’eva Cohen Dance Foundation, a not-for-profit arts organization.

How Your Contribution Will Help

In order to complete the documentary, Ze'eva Cohen: Creating a Life in Dance by early 2014, we will need to raise a minimum of $10,000.The Ze’eva Cohen Dance Foundation is a registered
501c3.  All donors will receive a tax-deductible receipt
from Indiegogo for their contribution to this project.
Biographies Of The Team
Ze’eva Cohen is a dancer and choreographer who retired as Head of Princeton University’s Dance Program, which she founded and directed since 1969. Cohen was born in Israel where she started her dance career.  In 1963, she won a scholarship to study at the Juilliard School in New York, and danced with The Anna Sokolow Dance Company.  Cohen was a founding member of Dance Theater Workshop and in 1971 initiated her Solo Dance Repertory Programs. In 1983 she founded Ze’eva Cohen and Dancers. Cohen has also worked as guest choreographer with many national and international dance companies, including The Boston Ballet, Munich Tanzprojekt, and Batsheva and Inbal Dance Companies of Israel. One of her last creative ventures, started in the mid 1990’s, was Negotiations and Female Mythologies - programs dealing with cultural, political, and social issues, focusing on women’s myths and lives.
Sharon Kaufman made her producing debut with Ze'eva Cohen: Creating a Life in Dance. She has enjoyed a long career as a film and video editor at ABC Television's 20/20, Prime Time, Turning Point, Close-Up, and Dateline NBC.  Sharon edited CBS's athlete profiles for their coverage of the 1992 Winter Olympics in France, and was the supervising film editor for the PBS series Heritage: Civilization and the Jews, as well as editing many other news magazine stories and long-form documentaries. She has been the recipient of numerous awards, including an Emmy and The Polk Award. Sharon is now an independent producer/videographer/editor, focusing on music and dance.

story:
Short Summary

This August Beyond the Mountain will be taking its first ever trip to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival with not 1 but 2 shows.

1. From Montreal will be bringing Paul Van Dyck's Paradise Lost an a multi-media adaption of John Milton's epic poem of the same name.

2. From San Francisco we will be bringing Christian Cagigal's Obscura a storytelling close up magic show 

For this to happen we need your help! For even the smallest amount can make the biggest difference to us


What We Need & What You Get

We need at least £7500. This money will go towards:

  • The Venue fees
  • The Festival fees
  • Equipment rental in Edinburgh

Our perks:

  • Donate £10 receive a Thank you on our Facebook & twitter and promote any show you wish

  • Donate £20 recieve 2 comps for a either Paradise Lost or Obscura

  • Donate £30 receive Official Paradise Lost/Obscura 2014 T-shirt

  • Donate £100 and receive one of each perk

  • Donate £500 or more and receive be listed as an Executive producer on all posters/postcards, a Thank you postcard of the show sent from Edinburgh signed by the cast  and one of each perk.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to post about our campaign

story:
Hearts of Men (HOM), is a two week dance and movement workshop held on the campus of Montclair State University and will offer classes in movement, improvisation, storytelling/sharing, repertory, culminating in performances on September 6 & 7.  This workshop is for men of all ages (high school through 80!) and the only criteria is the love for movement and at no cost to all participants!

WHY FREE?

Hearts of Men recognizes that many men, including male dancers, have few opportunities to collaborate and share their artistic expression with one another. This workshop creates a unique community which will allow for the experience of movement, collaboration and creation for men of all ages.

 Fredrick Earl Mosley, Founder and Director of Hearts of Men, says, “It is most important for me to make sure that the cost of tuition and transportation does not prevent anyone from participating in this transformational workshop.”

IMPACT/COMMUNITY

Mr. Mosley believes strongly in mentoring young dancers and helping them decide what it is they wish to do with their lives, whether it involves dance as a professional career or a stepping stone to head in a positive direction. “I think dance is one of the best ways to help young minds and hearts find their way in the world."

The goal of HOM is to broaden the learning process far beyond the performance aspect. HOM wishes to help these men grow in different ways as they learn from a variety of artists and teachers currently in different genres of dance.

The HOM workshop allows the men involved to share male-male relationships without hesitation, question or judgment.

Hearts of Men creates a community in which everyone is welcomed in the process with an appreciation that each age has its own value and wisdom and that spirit is the foundation and essence of the Hearts of Men project.

Ways You Can Help

 Your donation will help to cover all production costs which include: salaries for teachers, choreographers, crew, lighting designers, sound designers, costuming, mailings, programs and transportation costs so dancers living outside of NJ can afford to get back and forth to campus. It will also help to ensure that each participant be provided with lunch if they are unable to purchase it on their own.

In return we have fun perks to say THANK YOU from the bottom of our Hearts! Please review all of the perks on our campaign page!

 If you cannot donate at this time you can still help! This is not a secret! Share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter and through email with your Family and Friends!

CREATE HISTORY WITH US

Share in launching the first all-male summer dance intensive! This event will be documented as a groundbreaking and innovative experience. Help us to ensure that Hearts of Men 2014 is a success!  Be a part of it!

Hearts of Men is sponsored by Diversity of Dance Inc, a not-for-profit arts organization. Contributions to Hearts of Men are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Hearts of Men

August 23-September 7, 2014

Montclair State University

For more information contact:

Steffen Coleman at steffenemia@gmail.com

or Lori Katterhenry at katterhenrl@mail.montclair.edu

story:
Tea Set is going to Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2015 from 5th August to 23rd August, and 29th/30th/31st August 2015 @2pm each performance day.

'That incident left me cored. No other word describes it. Whatever was left of my essence, gist, kernel, life force, self was gouged out by that boy.'

Christmas, 1999. On the verge of the new millennium, a young woman becomes the caretaker of Mrs. A., an elderly woman who is forgotten and isolated from her family. As New Year's approaches, she makes an unlikely connection with her elderly charge and discovers the secret of her recent trauma, a secret that leaves both of them shaken in the wake of such unthinkable violence.


A compassionate play about loneliness, life quality and women at the edges of society...a compelling, absorbing and poetic story that captures what it is to be lonely and misplaced and the devastating choices this can lead us to.

Tea Set is written by award winning playwright and actress Gina Moxley ("How to Keep an Alien", EDFringe 2015 and "Lippy", EDFringe 2014, Fringe First award). Actress and co-producer Amy Molloy has teamed up with long time friend and director, Sharon Willems, of Kibo Productions to deliver this terrific one woman piece that succinctly explores what it is to feel a burden to those you love or even society (no matter your age).

After suffering a personal loss on Christmas Eve, Amy turned to Gina and her writing and 'Tea set' immediately struck a chord, in many ways. As a company, we feel passionately about honouring Human Rights and giving a voice and a platform to those who need it most, through stories that inspire, challenge and open important dialogues- 'Tea set' aptly fits the ethos of our young company for all these reasons.

Exploring an intergenerational issue pertinent to an increasingly older population 'Tea Set'  touches upon topics of just how important improving quality of life, confidence, self esteem and independence is, to us all. It is also unafraid to ask difficult questions about the right to die with dignity, and if that is really the best solution or just another dangerous path to abuse.

Tea Set's premiere in London's White Bear and Barons Court Theatre in winter 2014 received warm discussion by a diverse range of audience. The audience response to the topics in the play were strong and passionate and an encouraging visit from Pleasance theatre's director, Anthony Alderson, spurred the company on to an Edinburgh Fringe run. 

We feel it is an ideal show for a diverse and dynamic festival such as Edinburgh Fringe and we hope to raise awareness amongst the Fringe audience about the deadliness of isolation, loneliness and the disregard for, not just our elderly population, but anyone who suffers in silence with depression and no one to turn to.  We also hope to, in conjunction with elderly charities, help make people aware of the urgent need to reduce the level of abuse and attacks on the elderly, (particularly violent and often sexual assaults) and ensure victims have better access to appropriate support. 



Tackling often unspoken social issues on how we perceive old age and mental health. Where do the isolated "fit " in a society that often disregards and feels uncomfortable, when faced with imperfection and suffering?

The inspiration to produce and perform 'Teaset' began after a personal loss and a strong feeling that our elderly generation desperately need treated with more respect, equality and dignity. 'Tea set' became the perfect vehicle and voice to express the importance of these topics and open up a dialogue about them. 

“I related to the piece totally yet it was still mysterious and playful. I lost my paternal Grandmother on Christmas Eve last year. She was like another Mum to me and, I felt, was largely ignored and marginalised by her doctors as her illness progressed. Much like Mrs. A, she was increasingly overlooked by the world around her. l feel very strongly about improving care of the elderly and achieving better approaches to dealing with depression and mental health. As a society we tend to value youth and perfection above all else these days and it has some terrible consequences.” 

                                                                                   —— actress Amy Molloy

“Tea Set is a deeply unsettling play about our forgotten elderly living in fear and isolation and the effects this neglect can have on our future generations.” 

                                                                                   ——artistic director Sharon Willems.


Press Response

"Truthful company tackling big ideas. Terrific performance, furious, distraught, tautly watchful."

"A play almost entirely about women, on the edges of society, out of place, unwanted, or who want to withdraw"

                                                                    —— Lissy Lovett, The F Word


"A Tour de Force performance." 

                                                                    —— MICHAEL DAVIS, FEMALEARTS.COM


"Engaging, moving, harrowing...Brilliantly acted and fluently expressed. Packs a punch."

"A timely reminder that there are people in our society experiencing isolation and loneliness...compelling story"

                                                                      —— GINGERHIBISCUS.COM





Creatives

Kibo Productions are an emerging theatre and film production company passionate about bringing vibrant texts to the masses. Our previous productions include Love, Hate, and Human Rights, a week of new plays protesting the persecution of the LGBT community in Russia which received the support of LGBT advocates Peter Tatchell and Stephen Fry (2013, Barons Court Theatre) and Birthday by award- winning NYC writer Crystal Skillman, which was subsequently published by Samuel French (Waterloo East Theatre/Camden Fringe 2012). 


The cast, creative and production team includes: 

Playwright by Gina Moxley

Producers Kibo Productions and Amy Molloy

Director Sharon Willems

Leading Actress Amy Molloy

Original Music by Mari Sainio

Costume Design by Natalie Lewis

Lighting Design/Technician by Leonard Bacica

Marketing by Xinyi Shen and Sophia Booker 

and Poster Design by Bern Campbell.



Why Do We Need Your Help

The Pleasance venue has granted us a good deal with box office split, but nevertheless, we need to raise at least £3000 to cover costs of productions and all edfringe logistics including registering fee for the festival, venue deposit, travel and accommodation cost,  on-site technicians and necessary spendings for marketing and press. Your help is greatly appreciated to support our journey to Edfringe 2015! 


Other ways you can help

There are various ways that you can help other than donations, the first one would be come to see our performance in Edinburgh! 

Please also spread the word to your family and friends, and send them our campaign page to let more people know about us. AND please start to care more about the elderly around you:)
