story:
I'm Jack Phillips and I'm raising money for my show.

I'm the creator of Taking Care of Mom- The Musical  and I'm requesting contributions to help fund its premier. It's a tragicomedy- a sad story told in a funny way. The central character, Mom, is a composite of several members of my family: my mother, who was a science teacher; my grandmother, who had dementia and my step-father who contracted ALS and joined the Hemlock Society.  Among other things, the story deals with end-of-life decision making. 

Mom and Dad are retired- living at home with Natalie, their great-niece. Mom has been dealing with a serious health issue and has decided how she wants to handle it. Her plan creates a rift in the family that challenges everyone’s moral thinking. Mom’s “to do” list includes a final conversation with her son, Ted, who’s been away. As the show begins, Ted receives an urgent message: “Son- come home- my time is running out.”

It's pretty much inevitable that I will lose money on this production and that's fine. I need to keep the losses manageable. I have a great production team- a director, music director, stage manager, sound designer/recordist as well as an inspired cast of two women and two men and four gifted musicians. The money will end up with them (and also for production expenses, like rehearsal space, publicity and festival fees).  

I'm retired. For the last few years I've been learning to be an artist. I went back to college at UMKC to study playwriting and music composition. Everything I've learned I've put into this show and I'm doing all I can to make it successful and to learn from its shortcomings. After the Fringe Festival I will see if I can find a theatre company interested in producing it.     

  • Your contribution large or small will make a difference to the collaborative art that is musical theatre, to our production team, our audience and people everywhere facing difficult end-of-life decisions.

My fundraising goal is $2,500 

  * The plan is that actors will be paid from ticket sales. 

  * $1500 is budgeted for music director, musicians, equipment and recording,  

  * $1,000 is budgeted for director, stage manager, AV tech and rehearsal space. 

  * Fees and publicity will be about $850 but I'm not expecting to break even. 

 If by some chance I come out ahead, I will use the surplus to market the show.  

 Your unique perks will include programs autographed by the cast and crew. 

This is my fifth Fringe Show and by far the best.

   This will be my third original musical in the Kansas City Fringe-  The US & THEM Reunion (2010) and Cultural Confrontation (2012). I've also produced two original plays: Breeding Stock (2012)  and Future Perfect (2013).   

  • Taking Care of Mom is by far my best work. It has poignancy and humor and deserves to be seen. It delivers a valuable reminder about end-of-life planning.  
  • My previous shows have been successful. this one will be the best by far.  
  • Come see the show if you can. I want to get you an autographed program.

Risks & Challenges

My hope is to produce the show successfully without going too far in the hole.

  • I want to make a CD recording of the score.
  • I want to submit the show to Theatre Resources Unlimited and to other theatre companies. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still help:

  • You could help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Share our event page on FB  
https://www.facebook.com/events/646166768817705/
story_txt:
I'm Jack Phillips and I'm raising money for my show. I'm the creator of Taking Care of Mom- The Musical  and I'm requesting contributions to help fund its premier. It's a tragicomedy- a sad story told in a funny way. The central character, Mom, is a composite of several members of my family: my mother, who was a science teacher; my grandmother, who had dementia and my step-father who contracted ALS and joined the Hemlock Society.  Among other things, the story deals with end-of-life decision making. 
Mom and Dad are retired- living at home with Natalie, their great-niece.
Mom has been dealing with a serious health issue and has decided how she wants
to handle it. Her plan creates a rift in the family that challenges everyone’s
moral thinking. Mom’s “to do” list includes a final conversation with her son,
Ted, who’s been away. As the show begins, Ted receives an
urgent message: “Son- come home- my time is running out.”
It's pretty much inevitable that I will lose money on this production and that's fine. I need to keep the losses manageable. I have a great production team- a director, music director, stage manager, sound designer/recordist as well as an inspired cast of two women and two men and four gifted musicians. The money will end up with them (and also for production expenses, like rehearsal space, publicity and festival fees).  
I'm retired. For the last few years I've been learning to be an artist. I went back to college at UMKC to study playwriting and music composition. Everything I've learned I've put into this show and I'm doing all I can to make it successful and to learn from its shortcomings. After the Fringe Festival I will see if I can find a theatre company interested in producing it.     
 Your contribution large or small will make a difference to the collaborative art that is musical theatre, to our production team, our audience and people everywhere facing difficult end-of-life decisions.
   My fundraising goal is $2,500    * The plan is that actors will be paid from ticket sales. 
  * $1500 is budgeted for music director, musicians, equipment and recording,  
  * $1,000 is budgeted for director, stage manager, AV tech and rehearsal space. 
  * Fees and publicity will be about $850 but I'm not expecting to break even. 
 If by some chance I come out ahead, I will use the surplus to market the show.  
 Your unique perks will include programs autographed by the cast and crew.    This is my fifth Fringe Show and by far the best.    This will be my third original musical in the Kansas City Fringe-  The US & THEM Reunion (2010) and Cultural Confrontation (2012). I've also produced two original plays: Breeding Stock (2012)  and Future Perfect (2013).     Taking Care of Mom is by far my best work. It has poignancy and humor and deserves to be seen. It delivers a valuable reminder about end-of-life planning.   My previous shows have been successful. this one will be the best by far.   Come see the show if you can. I want to get you an autographed program.    Risks & Challenges My hope is to produce the show successfully without going too far in the hole.  I want to make a CD recording of the score. I want to submit the show to Theatre Resources Unlimited and to other theatre companies.     Other Ways You Can Help Even if you can't contribute, you can still help:  You could help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Share our event page on FB  

https://www.facebook.com/events/646166768817705/

story:
Who What When Where Why?

A new drama by emerging Kansas playwright, Lisa Sillaway, is set for it’s debut in London this August.  The dark drama, titled “blank.” is scheduled for it’s first public reading at the Hen and Chickens Theatre in Highbury.  The reading is scheduled for 5:30 p.m., August 12 at the theatre and pub on Saint Paul’s Road. The early time slot allows us to potentially attract theatre-goers for the evening show and also allow for theatre professionals in London who are already immersed in their own productions to attend.

Producers from several venues known for their work with new playwrights, as well as actors and other playwrights have already been invited to the reading. 

www.thehenandchickenstheatrebar.co.uk
lisasillaway.wordpress.com
guineapiglab.com

What we need. What you get.

What do we need? Money. Yes. I'm funding this on my own. It's an amazing opportunity for me as a new playwright. I need help. Funds raised will go toward:

  • Any services provided by the theatre for  me or my cast.
  • Food to feed my ALL VOLUNTEER CAST AND CREW.
  • $100 donors receive a tee shirt designed for the cast.
  • Help defray the cost of my airline ticket and that of my daughter, who is serving as my only crew/assistant from the States.

    The Impact You Will Make Is Statewide

    Playwrights outside of major cities suffer from lack of exposure and difficulty of production. That makes this huge. Enormous. Help?

    • I have made strides on my own in Wichita to help other local playwrights by founding the Guinea Pig Lab Theatre, which focuses on Kansas playwrights.
    • I also volunteer at the Wichita Community Theatre in their Readers' Theatre program, which I first volunteered for in 1991. We're committed to Wichita playwrights.
    • My experiences in London, therefore, will not only help me - but potentially dozens of local and state playwrights.


Other Ways You Can Help

I've been laid off myself, so I understand if you clicked here and can't help. Thank you for giving me the respect and my work the honor of thinking it worthy of that click! If you'd still like to help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign for donations.
  • Know folks in London? Spread the word there so we have a full house!
  • Drop me a note on FB or Twitter and I can get you a pdf of the poster or info to share!


Synopsis of the play

After a violent family tragedy, in which their mentally-ill mother took the life of their little sister; three children are placed in the home of their loving, patient and elderly Great-Aunt Eveline in North London. Charlie, a sensitive and mature teen, is Eveline’s ally and a voice of calm in the chaos created by her older sister, Penelope. She, on the other hand, is the instigator of chaos and mayhem in the formerly-childless Eveline’s life. Suffering from mental illness and traumatized by the death of her sister, she is at once angry, needy, rebellious, mean, and confused but also loving toward her boyfriend, Jamie. William, better known as Whizzer, is the youngest and most sensitive of the trio, tormented by Penelope and a bit of a bed-wetter. In the course of one tumultuous evening, Penelope and the rest try to work through some of their demons and wrestle with mental illness, the lingering trauma from their sister’s murder and the concept of mortality.

story:
WE WANT TO BEAT THE SHIT OUT OF RACISM - JOIN US!

**A huge thanks to all our donors so far! You're amazing.  And thanks to all those who came down to see us at 59E59 theaters! **

THE SHOW

Does America only dream in black and white? Celebrated Huffington Post and NY Magazine comedian Desiree Burch presents TAR BABY—a comedic solo show about “post-racial” America. Speaking to a growing majority of minority experiences in America, TAR BABY effortlessly weaves games, audience participation, laughter and insight in an interactive carnival of Race & Capitalism—where no one's a winner, but everyone's still playing!

Our setting is an all-American old time carnival that has managed to continue touring way past its prime. Our leader, is the funny and lovable Desiree Burch. As she takes us through an audience-participatory experience, each of the carnival’s sideshows represents a story from her own experience of race in America. There’ll be games to play! Cotton Candy! Singing and Dancing! White Liberal Guilt! Using comedic metaphor and gripping personal narrative, Desiree captivates and engages her audience while exploring some of racism’s most damaging effects on the individual and society. What she ultimately offers is a deeper understanding of what’s at play in the conversation about race, so that viewers can engage in explorations and discussions that are more empathetic, informed and productive.  

After seasons in New York, New Orleans and the Bay Area, we want to take TAR BABY to International audiences—and we need your help!


WHAT WE’RE DOING

This is urgent and important to us. We want to share TAR BABY with an even wider audience and be part of an international conversation about race relations. So we’re heading to the 2015 Edinburgh Fringe! The Edinburgh International Festival Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world, presenting new and exciting work from a variety of international artists. 

But is the International Fringe audience ready to have that frank, funny, interactive and possibly traumatising conversation about race we've been (talking about) having since Obama got elected? We'll find out this August!


WHAT WE NEED?

Our initial funding goal is $8000. The funds we raise will go towards our travel, accommodation and production expenses, getting our whole team to Edinburgh, putting us up and buying materials for the show. Once we reach our initial funding goal, any additional funds will allow us to pay everyone for their time and energy. 


THE TEAM


HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

As well as donating you can help us by giving us a shout out on Twitter, Instagram or Facebook.

Share our campaign with your friends. Talk about TAR BABY endlessly. And come to our shows!

JULY 11-12 at 59E59, New York City and

AUGUST 5-31 at the Gilded Balloon, Edinburgh

story:
Who Am I? What is This?!

Hello my name is Kevin McAuliffe and this is my first stand-up comedy one man show! I was born in Baltimore, Maryland, and I grew up in Missoula, MT. I recently graduated with a BFA  in acting from the Theatre Conservatory at the Chicago College of Performing Arts. From a very young age I loved comedy, especially stand-up, but I was really nervous about doing it in high school and I also did not have the opportunity to do so. Then in college I decided to give it a try. The first time I did the standing up and the comedy thing was during my sophomore year for a project for my class called, "The Story of My Voice." I did nine minutes, which is a lot for a first time, and it went well. Two years later, I got cast in a performance art show at my school and I did stand-up for it. That time I wrote 12 minutes and the performance ended up being 19 (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_uK7owgp_c). That was my second time doing stand-up. After that performance, I wanted to do more work like that. Since graduating, I have been doing open mics in Chicago.

The show is called "Hello, My Name is Kevin," where I tell stories about my life, and why I am the way I am. The reason why this show is different from other one man shows is because it's told from my weird point of view towards life. Also, two great performers will open the show, Nick Druzbanski and Tanner Munson, and will set an awesome tone for the evening.  Plus, it has verbal sound effects!

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $800 and I can't reach reach is with out your help. Your contribution will help with:

  • Rental of the space at Studio BE
  • Advertising
  • Print Posters and Flyers

Other Ways You Can Help

Now I know that everyone can't give money, but there is still a way for you to help. If you like the videos posted on this campaign and dig what I'm trying to do PLEASE SHARE THIS LINK!! Also, if you happen to be a Facebook friend of mine PLEASE SHARE THIS ON LINK ON YOUR WALL SO YOUR FRIENDS CAN SEE WHAT I'M DOING!! 

Thank you so much!

story:
Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez
This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece  
 
Short Summary
To celebrate renowned Puerto Rican choreographer and dancer Viveca Vázquez’ 30-year career, the Puerto Rico Museum of Contemporary Art (MAC) has organized a retrospective exhibition about her work entitled A Choreography of Error: Viveca Vázquez’ CONDUCT.  The exhibition, which opened to the public last April, has been curated by scholar Nelson Rivera and includes video and documentary material. A rich education program has been designed integrating forums, artistic workshops, and,–as part of the MAC Live Workshop Program– performances of some of Vázquez’ pieces. The exhibition project opened to the public with a performance that merged a selection of some twelve choreographic excerpts, original costumes, and video art material directed by Viveca Vázquez, in which she also performed with ten other dancers who have collaborated with her in the past. Amongst these is José Pepe Álvarez, her co-director for this repertory, who has been immersed in Vázquez’ work for the past ten years as student, dancer, and now colleague.
*This interdisciplinary project is now open to the public and will run through September 22, 2013.
For the project finale, Viveca Vázquez invited José Pepe Álvarez to direct the closing events, which include a forum and a closing performance that he has titled ¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece¨ (¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨).  
José Pepe Álvarez is re-visiting her conceptual and aesthetic propositions by using archive material, such as performance recordings, interviews and articles about her work, to reformulate those experimental art principles. He is highlighting her movement invention and its relation to language, which Vázquez has endowed with urban Caribbean as well as with race, gender and queer attributes in the context of Puerto Rico’s sociopolitical situation. 
 
Resumen del proyecto
En celebración de los treinta años de carrera de la renombrada bailarina y coreógrafa puertorriqueña Viveca Vázquez, el Museo de Arte Contemporáneo de Puerto Rico (MAC) ha organizado la exhibición retrospectiva: Coreografía del error: CONDUCTA de Viveca Vázquez. La exhibición, abierta al público el pasado mes de abril, ha sido curada por el estudioso Nelson Rivera e incluye material fílmico y documental. Un variado programa educativo ha sido diseñado para el proyecto, incluyendo foros, talleres artísticos y –como parte del programa de Taller Vivo del MAC– performances de algunas coreografías de Viveca Vázquez. CONDUCTA abrió al público con una presentación que recogía doce fragmentos de una selección de piezas coreográficas que junto con vestuarios originales y piezas de video arte, fue dirigida por Viveca Vázquez quien también participó como bailarina junto a su co-director José Pepe Álvarez y diez performeros de distintas generaciones que han colaborado con ella en el pasado. Álvarez ha estado inmerso durante diez años en el trabajo de Viveca Vázquez como estudiante,  bailarín y ahora colega. 
En este momento y para el final de esta retrospectiva, Vázquez invita a José Pepe Álvarez a dirigir los eventos de clausura de CONDUCTA que incluyen un foro y un performance que el denomina ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ Para esta pieza, Álvarez re-visitará los postulados conceptuales y estéticos de la coreógrafa usando su material de archivo tales como documentaciones de sus piezas, entrevistas y artículos sobre su trabajo para re-formular su propuesta experimental.  Álvarez hace particular énfasis en su invención de movimiento y su relación con el lenguaje que Vázquez atribuye en asuntos sobre raza y género, contextualizados en la situación social y política de Puerto Rico.   
 
 The project 
¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece¨ works with different raw materials from Vazquez´ archive to extract them from their original context. The audience will be invited to travel with Álvarez and other performers around two empty gallery spaces on the first floor of the Puerto Rico Museum of Contemporary Art,: the courtyard and the gallery where the CONDUCTA exhibition is presented. This journey will be guided by performative gestures, movement improvisations, video installations and other theatrical resources to articulate this performative inquiry. Álvarez’s ten-year experience working with Viveca Vázquez will allow him to contextualize all of this through a dialogue with some aspects of his own solo works. 
The audience is going to experiment Alvarez´ interpretation of some of Vázquez’ pieces, performed by and through his own body, and also his appropriation of some non-choreographic materials. These he will reformulate into a live installation that will incorporate her video and sound works, originally created for dance pieces, here re-signified for a museum context. 
Álvarez’ co-director is Arnaldo Rodríguez-Bagué, who is also working on Vázquez’ retrospective and whose interest in Vazquez´ works comes from the fields of visual anthropology and video art. For ¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece¨, Álvarez is formulating with Rodríguez Bagué a comparative montage of Vazquez’ video works and those by experimental artist Maya Deren. 
One aspect of this piece is the reinterpretation of one of Vazquez’ most important video pieces, ¨Las Playas Son Nuestras¨ (¨The Beaches are Ours¨), which focuses on the environmental and political issues related to the US military practices carried out in and around Vieques, a small island off the eastern coast of Puerto Rico. This video piece, recorded in 1990 with professional dancers and related to one of the most intractable political situations of the time, is now brought into a different sociopolitical context, as relevant today as the US military occupation of Vieques was some years ago. A group of seventeen- and eighteen-year old immigrant residents of the Dominican community of Barrio Obrero will be part of his “re-writing” of this video, which focuses on immigration, environmental, social and health issues caused by the contaminated waters of El Caño Martín Peña, a mangrove channel located in the center of the San Juan metropolitan area which is part of their community. . 
Additionally Álvarez is going to direct Viveca Vázquez as a dancer and performer by re-staging a selection of one of her pieces. 
CONDUCTA’s closing event –at the Puerto Rico Museum of Contemporary Art– seeks to underscore Vázquez’ contribution to dance and theatre as well as reflect upon the connections between her body of work and that of younger generations of contemporary artists in Puerto Rico. It also presents an approach to Vázquez’s work through another, younger artist’s perspective who wishes to contribute to the theoretical and critical production that gives continuity to the contemporary arts in Puerto Rico. 
 
El proyecto
 ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ se sirve de los materiales de archivo de Viveca Vázquez y los saca fuera de su contexto original. El público será invitado a recorrer con José Pepe Álvarez y otros performeros las dos galerías del primer piso del Museo de Arte Contemporáneo incluyendo el patio interior y la galería donde la exhibición CONDUCTA está ubicada. Este recorrido será guiado por gestos performáticos, improvisaciones de movimiento, coreografías, instalaciones de video y recursos teatrales que articularán este performance investigativo. ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ recoge la experiencia de Álvarez colaborando con Vázquez estableciendo así, un diálogo entre la obra de Vázquez y algunos aspectos formales y temáticos de su obra como solista. 
El público experimentará la re-interpretación corporal de Álvarez sobre algunas piezas de Vázquez así como también la apropiación de materiales no coreográficos junto con otros materiales ¨crudos¨ no utilizados del archivo de la coreógrafa. En estas reformulaciones Álvarez utilizará también material de video-arte junto con algunas bandas sonoras, originalmente creadas para piezas escénicas y de movimiento, para así resignificarlas en una ¨instalación viva¨ dentro del contexto del museo. 
Álvarez trabaja en colaboración con su co-director Arnaldo Rodríguez Bagué, quien también colabora en CONDUCTA. El interés de Rodríguez Bagué en el trabajo de Viveca Vázquez proviene de los terrenos de la antropología visual y el video arte. Para¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ Álvarez está formulando junto a Rodríguez Bagué un montaje visual comparativo entre el trabajo de video-arte de Viveca Vázquez y los videos experimentales de Maya Deren.
Otro de los aspectos importantes de ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ es la reinterpretación de una de las piezas de video mas importantes de Vázquez, ¨Las playas son nuestras¨, la cual enfoca en los asuntos políticos y ambientales causados por las prácticas militares de EEUU llevadas a cabo en Vieques, una pequeña isla municipio ubicada en la costa este de Puerto Rico. Esta pieza de video, filmada originalmente en 1990 con bailarines profesionales, basada en una de las situaciones políticas mas insuperables de nuestros tiempos, es ahora llevada a una situación sociopolítica diferente pero igualmente relevante como la ocupación militar de EEUU en Vieques hace unos años atrás. Un grupo de jóvenes entre 17 y 18 años de la comunidad dominicana de Barrio Obrero serán parte de la ¨re-escritura¨ de este video enfocado en la inmigración y los problemas sociales, ambientales y de salud causados por las aguas contaminadas del Caño Martín Peña, un manglar localizado en el centro del área metropolitana de San Juan donde se encuentra su comunidad. Adicional a esto Álvarez dirigirá a Viveca Vázquez para una de las re-formulaciones de sus piezas. 
Los eventos de clausura de CONDUCTA pretenden resaltar las contribuciones de Vázquez en el teatro y la danza así como reflexionar sobre las conexiones entre su cuerpo de trabajo y el de generaciones mas jóvenes de artistas contemporáneos en Puerto Rico. Este proyecto también propone un acercamiento al trabajo de Viveca Vázquez desde una perspectiva artística jóven contribuyendo al análisis crítico y teórico sobre el arte contemporáneo en Puerto Rico. 
 
 
What You Get 
•               Our deep gratitude for helping to support the development this piece as a research practice of an important part of the history of Puerto Rican experimental dance and art.
•               Your name will appear in the hand program and also in a module at the entrance of the first gallery that will remain for the three performances of ¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece”
 
Lo que obtienes 
•               Nuestro profundo agradecimiento por apoyar el desarrollo de esta pieza como práctica investigativa que celebra una parte importante de la historia de la danza y del arte experimental escénico y performativo en Puerto Rico.
 
•               Su nombre aparecerá en el programa de mano y también en un módulo a la entrada de la galería que permanecerá durante las tres presentaciones de¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez ¨.
 
 The Impact
•               To stimulate other Puerto Rican museums to share their galleries for live art performances. 
•               To rescue part of the history of experimental dance and its link to the local contemporary art scene.
•               To research the historical context of experimental dance in Puerto Rico. 
•               To highlight the influence of Vázquez’ aesthetics upon younger generations of Puerto Rican performers.
•               To bring a contemporary art experience into disadvantage communities.  
 
El impacto
Estimular otros museos de la isla a compartir sus galerías a artistas de arte vivo y del performance.
Rescatar parte de la historia de la danza experimental y sus conexiones con el arte experimental.
Investigar el contexto histórico de la danza experimental en Puerto Rico. 
Resaltar la influencia estética de Vazquez en generaciones jóvenes de artistas.
Ofrecer la oportunidad de experimentar el arte contemporáneo a comunidades desventajadas.  
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Any help or any other donation in support of this project will be more than welcome but please spread the word among your peers and contacts so that we can raise the funds that will allow us to develop this retrospective’s finale. 
 
Otra forma de apoyar
Por favor riegue la voz entre sus contactos y amigos para poder recaudar los fondos necesarios para que esta pieza se pueda desarrollar.
story_txt:
Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez


This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece  


 


Short Summary

To celebrate renowned Puerto Rican choreographer and dancer Viveca Vázquez’ 30-year career, the Puerto Rico Museum of Contemporary Art (MAC) has organized a retrospective exhibition about her work entitled A Choreography of Error: Viveca Vázquez’ CONDUCT.  The exhibition, which opened to the public last April, has been curated by scholar Nelson Rivera and includes video and documentary material. A rich education program has been designed integrating forums, artistic workshops, and,–as part of the MAC Live Workshop Program– performances of some of Vázquez’ pieces. The exhibition project opened to the public with a performance that merged a selection of some twelve choreographic excerpts, original costumes, and video art material directed by Viveca Vázquez, in which she also performed with ten other dancers who have collaborated with her in the past. Amongst these is José Pepe Álvarez, her co-director for this repertory, who has been immersed in Vázquez’ work for the past ten years as student, dancer, and now colleague.

*This interdisciplinary project is now open to the public and will run through September 22, 2013.


For the project finale, Viveca Vázquez invited José Pepe Álvarez to direct the closing events, which include a forum and a closing performance that he has titled ¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece¨ (¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨).  

José Pepe Álvarez is re-visiting her conceptual and aesthetic propositions by using archive material, such as performance recordings, interviews and articles about her work, to reformulate those experimental art principles. He is highlighting her movement invention and its relation to language, which Vázquez has endowed with urban Caribbean as well as with race, gender and queer attributes in the context of Puerto Rico’s sociopolitical situation. 
 

Resumen del proyecto

En celebración de los treinta años de carrera de la renombrada bailarina y coreógrafa puertorriqueña Viveca Vázquez, el Museo de Arte Contemporáneo de Puerto Rico (MAC) ha organizado la exhibición retrospectiva: Coreografía del error: CONDUCTA de Viveca Vázquez. La exhibición, abierta al público el pasado mes de abril, ha sido curada por el estudioso Nelson Rivera e incluye material fílmico y documental. Un variado programa educativo ha sido diseñado para el proyecto, incluyendo foros, talleres artísticos y –como parte del programa de Taller Vivo del MAC– performances de algunas coreografías de Viveca Vázquez. CONDUCTA abrió al público con una presentación que recogía doce fragmentos de una selección de piezas coreográficas que junto con vestuarios originales y piezas de video arte, fue dirigida por Viveca Vázquez quien también participó como bailarina junto a su co-director José Pepe Álvarez y diez performeros de distintas generaciones que han colaborado con ella en el pasado. Álvarez ha estado inmerso durante diez años en el trabajo de Viveca Vázquez como estudiante,  bailarín y ahora colega. 

En este momento y para el final de esta retrospectiva, Vázquez invita a José Pepe Álvarez a dirigir los eventos de clausura de CONDUCTA que incluyen un foro y un performance que el denomina ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ Para esta pieza, Álvarez re-visitará los postulados conceptuales y estéticos de la coreógrafa usando su material de archivo tales como documentaciones de sus piezas, entrevistas y artículos sobre su trabajo para re-formular su propuesta experimental.  Álvarez hace particular énfasis en su invención de movimiento y su relación con el lenguaje que Vázquez atribuye en asuntos sobre raza y género, contextualizados en la situación social y política de Puerto Rico.   


 


 The project 


¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece¨ works with different raw materials from Vazquez´ archive to extract them from their original context. The audience will be invited to travel with Álvarez and other performers around two empty gallery spaces on the first floor of the Puerto Rico Museum of Contemporary Art,: the courtyard and the gallery where the CONDUCTA exhibition is presented. This journey will be guided by performative gestures, movement improvisations, video installations and other theatrical resources to articulate this performative inquiry. Álvarez’s ten-year experience working with Viveca Vázquez will allow him to contextualize all of this through a dialogue with some aspects of his own solo works. 


The audience is going to experiment Alvarez´ interpretation of some of Vázquez’ pieces, performed by and through his own body, and also his appropriation of some non-choreographic materials. These he will reformulate into a live installation that will incorporate her video and sound works, originally created for dance pieces, here re-signified for a museum context. 


Álvarez’ co-director is Arnaldo Rodríguez-Bagué, who is also working on Vázquez’ retrospective and whose interest in Vazquez´ works comes from the fields of visual anthropology and video art. For ¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece¨, Álvarez is formulating with Rodríguez Bagué a comparative montage of Vazquez’ video works and those by experimental artist Maya Deren. 


One aspect of this piece is the reinterpretation of one of Vazquez’ most important video pieces, ¨Las Playas Son Nuestras¨ (¨The Beaches are Ours¨), which focuses on the environmental and political issues related to the US military practices carried out in and around Vieques, a small island off the eastern coast of Puerto Rico. This video piece, recorded in 1990 with professional dancers and related to one of the most intractable political situations of the time, is now brought into a different sociopolitical context, as relevant today as the US military occupation of Vieques was some years ago. A group of seventeen- and eighteen-year old immigrant residents of the Dominican community of Barrio Obrero will be part of his “re-writing” of this video, which focuses on immigration, environmental, social and health issues caused by the contaminated waters of El Caño Martín Peña, a mangrove channel located in the center of the San Juan metropolitan area which is part of their community. . 


Additionally Álvarez is going to direct Viveca Vázquez as a dancer and performer by re-staging a selection of one of her pieces. 


CONDUCTA’s closing event –at the Puerto Rico Museum of Contemporary Art– seeks to underscore Vázquez’ contribution to dance and theatre as well as reflect upon the connections between her body of work and that of younger generations of contemporary artists in Puerto Rico. It also presents an approach to Vázquez’s work through another, younger artist’s perspective who wishes to contribute to the theoretical and critical production that gives continuity to the contemporary arts in Puerto Rico. 

 

El proyecto


 ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ se sirve de los materiales de archivo de Viveca Vázquez y los saca fuera de su contexto original. El público será invitado a recorrer con José Pepe Álvarez y otros performeros las dos galerías del primer piso del Museo de Arte Contemporáneo incluyendo el patio interior y la galería donde la exhibición CONDUCTA está ubicada. Este recorrido será guiado por gestos performáticos, improvisaciones de movimiento, coreografías, instalaciones de video y recursos teatrales que articularán este performance investigativo. ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ recoge la experiencia de Álvarez colaborando con Vázquez estableciendo así, un diálogo entre la obra de Vázquez y algunos aspectos formales y temáticos de su obra como solista. 


El público experimentará la re-interpretación corporal de Álvarez sobre algunas piezas de Vázquez así como también la apropiación de materiales no coreográficos junto con otros materiales ¨crudos¨ no utilizados del archivo de la coreógrafa. En estas reformulaciones Álvarez utilizará también material de video-arte junto con algunas bandas sonoras, originalmente creadas para piezas escénicas y de movimiento, para así resignificarlas en una ¨instalación viva¨ dentro del contexto del museo. 


Álvarez trabaja en colaboración con su co-director Arnaldo Rodríguez Bagué, quien también colabora en CONDUCTA. El interés de Rodríguez Bagué en el trabajo de Viveca Vázquez proviene de los terrenos de la antropología visual y el video arte. Para¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ Álvarez está formulando junto a Rodríguez Bagué un montaje visual comparativo entre el trabajo de video-arte de Viveca Vázquez y los videos experimentales de Maya Deren.


Otro de los aspectos importantes de ¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez¨ es la reinterpretación de una de las piezas de video mas importantes de Vázquez, ¨Las playas son nuestras¨, la cual enfoca en los asuntos políticos y ambientales causados por las prácticas militares de EEUU llevadas a cabo en Vieques, una pequeña isla municipio ubicada en la costa este de Puerto Rico. Esta pieza de video, filmada originalmente en 1990 con bailarines profesionales, basada en una de las situaciones políticas mas insuperables de nuestros tiempos, es ahora llevada a una situación sociopolítica diferente pero igualmente relevante como la ocupación militar de EEUU en Vieques hace unos años atrás. Un grupo de jóvenes entre 17 y 18 años de la comunidad dominicana de Barrio Obrero serán parte de la ¨re-escritura¨ de este video enfocado en la inmigración y los problemas sociales, ambientales y de salud causados por las aguas contaminadas del Caño Martín Peña, un manglar localizado en el centro del área metropolitana de San Juan donde se encuentra su comunidad. Adicional a esto Álvarez dirigirá a Viveca Vázquez para una de las re-formulaciones de sus piezas. 

Los eventos de clausura de CONDUCTA pretenden resaltar las contribuciones de Vázquez en el teatro y la danza así como reflexionar sobre las conexiones entre su cuerpo de trabajo y el de generaciones mas jóvenes de artistas contemporáneos en Puerto Rico. Este proyecto también propone un acercamiento al trabajo de Viveca Vázquez desde una perspectiva artística jóven contribuyendo al análisis crítico y teórico sobre el arte contemporáneo en Puerto Rico. 
  
What You Get 


•               Our deep gratitude for helping to support the development this piece as a research practice of an important part of the history of Puerto Rican experimental dance and art.


•               Your name will appear in the hand program and also in a module at the entrance of the first gallery that will remain for the three performances of ¨This is not a Viveca Vázquez Piece”


 


Lo que obtienes 


•               Nuestro profundo agradecimiento por apoyar el desarrollo de esta pieza como práctica investigativa que celebra una parte importante de la historia de la danza y del arte experimental escénico y performativo en Puerto Rico.

 

•               Su nombre aparecerá en el programa de mano y también en un módulo a la entrada de la galería que permanecerá durante las tres presentaciones de¨Esto no es una pieza de Viveca Vázquez ¨.

 

 The Impact


•               To stimulate other Puerto Rican museums to share their galleries for live art performances. 


•               To rescue part of the history of experimental dance and its link to the local contemporary art scene.


•               To research the historical context of experimental dance in Puerto Rico. 


•               To highlight the influence of Vázquez’ aesthetics upon younger generations of Puerto Rican performers.


•               To bring a contemporary art experience into disadvantage communities.  

 

El impacto


Estimular otros museos de la isla a compartir sus galerías a artistas de arte vivo y del performance.


Rescatar parte de la historia de la danza experimental y sus conexiones con el arte experimental.


Investigar el contexto histórico de la danza experimental en Puerto Rico. 


Resaltar la influencia estética de Vazquez en generaciones jóvenes de artistas.

Ofrecer la oportunidad de experimentar el arte contemporáneo a comunidades desventajadas.  
 

Other Ways You Can Help


Any help or any other donation in support of this project will be more than welcome but please spread the word among your peers and contacts so that we can raise the funds that will allow us to develop this retrospective’s finale. 


 


Otra forma de apoyar


Por favor riegue la voz entre sus contactos y amigos para poder recaudar los fondos necesarios para que esta pieza se pueda desarrollar.

story:
Why this project?

I was inspired to do this show as a way of paying homage to my childhood spent on 40 acres of land in Langley.  Over the last few years, I’ve noticed that "outdoorsy" side of me slowly fading away.  Despite the fact that Vancouver is a natural rainforest and surrounds us with an overwhelming abundance of natural resources, at times I’ve felt like I’m being swallowed by the hustle and bustle of city life.  The need to work multiple jobs to support myself as a budding artist disconnects me - and I know many others - from the natural world and elements that surround us all the time (as we struggle to make ends meet in one of the most expensive cities in the world).  It’s a sad and strange paradox, not all encompassing, but a true reflection on my life and on the lives of others I know, with an acknowledgement of where I’ve come from and where I'm at now.

As a graduate of UBC's BA Honours program, I was also looking to challenge myself by truly spearheading a project, rather than just being the second string.  My passion for collective creation and on-site productions stems from the diverse challenges and happy accidents that present themself under atypical circumstances, influencing our creation in ways we may never think of in that conventional black-box theatre space.

The "Fringe" Onsite Challenge

No, it is never easy to independently produce any type of theatre production, but it IS particularly challenging when the cost attached to getting involved with the festival exceeds the actual amount that one may make back.  My passion for this project has led me to take the risk of simply, losing money.  According to my budget, even taking into consideration "in kind" donations from friends and family, the cost of the show simply exceeds the revenues, by approximately $1650.  This is factoring in the time and effort that is put in by the actors, the crew, my production team, and everything else that goes into putting on the show, like costumes, props etc.

THE CATCH :  We only have one audience member per show.  The show is meant to be experienced in a one-to-one framework with one audience member being guided through the play with the lead actress.  So in theory, there is only potential to sell one ticket per show:  Which means we have...

42 shows at $10 per show

28 shows at $12 per show

Budgeting our projections at 30% audience capacity = $226.80 from ticket sales

Even at full audience capacity, that only = $756 and it costs...drumroll please...

$800 for the Onsite Venue alone!

So, unfortunately, we can't even really break even without help from friends outside of ticket sales. :(  

What We Need & What You Get

Anything and everything you would like to send our way.  And I know everyone says this, but, every little bit really DOES HELP!

If you're not able to make a monetary contribution, there are many other ways that you can contribute.  Should you want to make an in-kind donation to the production you can e-mail me directly at jessica-nelson@live.ca

Items that would be useful for the show! 

1. Outdoor battery powered lanterns!  This is our way of lighting the show, and it might seem like at this point in time it stays light out longer, by September, the sun will be setting by 8:00pm, so lighting will be key!!! (cost of batteries and lanterns each can add up, my friends!)

2. If you are affiliated with some sort of printing company and would like to donate or sponsor the show with posters and postcards to advertise, that would also be incredible!

3. If you have read about the show from the above campaign and would like to share information about us on social media to help us get an audience that too would be amazing!!!

The Impact

Our artistic economy is in dire straights at the moment.  With continuous funding cuts and lack of support from provincial and federal artistic governing bodies, theatre suffers across the board.  As it is, the majority of funding still goes to union-affliiated theatre houses that have been staples in the Vancouver scene for a long time.  Supporting the Fringe Festival, and in turn supporting artists who participate in this festival, gives new artists an opportunity to take risks and contribute to the theatre canon in ways that are less affected by the need to do a show that will "have an audience".  This is not to say that the audience is invalid, but more a point in support of taking chances in order to further the artistic make-up and craft of theatre.  It gives us an outlet to really explore pressing issues that are affecting us NOW!  It also gives us an opportunity to push the envelope and explore new ways for theatre to plant roots in our current arts environment.

Why Theatre?

There is a romance about theatre.  That romance is in its fleeting nature.  No matter what, no show is ever like the last.  Something that happens at one show, may not happen at another.  This is even more of a possibility when one is doing an on-site show, with the environment also playing a character in the piece.  Also, no matter what you do, there is no way to accurately document a live performance.  Never.  No one has ever managed, and no one ever will, because there is a genuine exchange of energy that takes place between audience and performer that can not be replicated.  And in particular with this show, the exchange, will inevitably be even more intimate when one person's energy and participation with the actors, will inform the style, mood, and energy of the piece.  THAT'S exciting!  Don't you think?  The ephemerality is priceless! 


As a final note:

THANK YOU!!!!!

So much!  For taking the time to read about our show!  For spreading the word!  For any and all support that you're able to give in any way shape or form!  And for supporting the arts and seeing the value in it for our world today! 

 

 

UPDATE:

 


Wow, I feel so lucky to have such an incredible family. I want to send out a BIG shout out to the first people to donate to the campaign. Jennifer Salahub and James McCrea you guys are amazing and thank you so much for your generosity and support! Looking forward to the next time you're all in Vancouver so I can offer up 4 hours of nanying for you!

xox

And NOW, a sneak peak photo from tonight's rehearsal! ;) It's now in the Gallery tab! Check on over for it!

story:
Help us produce Artists Entrained's first production!

Artists Entrained is collective of actors, dancers, directors, and producers who are looking to create and put on new and interesting work that challenges and connects. Our debut production is "Love and Information" by Caryl Churchill. 

Over 50 scenes, over 100 hundred characters, in an hour and forty minutes, tell their stories, exploring what it's like to see, feel, and exist in a world where technology is king. 

Every donation, whether $5 or $500, helps to bring us closer to creating our dream production. As a theatre company in its infancy, we need YOUR help to create magic. 

LOVE AND INFORMATION features the talents of:
Elli Brown, James Cougar Canfield, Bradley Carter, Madeleine Drees, Helena Farhi, Jose Gamo, Dakarai J. Mills, Emily Oliveira , Liz Pegg, Claiborne Tomlinson, Shannon Uphold, and Ruby Vadiveloo

What We Need

Here's what your donations help cover:

Space Rental - $1200

Performance Rights - $600

Website Design & Domain- $65

Publicity Design & Execution (Flyers, Ads, Etc.) - $250

Costumes, Props, Lighting - $300

Insurance - $150

Credit Card Reader- $100

Concessions - $100

What You Get

For every donation, you will receive a Love and Information perk! From social media shoutouts, to memes, to even getting an opportunity to decide what we do in the show, you are help us build our show from the ground up and receiving some super fun bonuses to say THANK YOU!

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see our show!

LOVE AND INFORMATION performs 

March 29 & 31st at 8pm | March 30 & April 1st at 2pm and 8pm
at St. Paul’s Upstairs Theatre (334 S. 5th St., Brooklyn, NY, 11211)
 $10 advance online | $15 at the door

Help spread the word! 
Find us on FACEBOOK (Artists Entrained), TWITTER (@ArtistsEntraind), & Instagram (ArtistsEntrained).

story:
.... a projector is essential for our show  ... help us get one !


Our Story

An innovative performance: 
spoken word fused with enchanting experimental music, contemporary dance and mesmerizing visuals.

      Lovers Walk - A Poetic Journey in Eight Scenes, a short (yet infinite) odyssey created by dancer Siri Embla and poet Gus Simonovic, with video material by visual artist Peter Brierley-Millman and music by Jo Blankenburg ( piano ), Gareth Priceless ( guitar ), Dubtext ( all things electronica ) and Kotaro Nishishita (classical guitar ).
"Aroha, acquaintance, romance, affection, devotion, liaison - the show is about love in all its forms. “Lovers Walk reshapes shapes and brighten colours in your love-kaleidoscope while telling you a story that you know so well, as it was your own,”

 ... created to be a feast for all senses .. rich in content and extravagant  ... 
and now, compacted to be portable/ tour-able/perform-able in small spaces ...
                     
             performed LIVE by Gus and Siri .. but 

 WITHOUT A PROJECTOR THERE IS NO SHOW!!! 

We've been blessed with borrowing a projector for our shows in New Zealand...  Now we are travelling overseas, Fringe Festival in Edinburgh and other spots in Europe we must take one with us.

The Impact

Your contributions will help us towards purchasing a projector. Every $ counts! 
We are used to make things happen for next to nothing... but we can't mime a projector.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to be able to present our show in its full glory 
You get lots of love and become a big part of our "Lovers Walk"  ... choose you perks !

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread  the word about this campaign through your social networks!!! 
Its a DIWO effort! (Do it with others)

We need your help! We love you for helping us!
Even if you cant give us those clinging coins in our hat... share, like our FB page  
support international art collaborations!!

Lovers Walk

Printable Reality


Come see our show!

If you are in Edinburgh for the Festival we would love to hear from you and meet you!

http://www.facebook.com/home.php#!/event.php?ei...


Pass it on ... pass it on .... yeah!

.... a projector is essential for our show  ... help us get one !

Our Story
An
innovative performance: 

spoken word fused with enchanting experimental
music, contemporary dance and mesmerizing visuals.

      Lovers Walk - A Poetic Journey in Eight Scenes, a short (yet infinite) odyssey created by dancer Siri Embla and poet Gus Simonovic, with video material by visual artist Peter Brierley-Millman and music by Jo Blankenburg ( piano ), Gareth Priceless ( guitar ), Dubtext ( all things electronica ) and Kotaro Nishishita (classical guitar )."Aroha, acquaintance, romance, affection, devotion, liaison - the show is about love in all its forms. “Lovers Walk reshapes shapes and brighten colours in your love-kaleidoscope while telling you a story that you know so well, as it was your own,”

 ... created to be a feast for all senses .. rich in content and extravagant  ... 
and now, compacted to be portable/ tour-able/perform-able in small spaces ...                                  performed LIVE by Gus and Siri .. but 
 WITHOUT A PROJECTOR THERE IS NO SHOW!!! We've been blessed with borrowing a projector for our shows in New Zealand...  Now we are travelling overseas, Fringe Festival in Edinburgh and other spots in Europe we must take one with us.

story:
Tickets now on sale:  http://drunkencity.brownpapertickets.com/

 

WHEN YOUR HOMETOWN IS SHAKEN TO ITS CORE, THAT'S WHEN YOUR PRIORITIES ARE MOST CLEAR.

 
After the devastating effects of Hurricane Sandy in the tri-state area, we are more committed than ever to our original mission--to bring light and joy to NY in this difficult time of year through theatre!
 
Enter Adam Bock's "The Drunken City"--a funny (and wise) play about 3 best friends out on the town for a bachelorette party, and the ways in which all those pink drinks reveal the truth of their desires and the reality of their relationships. When the bride-to-be questions her upcoming wedding, it ripples through her friendships and creates a tectonic shift that they may not all recover from. 

Join us in getting this play onstage in November, so we can bring some lightness to the winter months and a story of alternate families at the time of year that celebrates families and community connections.

HOW ARE YOU HELPING WITH SANDY?

So many people feel at a loss--what can I possibly do? As artists, our gift is unique--we can bring smiles and entertainment and a feeling of normalcy. For the victims:

-We will be rehearsing and performing for NY residents in relief shelters

-We will be offering FREE tickets to the people in shelters, giving them a night on the town

-We're also donating 10% of our ticket sales to The Mayor's Fund to Advance NYC, which is exclusively centered on Sandy relief right now.

 

For more info on the show and creative team, see below!

*********************************************************

What are you crazy kids up to?

We're a dedicated group of actors who will perform 12 shows of Adam Bock's "The Drunken City" in late November - early December. We've hired a director, assembled a stellar team of designers, and rented a theater.

Now, all we need is a little cash to get us on stage!!

Samantha Payne Garland, the lead producer, self-produced a play early in 2011, and it was a huge success. This is her newest effort, a great big ambitious goal to produce and co-star in a play in a 65-seat theater, with a real design team supporting the players. She is joined by David Marshall, Jen Ponton, Kelly Strandemo, and Tyrone Davis, Jr. and Nicholas Cocchetto. We will be directed by Misti Wills.

We'll be performing at the Workshop Theater Main Stage in midtown Manhattan. It's a 65-seat, plushly outfitted theater.
 
(Full production details listed below)

What will you do with all this money?

We are fundraising for the very basic costs of space and the rights to perform the play. Theater rentals and rehearsal space are exorbitantly expensive in this little town of NYC.

Theater rental:            $8,100

Rehearsal space:         $2,500                                                               

Licensing play rights:    $   900                                                          

Insurance:                  $   550

                                 ________

                                 $ 12,050


Most of our designers are pitching in out of passion for the project. But we still want to honor their designs and give them the tools to build the sets, hang the lights, design the sound, and choreograph the heck out of this amazing play.

For this, we will sell tickets to cover the costs.

OR - if we do really well and raise the minimum $13,000 here, then we will spend that money on sets and costumes and lights!! Can you imagine?!!

Why this play now?

This play examines what's hard and what's wonderful about friendships and about love. A bride out on the town for her bachelorette party starts to question the decision she has made... and it ripples through her friendships. "The Drunken City" explores the ways in which our intimate relationships are tied to our peer groups, and how hard it can be to break out of those. And it explores the myriad ways in which we run from love, how being afraid of what's hard keeps us from opening up to what's right in front of us.

"The Drunken City" offers a timely exploration of the relationships that shape us, and the ways we struggle to remain true to ourselves within or in spite of those relationships.

 

Feeling cash strapped, but still want to help out? How about...

-- Forwarding this campaign to 3 friends, to let them know you think it's a worthwhile project. Your endorsement means a lot!

-- Posting about us on Facebook!

-- Sharing our story on Twitter!

 
... You'd be surprised how word of mouth from our friends helps us reach our goal.

So ~ THANKS, for everything you do!!

Feeling cash strapped, but still want to help out? How about...
-- Forwarding this campaign to 3 friends, to let them know you think it's a worthwhile project. Your endorsement means a lot!
-- Posting about us on Facebook!

... You'd be surprised how word of mouth from our friends helps us reach our goal.

So ~ THANKS, for everything you do!!

story:
Who are we?

areadance is a co-operated company in the process of expanding it's artistic scope through collaboration, and an eager openness. Drawn to vulnerability and risk, the work allows each performance to exist as a fleeting moment. We view new inspirations as opportunities to explore boundaries and see potential in space, time, and intention. Movement shares many commonalities, but the breadth of the work is within the through-line that allows movement to become meaning, to become a statement.

As a young company, we've been relishing in the journey and soaking up the creative juices of our 2011 season. Now, after a year of learning, experiencing, and growing, we are so grateful to see our work culminate for an evening in NYC. On November 2nd & 3rd areadance will fill the air of Dixon Place Theater, coloring the walls with memories, dreams, and a deeply rooted soul. Our work, envisioned by two artistic directors, is richly painted by humanity and ingenuity with a physicality tapering on the edge of falling. We care less about the final product, than we do the development of that project; a trait which gives us the power for progressive artistry. Movement is a universal language, which has the potential to speak volumes and generate conversation.


By donating to our campaign, you will bring areadance's vision to life. Contributing towards our efforts makes you a member of the areadance family, having a firsthand opportunity to access our work and share personal insight.


What We Need

areadance set a fundraising goal of $2000 by October 14th, 2012. By contributing to our campaign, and helping us reach our goal, your funds will support the following:

  • Rochester Fringe Festival September 23rd 2012
    • Travel & Dancer's Pay
  •  DUMBO Dance Festival September 29th 2012
    • Dancer's Pay
  • The Neighborhood Academy Teaching Residency in Pittsburgh, PA October 1st to the 5th 2012
    • Travel, Student & Community Outreach
  • our history, rooted.areadance full length concert presented by Dixon Place Theater on November 2nd & 3rd 2012
    • Dancer's Pay, Theater Fees, Production Fees, Marketing & Promotional Material, Costumes

What You Get

 

$25 = 1 Free drink ticket during the areadance performance, November 2nd and 3rd

$50 =  1 Free ticket to the areadance performance, November 2nd & 3rd, in NYC 

$100 = 2 Free tickets to the areadance performance, November 2nd & 3rd, in NYC

$200 = 60min Swedish Massage 


In the event that areadance does not reach $2000, any and all funds will go towards partial payment of the above expenses!

The Impact

      Without movement, the appreciation for the human form would be lost, along with the value of movement therapy. For children and adults, dance challenges motor skills through complex movement and rhythm, begins nurturing interpersonal contact, forces imitation through visual stimulation, and heightens self awareness. By donating to our campaign you are working with us to be a progressive force in the performing arts world, to preserve movement as a therapeutic tool of expression. Your help, brings the timeless sculpture, historical painting, and heart wrenching photographs to life. Recognition and support for performing artists is extremely important in today’s world, as dancers and companies alike work relentlessly to cultivate their craft. They understand the importance of what they do, and in all their efforts, hope others will begin to understand as well.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Attend our full length company concert on November 2nd & 3rd, 7:30pm at Dixon Place Theater in New York, NY!
  • Forward our campaign on to your friends and help spread the word!
  • Join our Facebook page at areadance/facebook!

story:
Our Embodied Impulses

…is a dance project for 10 dance artists to join in creating a performance using movement scores that encourage dancers to engage in a grounding and introspective process. The movement scores that shape this project will cultivate a meditative and reflective embodied practice, accompanied by journaling and guided by our physical and emotional impulses. The dancers complete the movement scores in their own private space, then later come together as a group to exchange findings and explore them collectively.  Ultimately, we will create dances together out of the material that surfaces. 

During a time when stress, loss, uncertainty and isolation have been abundant, it feels essential to make time for ourselves to check-in, acknowledge, and release whatever it is we’re holding from the day(s).  The movement scores offered through Our Embodied Impulses will prompt dancers to bring attention to physical and emotional impulses, to move with them, and to create short dances from our personal and embodied narratives. We will identify themes and retell our discussions symbolically via movement.

Our Embodied Impulses has been carefully crafted to provide a nurturing environment for its collaborators and invites cathartic release. By tuning in to our senses, we gather the body’s knowledge and let it guide us through processes of insight and self-expression. In addition to making dances, this is a space for us to be together, move together, and share experiences while exercising our ability as creatives to transform and regenerate our realities into something bigger. We’ll use our dances to move through and release burdens and baggages, to celebrate accomplishments, and to honor ourselves and each other.  We will allow our stories to lead us in creating something new that represents our experiences individually and collectively.   

Our Embodied Impulses: Origin and transformation

 Our Embodied Impulses was created in response to the “lockdowns” put into effect by the coronavirus outbreak.  Originally named, “Hey Homebody” the project aimed to acknowledge the widespread and largescale stressors that many folx were met with - especially related to being isolated at home, and considering the many different scenarios that could make home feel unwelcoming, unsafe, or uncomfortable.  Interested in the question, “how do you find home in your body?”, the movement scores asked dancers to bring attention to their thoughts and their senses, and to let the body speak its peace accompanied by some journal prompts and reflections.  Through virtual rehearsals, collaborators and I came up with an under five-minute piece that represented our reflections and group discussions about the state of the world and our own states of mind during civil unrest, pandemic, and other personal challenges and joys we had met during the summer months.  We really utilized this process as a way to connect and reflect on where we were mentally, emotionally, physically, spiritually, and to identify or explore what we needed together in this creative space.  I'm very much looking forward to sharing this experience with a larger group of movers and dance-makers, this time with a new name, and with more time to indulge in process to tell our stories. 

Your donations will...

…give you access to snippets of our movement scores which include grounding and body centering tips, self-reflection journal prompts, and related movement exercises for you to explore on your own. 

…compensate 10 dancers/collaborators for dedicating their artistry, bodies, time, and talents to our weekly rehearsals. Each dancer will be compensated $18/hr. 

…make ways for us to fully engage in process by helping us reach our goal of (16) 2-hour rehearsals. In this time, we will complete two movement scores, unpack themes, and piece together movement that represents the meaning we uncover.  

…create a movement piece for your viewing pleasure.

THANK YOU!

I look forward to sharing our process and outcomes with you.  I hope that you will join us by starting your own in-home self-reflective movement practice.  I also invite you to be a part of viewing and sharing feedback at the culminating premier of Our Embodied Impulses.

Caitlin is

…a Philadelphia-based dance artist with a background in dance/movement therapy (MA).  In her work, she tends to concentrate on the body's role in wellness, individuality, and expressions of personal and collective narratives. As a freelance dance artist, Caitlin has choreographed and co-created works featured in Philly Fringe Festival 2019, RAW Artist showcase (Baltimore), EMERGE Earthdance multidisciplinary artist residency, and the Painted Bride Art Center’s artist residency, Building Bridges. Caitlin is a teaching artist with Dancing Classrooms, where she teaches ballroom styles to 5th grade students.  For more information, visit https://caitgr33n.wixsite.com/caitgreen

story:
Short Summary 

Hello! We are a group of young theatre-makers and our show, 'The Prince of Homburg' has received a week long transfer to The Space, London between 10-14th December following it's first successful run at LAMDA as part of the MA Directing Season 2019 in September. 

About the show

This new, gender-swapped version of 'The Prince of Homburg' by Heinrich von Kleist has been freely adapted and directed by Júlia Levai based on Neil Bartlett translation as her graduation piece on the MA Directing course at LAMDA. 

We made The Prince of Homburg through a collaborative, experimental and playful process to explore and question through our show topics and ideas such as: What do we do when the politics around us become chaotic and confusing? Do we actively stand up for what we believe in or passively go on as before? What it means for a woman of today to inspire for love and power in a society built on old laws? 

Why are we taking the show further?

As recent drama school graduates the chance to take our show which we made at LAMDA as students further for a week run at a fringe venue in London is an extremely exciting and invaluable opportunity to invite reviewers, programmes, industry and to generally share the piece we have made with a much wider audience. 

We also believe that our show discusses, questions and highlights some very relevant issues and topics about politics, personal bias and young people's agency through a funny, playful and tender way and we would love more people to come and see it. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for £575 to cover around half of our costs as the rights alone for Neil Bartlett's translation cost us £500 which have generously been covered by a donation already. 

We are paying for:

  • Set & costume design (adjustments)
  • Print marketing (posters & flyers)
  • Transporting our set 
  • Travel expenses of cast & creatives 
  • Contingency 

We are also doing this all on a profit share base so all our cast & creatives are generously donating their time into making this show happen and so anything you could spare to help us would really mean the world to us! 

REWARDS

Donations means rewards! Up for grabs are special thank yous, video messages, postcards, signed posters, and tickets to the show. Depending on how much you donate your reward will differ.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand you might not have the funds to help us out with donating, but we would hugely appreciate if you could share this page and let others know about our show and about our fundraising page.

We are beyond excited to take our show further and to make our first steps in the industry and we are so grateful for anything you can spare!

Up for grabs are special thank yous, video messages, postcards, signed posters, and tickets to the show. Depending on how much you donate your reward will differ.Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand you might not have the funds to help us out with donating, but we would hugely appreciate if you could share this page and let others know about our show and about our fundraising page.We are beyond excited to take our show further and to make our first steps in the industry and we are so grateful for anything you can spare!

story:
Help Zero Boy raise funds for the next phase of production for REVOLT! DEATH AND TAXES! I’m seeking $2,500 to bring Seattle-based director Armitage Shanks of Circus Contraption to New York City to further develop this production. The workshop will culminate in an invited performance on March 12th, where I hope to raise interest for a full production this fall. I also intend to develop this show for schools.

REVOLT! DEATH AND TAXES is a one-hour history of the events in Boston leading to the American Revolution with an emphasis on the man that all the founding fathers thought of as the founder - Sam Adams. Beer maker or Muckraker? Riot leader or politician? From the Boston Massacre to the Boston Tea Party, Zero Boy takes you on a sonic comic journey to learn what really happened!

What Your Donation Will Pay For

With the money from this campaign I will be able to accomplish the following: 

  • An intensive three-day workshop with director Armitage Shanks. This will include rehearsal space, travel expenses and production materials.
  • Video shoot and Multimedia creation for production and marketing purposes.
  • Banner and visual elements created by artist Adriano Moraes. 

The Creative Team

Zero Boy (Writer, Performer) is an East Village icon who uses a unique blend of sound and mime, the results being something akin to a performed comic book. He can be seen on the upcoming Nickelodeon show Alien Dawn as the evil Dr. Drago. He appeared Off-Broadway in the Yllana Production of 666, and has performed regularly on NPR’s The Next Big Thing in a special Stump Zero Boy segment. He has been seen on the Fox and Friends, Good Day New York and MTV. www.zeroboy.com

Armitage Shanks (Director) is the co-author & director of The Handsome Little Devils, Squirm Burpee- A Vaudevillian Melodrama, which was performed in November 2010 at the New Victory Theater. See a clip of the show here- http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O1NSe7XiuS. He has directed Zero Boy’s, A Trip To Coney Island With Uncle Zero Boy, as well as sold-out shows for Can Can Cabaret, including Viva Oz Vegas starring El Vez. Armitage is the Performance Director for the Seattle Erotic Art Festival. He is the co-founder and Ringmaster of Circus Contraption, a one-ring traveling circus at the forefront of the New Circus movement, which toured both nationally and internationally for over 12 years.  

Adriano Moraes(Designer) is a Brazilian born cartoonist living in New York. His work has been seen at the Museum of Cartoon and Comic Art, Exit gallery, New Museum, Guggenheim Labs and he is involved with artwork for many events in New York as Dances of Vice, The Pink Room burlesque and Debauchery (hosted by Clown Kong and Stormy Leather). Clients included Warner Brothers, Bluewater Comics (Vincent Price Presents), Vernon Reid, Living Color, Phat Farm, GAP, truTV and others.He currently works on his fantasy graphic novel about Baron Munchausen being published by Convex Publishing. More information about him can be found on facebook.com/theadriano.

Other ways you can help

If you have seen my work and like what I do then help me spread the word. Tell your facebook friends about this unique show. Ask those who are interested in Theater, History and Education to donate and pass this link around. Ask your school to invite Zero Boy to perform!

story:
About Holly Noble

Holly Noble is a leading contemporary ballet artist based in London whose career spans theatre, TV, film as well as working with many of the leading dance companies and choreographers.

She is the Artistic Director of A D Dance Company (formerly Antique Dances), a London-based contemporary ballet company which has fast gained a reputation for its beautifully crafted choreography and exceptional dancers. Her works have been widely toured around the South East, and include 'FAWN', 'Memento', 'Slowly We Collide' and 'And They Have Escaped'. Her last works for A D Dance Company were 'Slowly We Collide' and 'And They Have Escaped' which were performed at the Yard Theatre in Hackney Wick in July 2012.

Holly is also actively involved in youth dance: she's the Artistic Director of English National Ballet's youth company, ENB YouthCo, she's a regular guest teacher at Tring Park School and has worked on numerous youth dance projects and performances as well as delivering workshops throughout the UK and mentoring young dancers and choreographers.

Her other projects include The Female Choreographers' Collective (www.the-fcc.org.uk) and Pop! Ballet (www.popballet.com)


Upcoming Projects

We are seeking your support for the following projects which Holly wants to accomplish over the next few months:


Glastonbury Festival

Having been invited to perform at Glastonbury, we need your support to get our dancers there and back in one piece!

Performing at Glastonbury Festival is an amazing opportunity and would be wonderful exposure for the company, and it would be very rewarding for audiences to watch a work of contemporary ballet, which you certainly wouldn't expect to find somewhere like Glastonbury!

We've been invited to perform 'And They Have Escaped' in the Theatre and Circus areas, and so we need your support to help with the costs of transporting seven dancers from London to Glastonbury and feeding them while they're there - as they'll be working very hard!

 

A D Dance Company Showcase

We want to follow up our Glastonbury performance with a showcase of A D Dance Company pieces in London in July, in response to demand for our works, and also to stimulate interest in a nationwide tour which we are in the process of confirming. Not only will these performances provide us with the opportunity to reconnect with our London audience, but they will enable us to invite key VIPs to see our work and meet with us afterwards.

We are planning two performances at an intimate venue, already associated with contemporary ballet, which will be an ideal setting for attracting new audiences to our work. We feel that it would be in the company's interest to hold two performances rather than one, partly due to the size of the venue and also to accomodate those who would not be able to come if it was only on one date.

These performances are essential to our work because of Holly's belief in helping talented dancers reach their full potential and creating performance opportunities for them to gain more exposure and recognition.

The venue will offer us a box office split which will cover some of the costs of the showcase, but we need your help in ensuring our dancers get paid for their brilliant performances on both nights.



Youth Workshops

Holly is also planning to offer a series of youth dance workshops in Brixton over the summer, specifically to reach young people with limited or no previous experience of dance. The workshops will be designed to teach basic movement sequences and improvisation, while developing sequences which can be performed at the end of the workshops.

The workshops will be taught by Holly and a guest teacher on alternate days so that the students can benefit from different approaches and styles. We will offer two half-day workshops each day to cater for different ages.

These workshops will be offered free of charge to ensure that they are accessible to all, therefore we need your help to cover the costs of venue hire and the teachers' fees so that we do can keep these workshops free of charge.


Where Your Money Will Go

Glastonbury: £1170
Minibus hire: £300
Per diems for 3 days x 7: £420
Dancers' fees x 6: £450

Showcase: £500
Dancers' fees (not covered by box office split): £500

Workshops: £800
Studio hire: £400
Teacher's fees: £400


Other Ways You Can Help

We are grateful for any support people can offer to help us reach our crowdfunding target - even the smallest donations will help us get there!

We know that not everyone can support us financially, so you can also help us by spreading the word of our crowdfunding campaign and helping as many people as possible to see it.

story:
What are You Doing Here?

Our current show, What are You Doing Here?, has been in the works since we first came together in November 2011. After one year of devising, improvising, writing and rewriting it is coming to fruition. Now we need your help to see it through! It's part improvised, part scripted, and all site-specific at the Democracy Center in Cambridge, MA. 

Who is Project: Project

Project: Project is a troupe producing ensemble-created, original stories that combine scripted material with improvisation, in site-specific, non-traditional spaces. Preferring creating to interpreting, we explore and experiment with form, story telling, and the role of the audience.

WE KNOW BOSTON NEEDS THEATRE LIKE THIS! So we're forging our own production, model, and theatre ensemble dedicated to this kind of creative process.

What We Need & What You Get

YOUR DONATION MEANS YOU SUPPORT NEW, NON-TRADITIONAL, AND ENSEMBLE BASED THEATRE...

but like any production, we need some start up cash to get the ball rolling, and hopefully keep it rolling. Your contribution will assist with long term items such as:

  • A website to voice the existence of Project: Project
  • A means of props and costume storage
  • Validation in our existance as artists.

Your contribution will also assist with short term items such as:

  • Props and costumes we can't find in our own closets.
  • Space rental

Donations will garner you gifts, experiences, and opportunities to directly contribute to the show such as: 

  • Your Scout Badge in Fundraising
  • Children's Book Blackout Poetry
  • The opportunity to create our roller derby character names for the show!
  • The opportunity to mould our monologues for the show!
  • A Dinner for you and a Friend made with secret recipies from Project: Project core members. (They will have dinner with you too!)

Look, we're artists....

and we know that what the world needs now is more art. Our formation is a testament to that, and we hope that by working together we can create something bigger than ourselves. Your donation will allow us to go above and beyond by eliminating the red tape that restricts our exciting vision for a new way of making art in Boston.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time, we hope you'll tell someone who can.
... or see our show this November.
... or LIKE us on Facebook to stay in the loop! http://www.facebook.com/ProjectProjectBoston
