story:
Who We Are

  • We're a diverse group of LA-based theatre artists, with backgrounds in everything from the cutting edge works of Sacred Fools, to the Shakespeare and Americana of Theatricum Botanicum, to indie film, the Hollywood Fringe, and burlesque.
  • Like many of you, we are continually shaken by the dangers of our current political climate and president. This unorthodox, yet powerfully poignant cabaret is our way of giving voice and action to our concerns and frustration, and inspiring others to do the same. We hope you'll join us.

What We Need & What You Get

  • In order to stipend/reimburse all of our artists, cover the expenses of publicizing for Fringe, and allow the Cabaret to reach as many audience members as possible, we are setting a goal to raise $7000.
  • Your contribution and interest in our show, no matter how big or small, won't go unrewarded. We are offering a wide variety of amazing perks: personalized Trump-style Twitter rants, signed posters from the cast, an Orange-Mango original skit, and even one-of-a-kind artwork made just for you by Playwright/Producer Teresa Beardsley.
  • Every donation helps. Even if our goal isn't reached, what we do receive will all go to the amazing artists donating their time and talent to the Cabaret.

The Impact

  • Since its conception, theatre has been an integral part of political discourse and resistance. We are believers is the dogma that art can truly bring about the change we wish to see in the world, with its power, as Homer once said, "to teach and to please." 
  • Given our current political situation, it is more imperative now to tap into the political power of theatre than at any other point in recent history. Your contributions will guarantee that our production has all of the tools at its disposal to make a powerful, meaningful statement that serves as a call to action. 
  • As veterans of Fringe and a slew of successful productions around Los Angeles, we have the experience to guarantee your support will have the greatest amount of impact possible, and not go unrewarded or unappreciated.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • As artists ourselves, we know that sometimes making a monetary donation can be challenging. If you are unable to contribute in this way, but still wish to support the Cabaret and what it stands, fear not! There are many other ways to help contribute to the cause!
  • Come to our show at The Hollywood Fringe! Donations are wonderful, but what our production truly needs is an audience to share its story with. Check us out and purchase tickets on our Fringe Website: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/4388
  • Follow us on social networking! Find us on Facebook (@OrangeMangoCabaret), Twitter (@CabaretMango), and Instagram (@themangoinchief). Share our updates and posts, and help us spread the word! Feel free to share this Indiegogo page as well!

Again, thank you, and we hope to see you this June!

story:
FUZE 2016

We need your help!

We are the UK's largest student run Fashion, Dance and Music Event, that has raised over £100,000 for various charities since its establishment.

This year's show, on the 18th and 19th March 2016, is set to be the best yet. We hope to raise as much money as we can for our chosen charity, Bristol Refugee Rights.

FUZE is run solely by students of the University of Bristol, entirely for charity. It not only allows us to showcase our talents through performance, but enables first-hand experience at producing a large-scale event for the many hands involved behind the scenes.

Every year, the show is a huge success due to the generous support of you - our sponsors, family and friends. 

Without you, FUZE 2017 would not be possible.

We start with £0.00 as we gain no funding from the University itself, and therefore to ensure the event is a success we need some support to get started. We massively appreciate even the smallest of donations.

The committee needs to ensure a positive and wide reaching audience, and your money will help support our promotional activities, and enable us to sell all  tickets over both nights. 

With your help in supporting FUZE, we will not only be mounting a prestigious event, but more importantly, we will be supporting and raising awareness for the incredible work of BRR.

The Impact

FUZE 2017 is the most eagerly anticipated event in the Bristol University calendar.

Over its 14 year history, FUZE has grown in reputation and in calibre. Because of your support, we aim to increase its profits for charity this year.

We hope to see you at the event, so you can see for yourself all that is involved in the event. With your help, it is on track to be the best show yet.

So please, take a look at our video, and thank you in advance for your time and generosity.

More!

Our audience and huge on campus publicity through our pre-show events ensures significant exposure to our key sponsors. If you believe that your company would benefit, please don't hesitate to get in contact: sponsorship@fuze-bristol.com

We would love you to get involved

story:
Who am I?

I have started Irish Dancing in 2008 with the certainty that this was what I had to do in my life. I’ve started off with a few workshops, as at that time there were no regular classes in Romania, so in between occasional workshops, I would spend 3 to 6 hours a day practicing every day.

After finishing up my University studies (which included general teaching techniques), I’ve decided it was time I made regular Irish dance classes a permanent thing, so I gave up my “normal” job, my Master’s degree and my financial stability and set-up a proper school which addresses kids and adults all together. My main goal is to make Irish dancing in Romania the popular sport it is abroad and one major contribution to this is my achieving of the TCRG certificate. 


What do I need help for and how will I acknowledge your support ?

Because Irish dancing is a new sport in Romania, it needs all the local involvement it can get in order to be visible and available for an increasing number of people. This means that all the spare time I can get and almost all the financial resources I have I invest in it.

With five to six days of weekly dance classes, plus all the extra hours needed to promote it, manage the performance group, the accounting part, website and social network managing, choreographing, practicing, studying and so on, I would not have the time for an extra job. I would never complain about it, as it is a very rewarding life-style, but my personal means of raising the money for the exam fee and associated expenses have already made me postpone it three times already.

The exam fee is 600 EUR and I will have to travel to Limerick/Ireland and stay there for a few days, as long as the exam lasts. It all sums up to 900 EUR (this including exam fee, travelling costs and accommodation).

With much gratitude for those who will support me in my dream, I will send out a personalised post card from Ireland, so please send me your address. I will also make a list of all the supporters on the school’s website, so please let me know if you wish to be listed and give me your full name.


More about me and the exam

After my beginners years, I have associated with my current TCRG (also the first and only native Polish TCRG), who is mentoring me for the certification exam and so, my dancers were able to start competing. Between 2012-2013, within 3 feiseanna, I had 21 dancers entered (ages 6-42) who brought home a total of 149 awards (13 firsts and a great number of seconds and thirds) and their tendency of getting more medals, being better awarded and granted more and more placements in the next levels of difficulty are part of what makes it all worth the love and effort I put in teaching all of them.

I have as well been in several feiseanna (beginner to Open Championships), but I have decided that being there for their competitions and moments of success was more important, so my focus has naturally shifted. My ultimate goal, the TCRG examination, is more important for my dancers, the school and myself. Succeeding in this would bring much more delight and opportunities for all of us, both nationaly, as well as internationally.

What is this exam?

The TCRG examination is one of the biggest challenges of an Irish dancer choosing to become a teacher. It is a multi-section official examination which the dancer has to pass in front of a Commission and succeeding in it grants you the diploma and international status of official Irish Dancing teacher.

It consists of five sections and the preparation for each of them requires a lot of time, energy and dedication (which often equals to days of just living and breathing Irish dance – dance classes, personal practice, learning the traditional, modern and social dances, choreographing and so on).

The exam sections:

1) practical test in dancing

2) written ceili dancing test (for which you have to know inside-out all the 30 traditional social Irish dances from a book).

3) practical test in teaching ceili dancing

4) practical test in teaching solo dancing

5) written music test


Other Ways You Can Help

As a self-employed dance teacher, I am very aware of the fact that sometimes, even though a campaign speaks to you, it may be hard to contribute financially and that is why I will appreciate you helping me with just spreading the word among those who might resonate with my dream.

Feel free to share my campaign via e-mail, Facebook or any other social media you might be using. Don't hesitate to share using the Indiegogo tools directly.

You can find my school on Facebook: link to the page , I am out there myself: my profile, so feel free to say "hi" and ask any other details you'd like to know, or just be connected and see what my dancers and I are up to.
story_txt:
Who am I?
I have started Irish
Dancing in 2008 with the certainty that this was what I had to do in my life. I’ve
started off with a few workshops, as at that time there were no regular classes
in Romania, so in between occasional workshops, I would spend 3 to 6 hours a day practicing every day. After finishing up my University studies (which included
general teaching techniques), I’ve decided it was time I made regular Irish
dance classes a permanent thing, so I gave up my “normal” job, my Master’s
degree and my financial stability and set-up a proper school which addresses
kids and adults all together. My main goal is to make Irish
dancing in Romania the popular sport it is abroad and one major contribution to this is my achieving of the TCRG certificate. 
What do I need help for and how will I acknowledge your support ?

Because Irish dancing
is a new sport in Romania, it needs all the local involvement it can get in
order to be visible and available for an increasing number of people. This
means that all the spare time I can get and almost all the financial resources
I have I invest in it. 
With five to six days
of weekly dance classes, plus all the extra hours needed to promote it, manage
the performance group, the accounting part, website and social network
managing, choreographing, practicing, studying and so on, I would not have the
time for an extra job. I would never complain about it, as it is a very
rewarding life-style, but my personal means of raising the money for the exam
fee and associated expenses have already made me postpone it three times
already.
The exam fee is 600 EUR
and I will have to travel to Limerick/Ireland and stay there for a few days, as
long as the exam lasts. It all sums up to 900 EUR (this including exam fee, travelling costs and accommodation). 
With much gratitude for those who will support
me in my dream, I will send out a personalised post card from Ireland, so please send me
your address. I will also make a list of all the supporters on the school’s website, so please let me know if you wish to be
listed and give me your full name.
More about me and the exam

story:
Thank you Thank you Thank you to all who have given so freely to make Annelise's dream come true.  Do another good deed today....

I am asking you to generously support a beautiful young talented girl, Annelise Colman, from Margaret River (a wine growing area, 3 hours south of Perth) is currently in her 2nd her in Dance at the prestigious Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts and has sacrificed everything to be able to do this.

Annelise has won the Cecchetti WA Intermediate Scholarship and passed her Advanced 1 with 100%.  Annelise was also a Gold representative for WA’s entry to the Lucie Saronova Memorial Award.  She is a beautiful dancer.

When coming to Perth for training in the past Annelise has had to stay in an unpowered caravan on the outskirts of the metropolitan area. This facility can only be accessed after 10:00pm and must vacate by 8:00am. It is the only accommodation they can afford. From Margaret River the family travels 315 kms to Perth - a 3.5 hour trip one way. 

We are asking you to donate some money - $20 would make all the difference to help pay her student housing, Academy fees and, in general, food and pointe shoes which are all essential and expensive.  Anything will help - it all adds up!

We are hoping to raise $10,000 to help Annelise finish her course (fees are $7,000 per year)  Anything else raised would go towards living expenses and pointe shoes.  Should you be extra generous and we raise more than this it would go towards sending Annelise overseas to audition for ballet companies.

It is a privilege and a pleasure to work with such a talented and dedicated student as Annelise Colman.  She is passionate about ballet and wishes to make dance her career. 

I hope you can find it in your heart and pocket to do a good deed for someone who deserves all the help we can give her, please be generous and feel good you have helped further a young dancer's career. 

Please spread the word through any medium possible!

A campaign like this is only as good as it's sharing- If you use the sharing tools at the top of the page, once a day, letting everyone know how much you support this campaign that can be a really big help.

story:
Our Story

Harold and the Purple Crayon is the story of a boy with a magical purple crayon that makes everything he draws come to life. It is inherently about creating something out of nothing. To highlight this, we use a company of six performers: one to play Harold and the rest to collectively portray the crayon and create the structure of Harold’s worlds using their bodies.

Overall, this adaptation of Harold and the Purple Crayon tells the tale of a boy who leaves home only to discover, using the assistance of a little magic, that he needs to return. The piece’s whimsical exploration of themes such as rebuilding and the importance of community will allow spectators of all generations to follow both their imaginations and their hearts.

We began the creation and devising process in September 2017, and have since grown it into a full scale production that we are excited about sharing with as many kids as possible. 

Our Goal:

We are lucky to be mounting our production as a part of Northwestern University's Mainstage ImagineU Season September 29 and 30, 2018.

Because the ensemble members make the world Harold creates with their bodies, we have an incredibly low operating budget. We are fundraising to cover the following costs:

  • Compensating our artists: $900   

It is important to us that the people working on our production (ensemble and crew) get compensated for their time and commitment to this process (2 wks rehearsal and 1 weekend of shows)

  • Props & Costumes: $100

We invested in the props (flashlights and the purple crayon) and costumes (purple and white hoodies) for our first workshop, so this budget will go towards their upkeep and batteries for the flashlights. 

  • Pre-show Supplies: $200

Before the show begins, audience members are invited to draw with the ensemble. This budget will go towards having those supplies on hand for every show.

  • The Future: $800

We want this show to reach as many children as possible. We plan to invite other companies, schools, and community organizers to the production at Northwestern. This budget would allow us to comfortably bring the show to wherever our next opportunity strikes :)

The Impact

As seen in the image above, audience members of all ages loved our first workshop of the piece!

Rives Collins, a Professor who heads up Theater for Young Audiences at Northwestern said,

"I was gobsmacked by the sheer inventiveness of this piece. I want this show to have legs -- I want everyone suffering from a wonder-deficit (who isn't?) to experience the passion and inventiveness of this terrific ensemble."

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, we hope you'll consider spreading the word!

Be sure to buy tickets to the show here: https://wirtz.northwestern.edu/harold

story:
Our Story

Christopher K. Morgan & Artists is the newest company to hit the Washington, DC dance scene and is the resident dance company of CityDance.  

November 18-20, the company will present Reveal, an evening of dance to celebrate the opening of the CityDance Studio Theater at Strathmore. But BEFORE we can hit the stage we need your help, to make sure we can get DRESSED!

Currently almost all the funds available to the company are going to artist fees.  But we all know it takes more than just performers to stage a dance concert.  Please don't let us dance naked! And while we are at it, we'll not only make sure the dancers have clothes, but we are making custom designed jackets for the panels that will serve as the projection surfaces for the newest work on the program, In Plain Sight.  The fabric for these panels has already cost $400, the labor is estimated to be $300. Your contribution directly underwrites these and other costs.

In Plain Sight is a world premiere collaboration between Choreographer & Artistic Director Christopher K. Morgan, Composer Ignacio Alcover (Morgan's longtime collaborator from Musica Aperta), Photographer Kay Chernush (whose series of photographs on human trafficking inspire the work) and Projection Designer/Dance Technologist Shannon Braine.

Also on the program, Morgan will perform a world premiere solo (that still needs a costume!) with an orginal score he created with New York based composer Monstah Black, a reprise of the exuberant work Tarantella, and a special performance by students of the CityDance Conservatory in Morgan's 2002 work Ties That Bind (we made sure the students have costumes already!).

Check out the website for more information on the company and upcoming performances.


The Impact

Christopher K. Morgan & Artists recognizes that in order to do their best work dancers need to be clothed and warm. You can help us do that by making sure they do not go onstage naked! Reveal will truly be a special evening of performance, with wonderful collaborations and work that connects current cutting edge artists with the next generation of performers.  Your contributions are an important part of the perpetuation of this vitally important art form.


What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to raise $1500 to finish costuming this production, both the dancers and the set!

No matter how much money we raise the show will go on... but this campaign determines what we will be wearing!
See the supporter chart to see what you get for helping us!

*Note: the titles for each level of support are reflections of your giving level, not an exact reference to the items that will actually be purchased with the funds!

And help us spread the word! Share our campaign on your twitter and facebook pages.

story:
Short Summary

After spending most of our formative years studying classical theater, the ladies of The Others decided on an experiment. Can our experience bringing Shakespeare and Marlowe to life give us the ability to develop new stories about our experiences outside of the norm? Instead of rehashing Henry V  set in an LA 'hood, can we just talk about the experience of gentrifying the neighborhood you grew up in? 


And so we began with texts from the Mexican Revolution, the Left Bank of Paris' Queer Underground, and the Harlem Renaissance and found our story, buried deep under the covers of night. We found  a story about the lives we lead under moonlight, how badly we can behave in darkness and the lasting impact on our lovers and families in the light of day. 

Also there's some burlesque, and it gets pretty gay.

What We Need & What You Get

Thank you so much for reading this far! Your reward? Here's what we plan to do with the funds requested. We are asking for:

  • $1,000 to rent the space including lighting and stage crew
  • $250 in Hollywood Fringe Registration costs
  • $150-200 for props and set pieces
  • $150 for post cards (which are a real Fringe cultural phenomenon)
  • $350-$400 for promotion
So please donate! We want to name a character after you, help you with your love life and even arrange for you to be serenaded sometime! (see the rewards on the side)

The Impact

So while we know that there is a lot of theater in Los Angeles we want to bring your stories to you. We want to tell the story of "Online Dating While Black" or "Explaining Your Friends' Sexuality to your Grandma" or "The Highly Contagious Foot in Mouth Disease." Sure, we may need to work on our titles but we're about plays that speak to us and you. 

We love building theater and we want to do it with you.

Other Ways You Can Help

We also get it: you're broke. If this is you, don't trip! We still would like your help!

  • Come and see our show preview Saturday, June 7 (it's pay what you can)!
  • Invite your friends to see the show!
  • Invite others to this Indigogo site!
  • Volunteer to help with our front house ticket collection!
  • Give us hugs and nice messages on Facebook!
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it. :)

story:
Short Summary

VIRGINS DIE HORNY  is a daring new drama that takes you into a distorted world where relationships between lovers and friends are put to the ultimate test. 

Risky and wild. Thoughtful and heart-wrenching. Manic and disorienting. This play in not for the timid or the faint of heart …this is not your usual night at the theatre!

VIRGINS DIE HORNY is the provocative, funny, and terrifying story of Katie, a 38-year old woman, who has married for the third time in ten years. 

The play opens on Katie’s honeymoon night with James and takes the audience on a cocaine-fuelled, alcohol-drenched roller coaster ride through the tangled relationships tenuously held by Katie and her three husbands, past and present – Jamie, Jimmy, and now James.

As the play unfolds, Jimmy, Katie’s second husband crashes the honeymoon, drunk and suicidal. Jimmy, holds Katie and her new husband, James, hostage  threatening to detonate the dynamite sown into the orange life jacket he is wearing under his coat. Meanwhile, Jimmy has secretly arranged for Jamie, Katie’s first husband to join them as well.

So by the end of the first act, poor Katie finds herself held hostage with all three of her husbands – on her honeymoon!

The second act is a terrifying and sometimes funny tour de force that builds to the reluctant disclosure of a carefully kept and devastating secret that all three husbands have agreed to keep from Katie. Events late in the second act, dictate that this secret must be told, regardless of the chilling consequences … consequences unlike any that you may have seen before on the London stage.

VIRGINS DIE HORNY -- What's that about?

On one level, the title provocatively alludes to the question: ‘Is it better to have loved and lost, then to have never loved at all?’

Katie is a woman who at times feels  she is defined by the men she marries. And the husbands feel that they are meant to care and protect Katie … firmly believing that they know what’s best for her. So, the play is about love, loneliness, protecting what you value, and holding onto secrets. The title itself refers to a decision that we are all faced with, a question that each of us needs to answer in some aspects of our lives … one way or another.

The question is this: Whether you are willing to risk pain, loss, and experience of venturing outside yourself to joint others or whether you would instead choose to be afraid, unable or unwilling to aspire to happiness, sex, love, life. And to rationalise some brand of solace in valuing safety over the expense of experience.

The phrase ‘Virgins Die Horny’ suggests that safety can only be ensured by not participating. But to refrain from participating … will inevitably leave one wanting, wondering, horny.

What We Need & What You Get

We need just £30,000 to bring VIRGINS DIE HORNY  to the London stage for a four week run mid-October to mid-November, 2014.

Approximately 60% of this budget will allow us to pay our very talented cast designers and crew at the recommended Equity scale. This is not something that is usually done in London’s ‘fringe theatre’ community. 

We think it is critically important to pay our actors, designers and technicians. Please help us to support these very talented artists in this truly unique theatrical endeavour. 

Our budget will allow us to hire The Courtyard Theatre, in London's popular Shoreditch area, as well as promoting the play and creating a buzz to attract positive press coverage, allowing the play to transfer to a larger theatre. 

This is a dream only you can help us to realise.

The Impact

I have been scribbling dialogue onto yellow pads since I was 16 years old. When I was young, I was told that when you pick a story you need to keep telling it over and over again, until you get it ‘right.' 

Forty years later, with VIRGINS DIE HORNY, I feel that I finally have it right.

I have been living with the characters for over 25 years, and now that I have moved from the States to London, I feel this play is ready for the London stage.

It's time for the characters to live and breathe. I know they will touch the lives of those who come to see them. They are deep souls, they are edgy, vulnerable and funny, just like the best of us.

I have written, directed, and produced 12 of my own scripts and have worked with other playwrights bringing their scripts to the stage, often for the first time. Some of my work has been staged Off-Off Broadway in New York. 

VIRGINS DIE HORNY will be my London debut. 

Impact: Why this Play NEEDS to be produced

Some plays are seen as ‘important’ because of the context of their social significance, by the play’s relevance to the time it inhabits, and because it invites an audience to reflect on their own experiences, for better or for worse.

I believe that VIRGINS DIE HORNY will provide audiences with an opportunity to reflect on their own experiences of relationships, revealing issues that are certain to be relevant and powerful. This play explores the notion of personal, intimate safety against the backdrop of the inherent risks of intimate relationships ... and certain things that we do 'to' or 'with' those we profess to love.

herself held hostage with all three of her husbands – on her honeymoon! 
The second act is a terrifying and sometimes funny
tour de force that builds to the reluctant disclosure of a carefully kept and
devastating secret that all three husbands have agreed to keep from Katie.
Events late in the second act, dictate that this secret must be told, regardless
of the chilling consequences … consequences unlike any that you may have seen
before on the London stage.
VIRGINS DIE HORNY -- What's that about?
On one
level, the title provocatively alludes to the question: ‘Is it better to have
loved and lost, then to have never loved at all?’ 
Katie is a woman who at times feels  she is defined
by the men she marries. And the husbands feel that they are meant to care and
protect Katie … firmly believing that they know what’s best for her. So, the
play is about love, loneliness, protecting what you value, and holding onto
secrets. The title itself refers to a decision that we are all faced with, a
question that each of us needs to answer in some aspects of our lives … one way or
another. 
The question is this: Whether you are willing to
risk pain, loss, and experience of venturing outside yourself to joint others
or whether you would instead choose to be afraid, unable or unwilling to aspire
to happiness, sex, love, life. And to rationalise some brand of solace in
valuing safety over the expense of experience.
The phrase ‘Virgins Die Horny’ suggests that safety
can only be ensured by not participating. But to refrain from participating …
will inevitably leave one wanting,
wondering, horny.What We Need & What You Get We need just
£30,000 to bring VIRGINS
DIE HORNY  to the
London stage for a four week run mid-October to mid-November, 2014. 
Approximately 60% of this budget will allow us to pay our very talented cast designers and crew at the recommended Equity scale. This is not something that is usually
done in London’s ‘fringe theatre’ community. We think it is critically important to pay our actors, designers and technicians. Please help us to support these very talented artists in this truly unique theatrical endeavour. 
Our budget
will allow us to hire The Courtyard
Theatre, in London's popular Shoreditch area, as well as promoting the play and creating a buzz to attract positive
press coverage, allowing the play to transfer to a larger theatre. This is a dream only you can help us to realise. 
The Impact I have been
scribbling dialogue onto yellow pads since I was 16 years old. When I
was young, I was told that when you pick a story you need to keep telling it
over and over again, until you get it ‘right.'  
Forty years
later, with VIRGINS DIE HORNY, I feel
that I finally have it right. 
I have been
living with the characters for over 25 years, and now that I have moved from the States to
London, I feel this play is ready for the London stage. 
It's time
for the characters to live and breathe. I know they will touch the lives of
those who come to see them. They are deep souls, they are edgy, vulnerable and
funny, just like the best of us. 
I have
written, directed, and produced 12 of my own scripts and have worked with other
playwrights bringing their scripts to the stage, often for the first time. Some of my
work has been staged Off-Off Broadway in New York. VIRGINS DIE HORNY will be
my London debut. Impact: Why this Play NEEDS to be produced  Some plays are seen as ‘important’ because of the
context of their social significance, by the play’s relevance to the time it
inhabits, and because it invites an audience to reflect on their own experiences,
for better or for worse. I believe that VIRGINS DIE HORNY will provide audiences with an opportunity to reflect on their own experiences of relationships, revealing issues that are certain to be relevant and powerful. This play explores the notion of personal, intimate safety against the backdrop of the inherent risks of intimate relationships ... and certain things that we do 'to' or 'with' those we profess to love.

story:
PhysiKal Bodies presents "Capture", a dance production fully produced by Philadelphia students, dancers and artists. 

Who are We? 

We are are group of passionate dancers dedicated to unearthing the expressive power of dance! The brainchild of Dawn Mazzola and Catherine Natter, PhysiKal Bodies works to bring to light dance's ability to not only delve into emotion, but the psychological and philosophical musings of the mind. In an evening-long dance performance entitled "Capture", audience members will be offered glimpses into the lives of individuals traveling through time, with movement used as an expressive lens. This performance will premiere in September as a part of the Philadelphia Live Arts/Fringe Festival.

Our Goal:

Our goal is to make and share work that is intentional and meaningful; to our choreographers, our dancers, and hopefully to you.

Who's Involved?

Dawn Mazzola: Co-Director/Choreographer/Dancer

Dawn Mazzola holds her BS in Dance from Drexel University and is pursuing her MS in Dance/Movement Therapy and Counseling. She has worked with the Departments of Recreation with Drexel and UPenn, and with the Lithe Method. In addition to performing and choreographing in Drexel DanceConcerts and the Live Arts/Fringe Festival, she also traveled to Singapore and London to perform and study dance and movement. She has also performed with SomaticMovers in both Philadelphia and Baltimore. Improv=LIFE!

Catherine Natter: Co-Director/Choreographer/Dancer

Catherine Natter holds her BS in Dance from Drexel University and is currently pursuing her MS in Teaching Learning and Curriculum as well as her PreK-4 teaching certification. In addition to performing with Drexel Dance Ensemble, Natter has performed in the Live Arts/Fringe Festival, and in the independent dance film “Momentum” set to be released in 2014. Natter has also choreographed several works for Drexel Dance Ensemble as well as for Philadelphia Dance Academy’s Youth Ballet, and recently traveled to London on a Dance Study Tour. She currently teaches dance and creative movement at The Creative Living Room in Swarthmore, PA.  

Rahul Kerur: Lighting Design/Technician

Currently a student at Drexel University, Rahul Kerur is pursuing a dual major in Civil Engineering and Architectural Engineering as well as a Minor in Architecture. Rahul has spent the last seven years working extensively in technical theatre, working on productions ranging from dance performances to plays. Currently, he is employed at Drexel University, Mandell Theatre as Master Electrician, and has also designed lighting for the Philadelphia Live Arts/Fringe Festival. Rahul has worked as an Architectural Assistant in Singapore with DP Architects, and has also assisted with design competitions in Dubai, as well as worked with VK:a Architecture in India. Rahul has a passion for working as a theatre technician and continues to pursue every opportunity to design in conjunction with his studies. 

Dancers: 

Michele-Olivia Francois

Victoria Eileen

Mary Stickney

Karly Bais

Avery Sohn

Cara Slemmer

Alicia Tom

Haley Robinson

Corina Cleffi

Sara Nichols

Brittani Bacchi

Courtney Carey

Charlotte Ashworth

Paige Francis

What We Need:

As current University students and recent graduates one of our greatest needs is funds to help bring our vision to life. Your generous donations will help us with production costs including acquiring appropriate dance flooring, venue space, light and sound equipment, costumes and more. Our desire is to share our talent and passion for art and dance with the city of Philadelphia, and any support received is appreciated. 

When you donate you can also win prizes and get some exciting perks! So please check out our perks as you continue to explore our page. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Come see the show! Our dancers will be rehearsing all summer to put together what we predict to be an outstanding performance. If you can't donate, no worries. Come to be entertained! Tell your family and friends and come support the arts and students in Philadelphia!

Show Description: 

"Capture" is the result of a series of investigations into the individual's progression though life. How does our past influence our present? What occurs when we attempt to return? As the hour glass drains, what keeps us moving towards the future, who do we keep close, and what do we do when we suddenly find ourselves out of time? "Capture" doesn't attempt to answer these questions, but rather offers snapshots of the lives of individuals traveling through time, using movement as an expressive lens. 

Performance Dates: September 5th at 8pm. September 6th at 4pm and 8pm. 

Performance will be taking place at Power Plant Productions, located at 230 N Second Street, Philadelphia, PA 19106.

story:
What's on your mind? What are we going to do about that?

Here. Somewhere else. How do you make your voice heard?

In Oakland, In Cairo, In Bangladesh? The art of speaking your mind is a powerful force. 

Let's harness that.

The International Youth Theatre Project begins January 2014 in Oakland, CA and Bristol, England.

About The Project

Get Skills. Make a Change. Meet a community, and introduce the world to yours.

The International Youth Theatre Project is where young people create theatre pieces based on issues they pick. We use a network of international drama and applied theatre teachers and practitioners to connect each group’s project with a group of youth facing their own set of issues in another country. We learn and use emerging digital technologies to connect and create meaningful solutions and new perspectives as both groups are facilitated through their creative process.


And we let youth have a global conversation about their future.

Applied Theatre Action Institute provides a forum for public performance and feedback sessions with audiences that have an interest in hearing these voices - and we help raise that interest as we create our art. As peers, parents, community members, business people and those in local government hear directly from these youth, each project is also connected to a group in another country through digital media, fostering global understanding and community, a digital “study abroad” that actually is working to solve problems on the ground, locally.

What We Need & What You Get

As a non-profit organisation, all our funds go towards making young people's projects come to life in the way they imagine. Funds raised will go towards the costs of:

  • Renting and using performance and rehearsal spaces - while we are working with some wonderful and generous organisations, there are undoubtedly still fees that need to be payed to use their resources. Your money will help go towards rental fees both in the US and the UK and ensure our performances can go ahead in the best possible places!
  • Allowing us to purchase computers to foster the global media connection - this project is all about bringing young people together, and having the technology to do that easily and accessibly would be an incredible advantage. We just need to be able to purchase a few computers to enable to young people to access material, content, and their partner group, and make them feel like the project is really their own. 
  • Marketing and fundraising materials and campaigns - we want as many people as possible to be able to see our final performance, so we need to be able to print posters, flyers and other materials to help get the word out as much as possible. 
  • Props, costumes, set and other performance materials - while we of course want the young people to learn how to perform to a budget, we would also not want them to feel limited by lack of funds. Your donations will help us to purchase materials and resources to enrich their creative experience and allow them to explore new and exciting ways of making theatre!
  • Practitioner and staff fees - we've got tonnes of amazing people volunteering their time and skills to help on the project, and it would be great to be in a position to pay them for their efforts - and if we raise enough money then we would be delighted to be able to use some of that to do so. 

In return, as well as offering our eternal thanks, we can offer a variety of perks and opportunities for you or your business. If you have anything in mind that we haven't mentioned, do feel free to get in touch and we can discuss options!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everybody can contribute financially, but we would still value your support!

  • Get the word out! Spread the link our fundraising page across social media, and tell any friends or family that might be interested. 
  • Like us on Facebook and keep up to date with our progress.
  • Let us know if you can support us in any other way - with resources, advice, time, spaces or advertising. 
  • Come along to our fundraisers and performances and support the work of these amazing young people!

story:
I'm Jenny Larsson, a Swedish choreographer working in South Florida. My newest project, called The Forest Diaries, will take place in both Sweden and America, and deal with some of the themes I've been working on for a long time: roots, ancestry, and identity.

The aim behind the project is to investigate and explore my relationship with the deep forests of Sweden (the inner calm, the scenic and beautiful sites, but also the mystical and sometimes scary forests I’m afraid to enter). My intention is to channel all of these sensations through my dancing.

 Throughout all of July, I'll be selecting 30 sites in the forests of my homeland, one for each day of the month. There, in each spot, I will create a site specific dance piece. I will be collaborating with musical composer Dag Rosenqvist, which will be writing original music for each piece. I will also be collaborating with Bjornhult Media, who will be filming the pieces. 

The final product will be three-fold. First, I will create a 30 minute-long dance film with photographer and video artist, Edison Penafiel . The film will be screened, alongside a multimedia presentation at Girls' Club, an alternative contemporary art space in Ft Lauderdale, followed by a live performance at the Vanguard Theater, also in Ft. Lauderdale.

To do all of this, we need your support. Every little bit helps -- a five dollar donation can make a big difference in the long run! For me, it's very important to pay artists for their hard work and your donations will help make that happen. The money will pay for technicians and materials.Thank you for listening and watching this video. We really appreciate you, and are excited to begin working on this project!



What We Need 

Filming in Sweden ( July 2014)  
Producer 800  
Musician 500  
Props/Costume 100  
 
Creating Dance film (Sep-Oct 2014)  
Video Artist 800  
 
Multimedia  Screening + Live Performance (Nov-March 2014-15)  
Technology 800  
Earphones 200  
Props 200  
Tech rental 1000  
Flyer/Program sheet 300  
 
Total 4700  
     

The Impact

The forest is not just a place, but an idea. Present in fairy tales, myths, and history, it holds a great deal of weight, symbolically. For some it is a sanctuary, for others, it is a threat. Through this project, I hope to bring the forest closer to the viewer -- allowing the viewer to engage with the forest and explore their own relationship with the woods. By staging 30 site specific dances in different locations, I hope to give my viewers new perspectives and points of view, new ways of seeing nature and the way in which we interact with her. For me, the forests are of great importance to our physical, mental, and creative health. I hope to share this with my audience and, more importantly, connect with my viewers so that they may, in turn, connect with the forest.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Post my campaign on your social network pages and help spread the word in any way you can think of!

Campaign: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-forest-diaries

https://www.facebook.com/theforestdiaries

http://jennylarsson.org/

story:
This is it friends - 3 days to BlakTina 3 Dance Festival AND we need to raise at least $375 - help us to get to $1000! 

Today's featured choreographer is Yarrow Perea and guitarist Will Guesz performing "punk rock flamenco" on September 24th, 25th, 26th & 27th at Bootleg Theater.   You will be supporting boundary breaking artists like Yarrow and 9 other equally amazing choreographers in Los Angeles!   Join our art force!

All contributions are tax deductible and greatly appreciated!

story:
Icare

Mission

Le Théâtre La Cigogne, situé au Nouveau Brunswick, a pour mission d'appuyer et de promouvoir la relève artistique par la production de textes de création ou de répertoire.

Description

La compagnie du Théâtre La Cigogne à été fondée par 4 finissants du Département d'Art Dramatique de l'Université de Moncton:

  • Isabelle Bartkowiak
  • Ludger Beaulieu
  • Frédéric Melanson
  • Bianca Richard
adresse électronique : TheatreLaCigogne@gmail.com

Le projet

Icare sera un laboratoire de création hybride entre le théâtre et la musique en Janvier 2014 en vue d'une éventuelle production plus tard dans l'année. Le texte sera écrit par Matthieu Girard et sera basé sur le poème Icare de Herménégilde Chiasson. Pour l'occasion, la compagnie a approché Joey Robin Haché, jeune musicien acadien, pour prendre en main la partie musicale du spectacle. L'exode, la solitude et la honte sont des thèmes beaucoup trop brûlants en acadie pour ne pas en parler. La poésie de M. Chiasson, la plume de M. Girard et la musique de M. Haché pourront travailler ensemble pour transporter le public dans son propre monde, trop souvent ignoré.

Le pourquoi

Faire du théâtre n'est pas chose simple, et souvent l'obstacle de l'argent est le premier qui se pose dans le chemin. Le Théâtre La Cigogne essaie donc avec cette campagne de financement de ramasser les fonds de base pour payer l'auteur et le concepteur musical. Vos dons participeront donc directement à la création du spectacle. Votre participation nous est absolument indispensable! C'est pourquoi n'importe quel don est incroyablement apprécié et certaines récompenses seront remises!

  • 20$ - Votre nom au programme à toutes les représentations de Icare et sur notre page facebook.
  • 50$ - COURTE VIDÉO - Chaque personne qui donne 50$ ou plus recevra une petite vidéo personnalisée qui dit un gros merci et qui sera publiée sur notre page facebook et youtube.
  • 80$ - LONGUE VIDÉO - On vous fait une vidéo personnalisée plus longue et développée. Veuillez vous référer à notre profil youtube pour des exemples de tout ce qui est possible.
  • 150$ - En plus d'une longue vidéo, vous pourrez assister a quelques sessions de répétition en Janvier 2014 suivi d'une session de discussion. Vous ferez donc partie du processus de création!

Si vous ne pouvez pas donner:

Si vous ne pouvez pas donner, il est quand même possible de nous aider! Progagez le mot! Publiez cette page et notre vidéo sur votre facebook ou votre twitter et parlez-en! Le bouche à oreille est autant important que l'argent pour notre campagne!

L'exode, la solitude et la honte sont des thèmes beaucoup trop brûlants en acadie pour ne pas en parler. La poésie de M. Chiasson, la plume de M. Girard et la musique de M. Haché pourront travailler ensemble pour transporter le public dans son propre monde, trop souvent ignoré.Le pourquoiFaire du théâtre n'est pas chose simple, et souvent l'obstacle de l'argent est le premier qui se pose dans le chemin. Le Théâtre La Cigogne essaie donc avec cette campagne de financement de ramasser les fonds de base pour payer l'auteur et le concepteur musical. Vos dons participeront donc directement à la création du spectacle. Votre participation nous est absolument indispensable! C'est pourquoi n'importe quel don est incroyablement apprécié et certaines récompenses seront remises!

20$ - Votre nom au programme à toutes les représentations de Icare et sur notre page facebook.

50$ - COURTE VIDÉO - Chaque personne qui donne 50$ ou plus recevra une petite vidéo personnalisée qui dit un gros merci et qui sera publiée sur notre page facebook et youtube.

80$ - LONGUE VIDÉO - On vous fait une vidéo personnalisée plus longue et développée. Veuillez vous référer à notre profil youtube pour des exemples de tout ce qui est possible.

150$ - En plus d'une longue vidéo, vous pourrez assister a quelques sessions de répétition en Janvier 2014 suivi d'une session de discussion. Vous ferez donc partie du processus de création!
Si vous ne pouvez pas donner:Si vous ne pouvez pas donner, il est quand même possible de nous aider! Progagez le mot! Publiez cette page et notre vidéo sur votre facebook ou votre twitter et parlez-en! Le bouche à oreille est autant important que l'argent pour notre campagne!

story:
Clockwise from top left: Carol Mazhuvancheril, Jorge Sánchez-Díaz, Anthon Mondesir, Geovonday Jones, John Teresi, Sabra Shelly, Tara Novie, & Maria Mukuka

We are an ensemble of 8 international actors finishing their last semester of our MFA program at Brooklyn College and we're looking for backers to help fund our Spring showcase!

Our ensemble consists of artists from Zambia, Puerto Rico, Trinidad & Tobago, India, and various regions of the United States: a microcosm of the world and a reflection of our home for the last two years, Flatbush, Brooklyn. Our class is uniquely suited to meet the needs of an industry that craves and desperately needs diversity in representation to tell the stories that need to be told in 2018 and beyond.

For the first time, the Brooklyn College MFA Acting class will be conducting an innovative, two-pronged approach to our showcase: we will be creating an online video series of professionally produced scenes highlighting our diverse talents and personalities, as well as an onstage performance for industry professionals alongside the Brooklyn College BFA class on April 1, 2019 at the Clurman Theater in Theatre Row. Together, these two showcases will serve as our official introduction to the professional film, TV, and theatre world as well as the culmination of two years of rigorous study and practice.

We have so far raised $1000 of our $5000 goal. However, we need $2300 ASAP in order to pay for our online showcase. Hence, your generous contributions towards Phase I of our fundraising efforts will be geared towards paying the production company that will be handling our online reel. We will launch Phase II in February to fund theater rental for our live showcase, brochure printing, catering, and marketing costs. Any leftover funds will be given as a gift towards next year's MFA Acting showcase.

Any and all contributions are welcome and helpful. If you can't give, don't fret! Please help us out by sharing this campaign on social media and spread the word!

"Thanks, and thanks, and ever thanks,"
Anthon, Carol, Geo, John, Jorge, Maria, Sabra, and Tara

story:
Time Between Us: A New Musical

Music by Brett Schrier
Book & Lyrics by Tess Barker & Brett Schrier

Fresh out of art school, best friends Morgan and Matthew begin "real life" with the shared dream of having it all. But is it really possible to build the perfect career and the ideal personal life?  Across the span of thirty years, irresistible opportunities and heart-wrenching decisions bring each of the friends towards achieving half of their dream – and force them to leave the other half behind. A beautifully haunting portrait of best friends, passions, and time.

Our Story:

Time Between Us began as a dream between two best friends. Two years ago, Brett Schrier and Tess Barker sat down to begin writing and developing an original musical with the hopes of creating a piece of theatre that would impact the world forever! 

Now...after countless months of hard work and creative development, the New York Musical Theatre Festival has selected Time Between Us for a full production in New York City.  For those who aren't familiar with the magnitude of this achievement, several hundred musicals submit to the Next Link Project each year, and only 12 are accepted!  Many musicals produced at NYMF have gone on to become huge Broadway and Off-Broadway hits!

This production will run at The McGinn/Cazale Theatre between September 26th - October 16th, 2011.

This INCREDIBLE opportunity will give Brett & Tess a chance to bring their story to life on stage for the first time.  More importantly, it will give Time Between Us the chance to be seen by the New York theatre industry - a step that's crucial in spreading this compelling story around the world.  For Brett & Tess, this is nothing short of a DREAM COME TRUE!

Please help make the dream of Time Between Us become a reality!

The Impact:

Brett Schrier & Tess Barker are two ambitious musical theatre writers with talent and passion.  By supporting this project, you're not only investing in the future of new musical theatre.  You're giving young artists the chance to explore their passion in hopes of keeping theatre alive for years to come!


What We Need & How We'll Use It:

In order for Time Between Us to be produced this fall, Brett & Tess must raise a total of $30,000.  This budget includes: actor salaries, director, music director, designers, publicity, casting, printing, set construction, costumes, and rehearsal space (to name a few.)  Although there are many different fundraisers planned, the hope is to raise at least $5000 through this online campaign.
 
Please be generous, and note that we DO receive all donations, regardless if we reach our full goal through IndieGoGo or not.  No donation is too small ($1, $5, $10, $25, $100, $1000...)  EVERY SINGLE DOLLAR COUNTS!

Brett & Tess are determined to raise this money.  They've come this far, and they won't let lack of funds lessen their belief in this piece!  Please help them out!


Other Ways You Can Help:

*Tell everyone you know about this campaign.  Send the link to this page to anyone who may be interested in contributing.


*Post this campaign on your Facebook page, Twitter, and other social media.  Help us spread the word!


*Become a fan at:  www.facebook.com/home.php#!/timebetweenus


*Purchase a ticket to the show at: www.nymf.org/timebetweenus


*To make a donation that is 100% tax deductible (using our fiscal sponsor's non-profit status), write us at:  time.between.us@gmail.com.  We will happily provide the mailing address to send a check, and a tax receipt will be mailed to you once your check is received.


In Closing:

Developing a new musical is a challenging endeavor, but with the help and support of friends like you, Time Between Us will have a full production in New York this fall.  Thanks in advance for making this dream come true!

story:
Above is a video produced by WGN Chicago by Marcus Leshock in December 2010. WGN Chicago is not affiliated with this campaign.


About The Penguin Project

"Our penguins may not be able to fly, but that does not prevent their spirits from soaring."

The Penguin Project is a unique theatre experience dedicated to children with developmental disabilities. Working side by side with "peer mentors," children their age without disabilities, they create outstanding performances featuring professional equipment, fantastic costumes and the extraordinary talent of the actors and actresses.

Our mission is to bring out these hidden abilities in a safe and supporting environment. For many of these children, it is the first time they are able to connect or bond with people of their age. They and their parents are able to network and create friendships to last a lifetime. By performing in fantastic shows every year, children with disabilities gain self-confidence and learn communication skills essential for when they leave the comfort of the program.

The Penguin Project also includes a summer camp immersion experience to continue the project year round. We have also created a troupe for older Penguins who have graduated from the program to continue their opportunities to perform and maintain social connections.

As the Project celebrates its 10th Anniversary, the demand for the program locally and regionally has increased. However, the resources available have not. If the Penguin Project is going to continue providing these wonderful opportunities to amazing and talented children, it will need to expand.

We already have three sites in Illinois and are looking to spread to other communities around the country. The Penguin Project is currently identifying communities to launch programs. If you think you or your community would like a Penguin Project affiliate, contact us through Facebook or website below.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Join us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter at @penguin_project! You can visit our website for more information at penguinproject.org.
