Going Beyond the Fables!

The Drexel Players are back for another round of fun at the Philadelphia FringeArts Festival! This summer, we need your help to bring our latest original play AE$OP to life. 
Everyone has heard one of Aesop's fables at some point in their lives - The Tortoise and the Hare, The Dog and Its Reflection, The Boy Cried Wolf. But not everyone has taken the time to dissect, contextualize, or even plain-old understand these sometimes-twisted stories.  That's where AE$OP takes over!
AE$OP is an imaginative and immersive theatrical adaptation of the famed fables. Set in the dog-eat-dog (literally) corporate world, the tales of the fables' characters intertwine to venture beyond simple morals of right and wrong. This mature take on the stories will encourage audiences to consider what these childhood lessons truly taught us.
Who are the Drexel Players?
 Good question, ambiguous potential donor! The Drexel Players are the only student-run theater organization at Drexel University. We strive to produce quality theater, engage the student body socially, and broaden students' knowledge and involvement in the Philly theater community. 
When it comes to our productions, students participate in all aspects from acting to design to publicity. Over the past two years we have staged two successful pieces for the FringeArts festival: MONUMENT in 2012 and Parts: A Speed-Through in 2013. 
This year, we will try our hands at adaptation. We will be working in conjunction with Claire Moyer, a professional director in Philadelphia, to create another spectacular production. But we can't do that without your help!

  

What We Still Need



As college students, the Drexel Players are no strangers to being thrifty (Ramen noodles, EasyMac, sneaking into dorms to do laundry on the cheap). Despite that frugal aptitude, theater can't always be bought at a 10-for-10 sale.  We try our best, like acquiring Drexel's URBN Annex Black Box for a killer performance space, but we still have some other costs to cover: 


Scenic Design - because our characters will be sitting in style


Props - because an office needs staplers, Post-its, water-coolers

Costume - because CEO's wear ties and blouses

Sound and Lighting- addressing the needs of two vital senses


Marketing - because people need to know when and where to show up
Incidentals - because laundry detergent doesn't grow on trees
Other - because you never know
 Get involved!

 One of the best ways you can help bring AE$OP to life is by contributing to our campaign. We have a host of amazing perks for you to take advantage of, including tickets to the show, access to behind-the-scenes videoblogs, and dinner with the cast. With Flexible Funding, we will be able to use whatever money we raise, so any contribution helps! 
If you cannot contribute financially, feel free to share this campaign with your friends! Spread the word through Twitter, Facebook, email, or even carrier pigeon. Anything helps! If you're interested in donating creative or administrative services to the production, please email us at drexelfringe@gmail.com. THANK YOU!


AE$OP by the Drexel Players
Performed at the URBN Annex Black Box Theater3401
Filbert Street, Philadelphia, PA 19104


September 5, 6 at 7 PMSeptember 6 at 11 PMSeptember 7 at 6 PMSeptember 8 at 7 PMSeptember 11, 12, 13 at 8 PMSeptember 14 at 2 PM

story:
www.neharadance.org



Nehara symbolizes the challenge of the Jewish modern orthodox woman combining a professional dance career without compromising her observant way of life.

Revolutionary within the dance world and the orthodox world – Nehara's performances are open to all audiences - orthodox and secular, men and women,  Nehara's unique creative works serve as vehicles bringing together Jewish and universal content and bridging the Jewish world and the professional dance world.

What is important to us is to bring under one roof the passion and love we have for our Torah-based belief system, raising our children in a religious home, and maintaining high standards as professional dancers.

It  also important for us to be able to serve as a bridge between the secular and orthodox communities in Israel. Sitting next to each other in a theater during a performance, talking about and sharing one's feelings about the performance are other ways of doing that.


For more info, check our Press Kit.



Your support counts!

Nehara Dance Group has brought a new vision to the world of dance and the Jewish community. Over the past three years we have performed to sold out theaters throughout Israel, performed for Jewish communities abroad, given workshops and lectures in schools to students about the complexity of our way of lives , combining our observance of Jewish faith and laws with our passion and will to dance professionally.

Today, all this is in danger of coming to an end.

No artistic institution including dance companies can survive anywhere in the world without government and/or private funding. We receive neither.  We are a young group with a big vision and have been promoting ourselves independently both artistically and financially.

With your support we can continue:

  • performing
  • giving workshops
  • speaking to youth
  • expanding our artistic and communal activity.

Your support will allow us to keep our "home"and it will enable us to continue bringing the important messages of diversity within the Jewish faith and the extraordinary richness of the culture of dance to thousands of people. 

Since our founding, Nehara Dance Group has been struggling to survive on a daily basis.  Dance is an expensive enterprise, not widely funded.  We want to continue advancing our important message, inspiring change within the world of modern orthodoxy and dance.

It is not easy being a professional dancer with the rigorous schedule and demands of the profession (and our personal lives.)  Add to that the fact that we have a burning desire to remain true to our convictions - observing Shabbat, dress code, covering hair, you can see how complex our lives must be.  But, with Nehara this complexity is transformed into an opportunity to be  complete within our lives – and to share that completeness with thousands of others.


5 Ways to help

There are many ways in which you can help and support us and our vision:

  1. Contribute! - a great place to start is to buy one of our awesome perks. Scroll up to find out more!
  2. Join our community - come and meet the dancers and become one of us by joining our mailing list at our web page: Nehara's Web Page
  3. Share with at least 5 friends - Spread the word to everybody you know that will be interested in supporting Judaism, dance and women. Talk to them on your social media platform (e.g. Twitter, Facebook, Google+).
  4. Become an ambassador - If you believe in our way and want to be one of us and help promote Nehara, join our ambassador program.
  5. Put posters up in your community - go and download our crowdfunding poster. Print the posters out and put them up in your Synagogue, local coffee shops, universities, colleges, schools, and elsewhere!
Remember, if you have questions, be sure to join the Nehara community at Nehara's blog.


Perks

Nehara Dance Group invites you to a special performance

of our newest creation:“ Draft “.

Be a part of our audience and after the show come backstage and meet the dancers.

*** This can be a great gift to give to a friend in Israel :)

Gerard Bachar Center in Jerusalem - Monday February 9th at 9 pm

Only $35 Perk!!!



$5

Thank you. You are great. Every dollar counts! you will be Listed on Nehara Dance Group website for showing your support for the campaign! 

contributions are tax-deductible.


$15

The Nehara dancers will thank you personally in a personal video sent to your email. contributions are tax-deductible.

$35

Receive our unique full size poster of one of the beautiful dancers of Nehara. Signed and dedicated personally to you (Shipment included).
contributions are tax-deductible.

$60

If you want a sweet memory of our performance or you are unable to come see us perform in person, you can still enjoy watching the beautiful artistry of the women of Nehara. We will send you a personally signed copy of our DVD specially dedicated to you (Shipment included). contributions are tax-deductible.


$250

Feel the true spirit of Nehara. Come watch us work and sweat in any one of our daily rehearsals and get to know the dancers up close and personal. Also you will receive a signed group photo with you. contributions are tax-deductible.


$1,000

Your contribution will fund a workshop and performance for children in a school. Nehara is deeply dedicated to promoting the education of culture and Judaism among students. You can help us do so. We will send you photos of the meeting and a big thank you from the children. ( only available in Israel ).

contributions are tax-deductible.


$3,500
Daniella Bloch, Founder and Artistic Director of Nehara Dance Group will come to your community to lecture on the inspiring story of the creation of Nehara.
( Flight and accommodation not included in the price ).
contributions are tax-deductible.

$5,000
By being our angel sponsor you will allow us to continue inspiring change in the Jewish communities, orthodox woman and children. Your name and/or company logo will appear on our web site and in all our promotional materials for an entire year. contributions are tax-deductible.

What so unique about Nehara?


Israel's dance world is very rich and developed, with an abundance of dance companies, large and small. But, there is no high-level, professional dance group which provides both a viable platform for dancers who live and believe in a religious lifestyle and a repertory that combines Jewish and universal themes.

Nehara expresses its uniqueness in two major arenas. First, we aim to create a bridge between two worlds -- Judaism and professional dance -- ensuring that all performances will maintain the highest professional standards of dance and theater. Our goal is to ensure that these two worlds, rather than opposing each other, will complement and strengthen each other.

Second, Nehara  performs before mixed audiences. By showing that a religious way of life is part and parcel of the members of the dance company, we aspire to attract the religious sector to our performances and similarly share our life experiences and art form with the secular sector.


How it all started

Daniella Bloch (founder & Artistic Director): "How does something go from being just an idea to becoming an actual living, breathing active project?

Nehara Dance Group started as an idea, a dream. At the time I didn't really realize what it meant or where it would take me but I knew that it felt right, at home, something I had to do.

The idea of Nehara is an outgrowth from my personal biography --  my life as a professional dancer alongside my belief and way of life as a Jewish orthodox woman -- and all the struggles that go along with these two alternate lifestyles.

Dance and religion do not mesh easily. On the contrary - they clash in almost every way possible. Yet, ever since I can remember, I have juggled my way between these two opposite worlds. However, growing up in a religious home which also had a great passion for the arts, gave me the strength and willpower to live and grow within both my " identities," pursuing a very demanding career as a dancer while continuing to observe a traditional Jewish way of life keeping Shabbat, Kashrut laws and such.

Everything was a battle, a struggle to be who I am without compromise. But in the end , compromise was everywhere, on both sides.

From these experiences, these hardships, the idea of Nehara was born. Nehara is  a professional dance group providing a home, a professional feeding ground for orthodox female dancers who want to promote their careers as performers without compromising their religious way of life.  But, it is also more than that.  Over time, as I wanted to share my experiences with my religious friends I would invite them to performances of mine.  For many of them this was their first exposure to dance and it was a real eye-opener.  All of a sudden they began to understand the many ways in which one's body can speak, tell a story and share profound emotional experiences.  To this day, they remain a loyal and engaged audience.  

Nehara , which means light in Hebrew, represents for me the place of something whole, fulfilled, a great passion and love for what we do , living as we do."


Questions & Answers

How is it that orthodox women perform before mixed audiences ( men and women )?

We believe that as a dancer and artist it is important to be a part of the dance community. This demands a high level of performance.  It also exposes dancers to what is new and upcoming within the dance field, enables them to be part of the community and take part and contribute to the changes that are taking place. Without this you become irrelevant. It is like any community, you must be physically part of and participate in the communal activities.  It this case, this translates into rehearsals and performances.  We feed off each other's successes and creations. This is how you become excellent.

As individual Jewish women, performing only for women is not part of our belief system. We believe in respecting our bodies and our place within the Jewish community and keeping to the traditional laws of Judaism but men seeing us dance is not an issue for us.. What is important to us is to bring under one roof the passion and love we have for our Torah-based belief system and raising our children in a religious home and our professional lives as dancers.  

It is also important for us to be able to serve as a bridge between the secular and orthodox communities in Israel. Sitting next to each other in a theater during a performance is one way of doing that. 

Who funds us?

No one. For the past three years we have been functioning on a low - no budget. Private funding has been invested in the group by Daniella Bloch ( Artistic Director) who deeply believes in this venture and its importance. In addition, we received a modest one-time grant from the Mifal Hapayis in Israel for a new work. 

Where do we perform? 

Nehara has performed in some of  Israel's major theaters - Suzanne Dellal Center, Tel Aviv, The Gerard Bahar Center, Jerusalem. Inbal Theater, Tel Aviv.

We participated in several major dance festivals - “Between Heaven and Earth” (Jerusalem), “Machol Lohet” ( Tel Aviv ), “Emunah Festival for the Arts” (Beit Raban ), “International Exposure” (Tel Aviv )  and the major dance festival " Arte Sacro " in Madrid.

We also perform in schools to students and give lectures and workshops on the connection between dance and religion.

Do all of our dance pieces correspond with Jewish Issues?

No. We believe artists need to bring their entire selves and experiences from life to the stage.  Therefore, Nehara's creations deal with universal issues such as womanhood and our daily struggles, alongside relevant Jewish issues and content, such as prayer, spiritual journeys, covering one's hair, etc..

Does the group work only with women?

Yes. Within the studio we work only with women professionals - Dancers, Choreographers, Teachers, Rehearsal Directors, Costume designers, etc.

Do we promote dance education to students?

Yes. We deeply believe in the importance of what we do and its educational aspect. Some of us  are teachers as well, and we use this platform to educate children on the importance of understanding the complexity and possibility of fusing these two ways of life together - dance and religion. 

Nehara Dance Group is part of the Israel's Sal Tarbut Artzi, an educational program offering cultural programming for high school, grade school, and kindergarten children all over Israel.

Where will the funding go?

The funding will go to studio and theater rentals, costumes, lighting design, dancers fees, set designs, and other production costs.

How does the orthodox community accept us? 

Some people are extremely excited and moved by what Nehara Dance Group is doing. They feel it is sorely needed with the Jewish orthodox community and brings a new and unique platform for dialogue and change.

Of course there are also those who object to us and our ideology.

We are happy both opinions exist.

story:
The Cinema Theater has been a neighborhood institution since it opened in 1914. By the late 1920's as many as two dozen movie houses served the city neighborhoods of Rochester. With the advent of television and the rise of suburban multiplexes, The Cinema is now Rochester's last neighborhood movie theater.

Through the century, The Cinema has renovated in order to survive. The wooden benches and dirt floor of the original 'flea pit' gave way to an Art-Deco makeover in the 1950s. In 1985, The Cinema once again modernized extensively. In 2006, current owner John Trickey stepped in for much needed improvements, including a new roof and the digital marquee.

We are committed to staying open no matter what it takes. The one change we must make to stay open is the purchase of a digital projector. By early 2014, film prints will no longer be available. The cost of this projector is approximately $70,000. We don't expect our patrons to contribute every penny of this, but every donation from the community brings us closer to our goal.

We have been overwhelmed by the generosity our patrons! We are now within $25,000 of our goal. Please keep donating to The Cinema. Your help means everything.

Please, support your neighborhood movie house! Save The Cinema Theater! Make its 100th birthday the greatest yet!

Check out the great perks your generosity will bring!

story:
Homo File's Story

Homo File is a Queer history performance project chronicling the life of iconoclast Samuel Steward (1909-1993). Steward was a college professor, friend to Gertrude Stein and Dr. Alfred Kinsey, a groundbreaking author of homoerotic fiction, an influential tattoo artist, and sexual rebel who lived in the Bay Area before dying in his 80s, nearly forgotten.

                                                    

Samuel Steward's life story is an essential Civil Rights story and reflects the experiences of many LGBTQ ancestors whose lives have been erased from the historical record and tragically forgotten. We are preserving Sam's legacy and we need your help to make it happen. Your contribution will help produce the first staged production based on Sam Steward's life and you’ll also be supporting an incredible team of artists.

The title Homo File is a fusion of Sam Steward's Stud Files (meticulous records he kept of his sex life) and "homophile,"  the alternative to "homosexual," used by early gay Civil Rights activists.  Homo File combines  performance, original music, puppetry, aerial dance, video, and visual art to examine Steward’s life 20 years after his death. Because Sam meticulously described all of his sexual encounters, his memoirs fill in missing pieces of Queer history (1930 through 1969) when the majority of the nation’s LGBT community lived underground in fear of being fired, jailed and socially ostracized. His creative output provides windows into the life of a gay man who accepted his sexual orientation and examined his impulses as sources of self-knowledge and artistic vision.

Homo File On Stage

Homo File has had a fantastic run at CounterPULSE. Even Rudolph Valentino made an appearance:


Homo File Fundraising

We need to raise $15,000 to reach our final fundraising goal and we need your help to make it happen. Your generous donation will go directly to our artists, actors, musicians, puppeteers and designers. Your contribution will also help cover production costs ranging from studio and theater rental to sets, props, costumes and administrative support.

When you make a tax-deductible donation to our project we have an array of fabulous rewards for your generosity:

  • A stunning 5"x7" print of the original poster art for Homo File. This poster was designed, produced, and cut from a linoleum block by the artist  Katie Gilmartin of The Queer Ancestors Project!

                                          

  • Your choice of a photographic recreation of Samuel Steward's Polaroids by Gary Ivanek. These pictures re-envision Sam's underground life.  You can choose a photo from our 2012 shoot focused on Sam's kink life or from our 2014 shoot focused on Sam's tattoo life.

     

  • Printed copies of Original Homo File Shadow Puppets created by multi-talented Diego Gomez. Own your piece of Homo File ephemera from behind the scenes!

        

  • An invitation to an exclusive post-show party with Homo File's cast and crew. Meet the artists, share the joy, and enjoy some sweet treats & drinks

  • Artistic Coaching with Homo File's Artistic Director Seth Eisen. Hone your craft, develop your artistic ideas, and learn invaluable creative skills during a one-on-one session

                                       

  • A private Homo File excerpt performance at the venue of your choosing. See excerpts of the show or the full-length affair in your home, at your party, or anywhere you want... just the cast, you, and your guests

Homo File Effect

Eye Zen Presents has a rich history of producing stunning theatrical events from Blackbird: Honoring A Century of Pansy Divas to Buffet Flats. Since 2007, our productions have told the stories of little-known and under-recognized LGBTQ people whose lives contributed to the formation of contemporary Queer culture. 

This riveting production tells the fascinating human story that fills gaps in LGBTQ history and speaks to the pain and beauty of living an underground life. Sam's legacy must go on and you play a crucial role in helping to share his story with audiences in San Francisco and beyond. Our goal is to take the show on tour and that begins with the success of the premiere. Your contribution to this project will help over 900 people learn about the legacy of Sam Steward. We cannot make this dream without the generosity of our community. Help Homo File today and make this dream a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word about the work we are doing by sharing this campaign. Use the Indie Go Go share tools, post the link on social media, and bring your friends on board.

If you can't make a financial contribution or you want to contribute more, volunteer with us. Email info@eyezen.org to learn about how you can be involved with Homo File.
story_txt:
Homo File's StoryHomo File is a Queer history performance project chronicling
the life of iconoclast Samuel Steward (1909-1993). Steward was a college
professor, friend to Gertrude Stein and Dr. Alfred Kinsey, a groundbreaking
author of homoerotic fiction, an influential tattoo artist, and sexual rebel
who lived in the Bay Area before dying in his 80s, nearly forgotten.                                                     
Samuel Steward's life story is an essential Civil Rights story
and reflects the experiences of many LGBTQ ancestors whose lives have been
erased from the historical record and tragically forgotten. We are preserving
Sam's legacy and we need your help to make it happen. Your contribution will
help produce the first staged production based on Sam Steward's life and you’ll
also be supporting an incredible team of artists.
The title Homo File is a fusion
of Sam Steward's Stud Files (meticulous records he kept of his
sex life) and "homophile,"  the alternative to "homosexual," used
by early gay Civil Rights activists.  Homo File combines  performance, original music, puppetry,
aerial dance, video, and visual art to examine Steward’s life 20 years after
his death. Because Sam meticulously described all of his sexual encounters, his
memoirs fill in missing pieces of Queer history (1930 through 1969) when the
majority of the nation’s LGBT community lived underground in fear of being
fired, jailed and socially ostracized. His creative output provides windows
into the life of a gay man who accepted his sexual orientation and examined his
impulses as sources of self-knowledge and artistic vision.


Homo File On StageHomo File has had a fantastic run at CounterPULSE. Even Rudolph Valentino made an appearance:
Homo File FundraisingWe need to raise $15,000 to reach our final fundraising goal and we need your help to make it happen. Your generous donation will go directly to our artists, actors, musicians, puppeteers and designers. Your contribution will also help cover production costs ranging from studio and theater rental to sets, props, costumes and administrative support.When you make a tax-deductible donation to our project we have an array of fabulous rewards for your generosity:
A stunning 5"x7"
print of the original poster art for Homo File. This poster was
designed, produced, and cut from a linoleum block by the artist  Katie Gilmartin of The Queer Ancestors Project!

people whose lives contributed to the formation of contemporary Queer
culture. 
This riveting production tells the fascinating human story that fills gaps in

life. Sam's legacy must go on and you play a crucial role in helping to
share his story with audiences in San Francisco and beyond. Our goal is to take
the show on tour and that begins with the success of the premiere. Your

story:
T.I.M. (The Improvised Musical)

T.I.M. (The Improvised Musical) is Milwaukee's only musical improv show and also one of the largest shows the city has! T.I.M. has been going three years strong now because of the help of amazing fans and Milwaukee pride! T.I.M. has  been chosen to be in the New York Musical Improv Festival's I.P.O. (Initial Public Offering showcase), and we could not be more excited to represent the Brew City out in NYC! 

Milwaukee’s only fully improvised musical brings you a musical that you will only see that night and never again! Based only on an audience suggestion for a title of a musical that has never been made before, 7 cast members, a live 4 piece band, and a light designer bring you a Broadway-style musical totally off the cuff. 

Voted by Shepherd Express reader’s in the Top 3 Theatre Companies of Milwaukee in 2012 (along side The Rep and First Stage), T.I.M. is 3 years old and growing larger and larger each month. T.I.M. has developed a touring company that not only provides their live shows to live audiences both in Wisconsin and in other states, but also has taught workshops and classes for Universities. 

Although T.I.M. is a completely improvised show, and will make you laugh every time you come and join in the experience, T.I.M. also goes outside of the improvised show norms and also brings drama, romance, darkness, and above all a story worth seeing!

What exactly we need donations for!

T.I.M. has been getting bigger and bigger with each show, however The Improvised Musical is still a small independent theatre group. We want to be able to transport all of our band, actors, and crew to NYC and pay for room and boarding. Our entire crew works very hard to put on the best show possible one time a month, and this entire trip is very important to them. 

Different things we need donations for: 

  • Transportation for 12 to 18 people. 
  • Room and board for 12 to 18 people. 
  • Transporting equipment for a 5 piece band as safe for the instruments as possible.
  • Registration for NYMIF.

    The Impact

    Milwaukee isn't known worldwide for our comedy scene. However, if you've been to an improv show, a sketch show, a stand up set you know that we have so much talent here right in our hometown. Representing Milwaukee in New York City is such a huge honor for T.I.M. (The Improvised Musical). We plan to make Milwaukee as proud as we can!

story:
The Idea

Producing plays for our University degree has sparked our passion for theatre. We have each written a short play linked to mental health, that we would like to put on in a theatre in Newport, in November/December 2014. 

The entire project will be non-profit. We are doing it for the experience and to share our stories. 


What We Need

£200 Set, props and costumes.
£50 Printing costs. 

The minimum funding amount on here is £500, however we intend to put the plays on with whatever funding we get! Ideally we need £250 however the more we have the more flexibility and advertising we can have. 

We are a non-profit team, we will use student actors and technical teams, any remaining funds will be donated to a mental health charity. 


The Impact

1 in 4 people experience mental health difficulties each year. Yet mental health still has a stigma attached to it. We want to make it okay to talk about and to show that it can be entertaining, hopefully making it a little less frightening. 

Obviously we can't cover every mental health issue and eventuality in two short plays but we are so excited to write, direct and produce our own pieces and our main goal is to get the stories out there. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Any contribution is gratefully received, however if you can't donate and wish to help in some way please share our project with your friends. We also aim to produce a list of costume, set and props which you may donate to if you are able.

story:
Our Story


Hola...I am an actress, writer and community activist from the South Bronx and for the last 3 years I've been writing a one-woman show about an "unnamed" New York City actress who wants to transform into 1940's film star Maria Montez..but first she has to take a Journey, a Journey to the Dominican Republic that will forever change her life. I was  awarded a grant to write the show and now I need your help in order to bring the show to life. 
This is the first time I will be performing an Orginal work that will be debuting in my hometown of the South Bronx...a community that is in need of artists and stories that will help them continue living with hope in neighborhoods that can at times be harsh. I know that my work will continue to evolve here in the South Bronx.  


ABOUT THE SHOW 

(The show will debut September 29-October 3,2011... 6 shows. Directed by Padraic Lillis)
Tickets go on sale June 29
Pretending to be Maria Montez Queen of Technicolor is a one woman multi-media show that tells the story of an “Unnamed” New York City actress as she is transforming into the 1940’s Dominican Hollywood film star María Montez, and in the process reconnects with her Dominican roots, her mother, and explores the strength of her spirituality while living in the South Bronx. For the performance Dalia Davi alternates between story telling, two short films and photo projections. There will be a talk back after each performance with the intention of gaining feedback on the themes raised during the performance. Including the search of an identity in a foreign country, escapism, spirituality, the parallels of the “Unnamed” actress's Journey and María Montez’s Journey, the power that images and Hollywood have on the sub-conscience, and the role of the artist during a time of war. 

ABOUT MARÍA MONTEZ
Maria Montez (June 6, 1912 – September 7, 1951) was a Dominican born motion picture actress who gained fame and popularity in the 1940s as an exotic beauty starring in a series of filmed-in-Technicolor costume adventure films. Her screen image was that of a hot-blooded Latin seductress, dressed in fanciful costumes and sparkling jewels. She became so identified with these adventure epics that she became known as "The Queen of Technicolor." Over her career, Montez appeared in 26 films, 21 of which were made in United States and five in Europe. 


The Impact

On June 3, 2011 I read an excerpt of the show to a group of 60 kids from Maine, kids that had never been to the South Bronx and their response was amazing. They were so eager to learn more about different cultures and understand our community, which at times has not been well represented in the mass media. The story I am telling with this show will have a tremendous enlightening impact for the youth of the South Bronx and all over the country.

 Once I am able to raise the money to produce the show, I plan to tour schools, translate the show into Spanish and hopefully take it to the Dominican Republic and other Spanish speaking countries. But what I wish the most is to raise awarness within the New York City theater community about the budding artist community of the South Bronx, and to invite everyone to come to Pregones Theater, which is one of the most beautiful theaters in the City. 


What We Need & What You Get

Why we need to raise $10,000


Theater Rental $2000.00 

( 20x $100.00 donations = can help us pay for the space! Yay!!)


The cost of the 2 Short Films $1000.00 (40x $25.00 donation will help with= Editing and shooting)

(one of the short films was shot in the Dominican Republic and the other in the South Bronx...we need to edit them and make sure they are top quality)


$2000.00 will help with this very important Publicity Cost....we gotta let the audience know about it!!!

(Posters, post cards, flyers, playbill, website, publicist)



$5000. will help us pay the production team and technical materials 

5x $1000.00 donations= A beautiful looking show!!!


(it is very important to be able to pay fellow artist for their contributions and collaborations)

(Wardrobe, set/lighting/sound design, video projections, directors fees) 


I have been very lucky to have people who believe in my vision and are trying their best to help us produce this production at a low cost without compromising production value and quality!!


 The perks we are offering you as you help this production manifest......some involve a photo KISSED by Maria Montez herself ;)....Tickets to a live taping of the show...Tickets to our 1940's theme Vip gala....and other perks!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please follow us on our 

Facebook page, twitter and website www.daliadavi.com

help us spread the word about the show, 

buy (lots of) tickets.. available June 29, 2011......AND


Start thinking of The South Bronx as a place where you can go see good quality theater and baseball!! 


Thank you xoxo!!!!
